column2: Grandmaster Robert Byrne of Indianapolis took the lead in the United States Chess Championship at the Empire Hotel here last night by defeating Dr. Anthony Saidy of Los Angeles.

PARIS -- Today for the thirteenth conseuctive time Averell Harriman will knock at Hanoi's door and suggest some means of starting down the road to Vietnam peace. The North Vietnamese delegation to these Paris talks about talks -- diplomatic euphemism for going around the mulberry bush -- will almost surely once again say "No" in several thousand words.

Crisis requires what logic also supports. It is imperative that New York State join with New York City and the Federal Government in permitting the city to alter welfare regulations and replace "special grants" with "flat grants."
PITTSBURGH, July 16 -- The leadership of the United Steelworkers of America today ordered that a strike vote be taken among the membership next Tuesday.
LITTON Industries, patriarch of the conglomerate world, has apparently ironed out its problems and the company seems back on the path to rising profits.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- After negotiations to end the Chicago telephone strike collapsed, Mr. Bailey sent John Criswell, the National Committee's treasurer, who is in charge of convention arrangements, to Chicago to talk with the "principals there."
MILWAUKEE, July 16 -- Controversy has followed Marty Riessen to the crossroads of his tennis career and may force a change in his status from amateur to professional before the year ends.
NEWARK, July 16 -- Two Army demolition experts disarmed a time bomb in a trash can outside the Mexican consulate and Mexican national airlines offices here early today.

NEW DELHI, July 16 -- It was confirmed in New Delhi today that more than 600 Chinese-trained guerrillas had infiltrated across the Indian-Burmese border and were hiding in thick jungles surrounding Kohima, the state capital of Nagaland.

An imposter was "discovered" yesterday among the 24 powerboats scheduled to start in today's Hennessy New York Grand Prix ocean race around Long Island. The nonstop course measures 253 nautical miles and the first prize is $2,000.
This spring was a good one for Earl and Marianna Weaver. After 20 years in the minor leagues, he was promoted to a coach for the Baltimore Orioles, and life became very enjoyable for the two of them.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Senate Finance Committee, seeking to help ease air traffic congestion, moved today to exempt the Federal Aviation Administration from a Congressional mandate for personnel reductions.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Senate probably will accept, without controversy, changes in three major bills affecting the securities industry, which were passed by the House yesterday, officials here believe.

PRAGUE, July 16 -- Reliable sources reported tonight that the Soviet Union and its allies had insisted that Czechoslovakia yield to demands to meet them in two weeks to justify her democratic reforms.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 16 -- The Larchmont Race Week sailing, beset by light airs since it began last Saturday, was washed out altogether today because of an oily calm on Long Island Sound.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- In response to rapidly growing interest in Negro history and culture, the National Endowment for the Humanities is awarding $70,000 to seven colleges for summer workshops on the topic.

A national citizens' group concerned with Indian affairs charged today that "a concerted effort is being made to assimilate Indian children into white society, without regard to the wishes of the Indian people themselves."

George H. (Pete) Bostwick and Rigan McKinney will have their names added to those in the Hall of Fame at the National Museum of Racing at Saratoga on the morning of Aug. 5. George D. Widener, president of the museum, will preside over the induction ceremony.
MOSCOW, July 16 -- Two blue-and-white Pan American jet airliners landed at Sheremetyevo International Airport here today to start United States service between New York and Moscow.

FASHION shows during the lunch hour have become a regular thing in Bryant Park. So yesterday, when a runway was set up in the park's east end, men clustered about hoping to ogle the usual group of young and willowy models. They were in for a surprise. The show was given by Lane Bryant, the store at Fifth Avenue and 40th Street that specializes in "clothes for the fuller woman."

Nelson Rockefeller's campaign is something less than a smash hit. He had hoped to be leading all the popularity polls by this time, but he is running barely even with Vice President Humphrey and behind Senator McCarthy in the last nationwide Gallup tally.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -The Administration's proposed tax on expenditures by American travelers abroad, long on its deathbed, received the final blow today.

AND what happened last Sunday to the Porsche factory team at Watkins Glen? It was like one of those days when the air-conditioning breaks down, the credit cards have disappeared, there's a gas leak in the kitchen and the cat comes in sopping wet from God-knowswhere.

Supporters of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy announced yesterday a month-long campaign -- culminating in a series of nationwide rallies on Aug. 15 -- to convince the delegates to the Democratic National Convention that their man would be the party's strongest candidate in November.

BRIDGEWATER, Conn. -- Mrs. Van Wyck Brooks has lived in many houses. First, there was 81 Irving Place, near Gramercy Park, where she was born Gladys Rice 82 years ago. In his office there, her father, a nose and throat specialist, treated such famous patients as Mark Twain and Edwin Booth.
The Federal Government acted yesterday to make an additional $600-million available for home mortgage lending.

BALTIMORE, July 16 -- The Society of Jesus announced today that the Very Rev. Edward J. Sponga, head of its 800-member Maryland Province, had resigned his post and was leaving the order to get married.
The election of three first vice presidents in the metropolitan-banking department of the Bankers Trust Company was announced yesterday by William H. Moore, chairman of the board.
I read the July 8 letter of John Sampson concerning his "ordeal at Kennedy Airport."
Ernest Willis, 12 years old, stood on Governors Island one morning this week and pointed to a huge Norwegian freighter moored at a pier in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The organizers of the Poor People's Campaign plan to send a 51st state delegation representing "the state of hunger" to both the Republican and Democratic National Conventions.
A three-way investigation was being made yesterday into the disappearance of more than $28,000 worth of platinum from a freight terminal at Kennedy International Airport.

PITTSBURGH, July 16 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy sought today to swell his delegate strength in Pennsylvania by building up public pressure on uncommitted delegates and those favorable to but not finally committed to Vice President Humphrey.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 16 -- Major enemy forces have drawn back from the area around Saigon over the last two weeks, coincident with a series of secret, top-level strategy sessions in which enemy leaders are believed to have discussed plans for their next offensive.
YORK, Pa., July 16 -- Policemen have been placed on 12-hour shifts and their days off and vacations have been canceled following racial disturbances.
UPPSALA, Sweden, July 16 -- Following is the statement on human rights approved today by the Fourth Assembly of the World Council of Churches:
A plea by a mentally ill mother that her three young children be cared for by her 48-year-old mother was rejected yesterday by the Appellate Division in favor of "extremely warm" foster parents.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A witness before a Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into stock-market commissions described today what he called "the arrangement," whereby he channels commissions earned on New York Stock Exchange transactions to brokers who are not members of the exchange.
Three Columbia Law School students asked a Federal court here yesterday to bar the state from questioning prospective lawyers about their private beliefs and associations.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) -- The House voted today to provide live, color television coverage of the inauguration of President Johnson's successor next Jan. 20.
LONDON, July 16 -- James Earl Ray, who is accused of assassinating the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., has decided to give up his fight against extradition.
The failure of Governor Rockefeller to appoint a successor to Senator Robert F. Kennedy is becoming a disservice to New York and the nation.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Congressional leaders abandoned plans today for adjournment before the national political conventions in August. Their decision prompted President Johnson to renew his call for Congress to complete action on what he termed "vital legislation" in a post-convention session.

Spokesmen for the American Guild of Variety Artists and the American Federation of Musicians, which have jurisdiction over variety artists and musicians, said yesterday they were not aware of any mistreatment or abuse of their members in South Vietnam.
NEWARK, July 16 -- Plans for the construction of a 23-acre campus for the new Essex County College in downtown Newark were approved today by the Essex County Board of School Estimate.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles scored their seventh straight victory tonight, a 4-2 triumph over the Chicago White Sox. The victory was the Orioles' sixth straight under their new manager, Earl Weaver.

After eight months of study, Pechiney Enterprises, Inc. and the Howmet Corporation yesterday announced their decision to build a primary aluminum reduction plant in Maryland's Frederick 20 miles from the District of Columbia.

LOS ANGELES, July 16 -- The possibility of a plot to poison Sirhan B. Sirhan, accused as the assassin of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, has been considered by authorities, and steps taken to thwart it, Sheriff Peter Pitchess of Los Angeles County said today.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Food and Drug Administration proposed today that tablets used to treat vertigo be removed from the market.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd has asked for a Federal appeals court here to overturn a lower court decision that two columnists did not violate his right of privacy, it was disclosed today.

GENEVA, July 16 -- President Johnson informed the Disarmament Conference here today that the United States and the Soviet Union expected to decide "shortly" the time and place for their proposed talks for limiting ballistic missiles.
A capacity audience assembled Monday evening at the Dance Theater Workshop's loft at 215 West 20th Street for the first in the group's new Mondays at Nine series.
The stock market stumbled through another low-key retreat yesterday with major indicators closing at or near their lowest levels of the day.
Dr. Alexander B. Platt, a key official in the disciplining of Columbia students, has resigned as associate dean for student affairs at Columbia College.
HARTFORD, July 16 -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd was roundly booed and repeatedly heckled this afternoon as he pleaded at a public hearing for strict state control of firearms.

Once the world lightweight champion with more flash than fury, Ismael Laguna hopes a new style and a new manager will help him achieve another title opportunity with a triumph tonight over Victor Melendez at Madison Square Garden.
Metals futures closed mostly lower yesterday on commodities markets here.

As a member of the National Kindergarten Society's board, I agree with Nancy Akers Goss [letter July 10] that "all youngsters, especially in depressed areas, are in need of costly, all-out crash programs to teach the basics of reading and other English-language skills."

" You are powerless." Mrs. Thelma Johnson, an assistant commissioner of the city's Community Development Agency, said last night. "You can't hire, fire, buy equipment, call a principal on the carpet -- ."

UPPSALA, Sweden, July 16 -- The World Council of Churches declared today that the legal right of the individual to refrain from participation in "particular wars" on grounds of conscience must be regarded now as essential to the protection of fundamental human rights.

PARIS, July 16 -- An official of the National Liberation Front -- the political arm of the Vietcong -- was reported today to have voiced the Front's opposition to international supervision of elections to form a postwar Government in South Vietnam.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- Plans to hold the 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago were dealt a serious blow this afternoon when the Illinois Bell Telephone Company rejected a union proposal for binding arbitration.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Wednesday, July 17 -- The Baghdad radio reported today that the Iraqi Government had been overthrown and that President Abdel Rahman Arif had been stripped of his powers and pensioned off.
CAPETOWN, July 16 (UPI) -- Doctors who pioneered the world's first human heart transplants ended a symposium today convinced that such transplants will one day become commonplace.
LONDON, July 16 -- Michael Eugene, Ray's British attorney, said the suspect had signed a statement accepting extradition rather than to pursue an appeal.
DENVER, July 16 -- A global warning system has been formed to protect high-flying airliners from spacecraft debris falling out of orbit.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 16 -- The Council of Latin-American Bishops, in a working paper made public today, contends that South America's choice is "between violent change and pacific change."
Drivers for the United Parcel Service, who voted last week to end a 10-week strike, began returning to work last night through the picket lines of striking mechanics.
DO the experiences of the modern black African republics really have much relevance for the American Negro?
Prices eased slightly on the American Stock Exchange yesterday for the second day in succession. Volume, however, rose a bit, to 7,396,870 shares from 7,186,560 on Tuesday.
The temperature in New York City rose to a near-record of 97 degrees yesterday, causing low water pressure in some sections, buckling pavements, and overheating automobiles.
Interest rates on new bond issues continued to decline yesterday, and investors became more hesitant in buying the securities.
Mayor Lindsay said again last night that he would not accept a place on any Presidential ticket this year.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 16 -- From all parts of the United States they come -- guitarists, drummers, singers, bassists and comedians -- and they hope to entertain soldiers and earn money at the same time.
OAKLAND, Calif., July 16 (UPI) -- The defense ran into heavy going today in its attempts to delay the murder trial of Huey P. Newton, founder of the Black Panther party.
NIAMEY, Niger, July 16 -- Leaders of six African nations, meeting here to discuss Nigeria's civil war, invited the leader of secessionist Biafra today to attend the talks or send an envoy.
BATON ROUGE, July 16 (UPI) -- A state investigation of an alleged link between the Governor's office and underworld figures has turned up no wrongdoing, officials said today.

A PLAYER defending a game contract who holds five cards in a side suit is normally happy to discard one card, especially if he knows that neither opponent has more than four cards in it. But such a discard proved a fatal error in the diagramed deal, played Sunday in the final of the Knockout Team Championship in the Brooklyn tournament.

ATHENS, July 16 -- Archbishop Iakovos, primate of the Greek Orthodox Church in North and South America, sharply criticized Greece today for what he described as treating Greek-born Americans as aliens.
PITTSBURGH, July 16 -- In a contest that could be compared to two drowning men reaching for the same straw, the Pittsburgh Pirates won out tonight and scored a 3-2 victory over the New York Mets.

Heartland was the strongest favorite on the card at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing against eight rivals in the feature contest for fillies and mares, she came through with a 1 1/2-length score over Sarita for a win price of $3.20 for $2.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Members of Congress have won the right to be issued free, black "diplomatic" passports when traveling overseas on official business, the State Department disclosed today.

The ghetto has not always been appreciated as an economic institution. For masses of American immigrants, such ghettos as New York's lower East Side meant incredible crowding and exploitation. For the lost or bewildered, the ghetto became the first and last stopping place on a foreign shore, the ultimate backwater.
As bankers increasingly think, act and advertise like retailers, they become more aware of that common marketplace problem -- penetrating consumer consciousness.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., July 16 -- Two local policemen and a contractor were arrested today on charges connected with the illegal sale of the revolver used in the fatal shooting of two persons three weeks ago in New York City's Central Park.

Warwick Legler., which has not had a senior vice president since last December, has just appointed four. They are Sampson P. Bowers, James Ellers, John H. Lambert and Sol Katz, all former vice presidents.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 16 -- Terrorist attacks on civilians have dropped sharply in South Vietnam in the last week as part of a general reduction in enemy military activity.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Deluged by mail, besieged by friends and strangers, the House opened an intense three-way struggle today over gun controls.

NIAMEY, Niger, July 17 -- Nigeria's head of state apparently persuaded six other African leaders today that they should amend a resolution proposing the establishment of an internationally policed demilitarized zone inside Nigeria through which emergency relief could be delivered to secessionist Biagra.

UPPSALA, July 17 -- Twenty-five American Negro delegates to the Fourth Assembly of the World Council of Churches launched a drive for increased black representation on the council's powerful Central Committee today.
The move by banks to list their shares on the New York Stock Exchange showed signs of turning into a rush yesterday.
DANANG, South Vietnam, July 17 -- Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford flew to the northern provinces today and predicted widespread enemy attacks throughout the country in the next few months.

To the Editor: "Time is running out" -- on the young victims of the Nigeria-Biafra hostilities say your editorials and your correspondents. For many thousands, time has already run out. For several millions more, time will run out as inescapably as night follows day. Unless we continue to act, and act on a massive scale.

THE expatriates of the nineteen-twenties are alive and well and Paris-bound, I'm happy to say, in "Being Geniuses Together." How long will the golden legend last? Apparently, forever. Or, at any rate, until it's displaced by a new literary force that can show even greater style and pungency. Which doesn't, at the moment, seem awfully imminent.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Governor Rockefeller walked through a Negro business district on Chicago's South Side today on a political promenade that recalled those of Senator Robert F. Kennedy. Hundreds of Negro adults and children clustered around the perspiring Governor to promise him their support.

Jules David Prown, a 38-year-old art historian, has been appointed director of the projected Center for British Art at Yale University, it was announced yesterday by Kingman Brewster Jr., president of the university.
Mayor Lindsay and several hundred youngsters from Brooklyn slum areas visited a berthed Navy destroyer at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- President Johnson told Congress today that the passage of the $2.3-billion foreign aid authorization bill was "absolutely essential" to the national security and world peace.
Prices on the London stock market closed mixed in quiet trading yesterday.

JERUSALEM, July 17 -- A cluster of high-level American envoys, official and unofficial, have been in Jerusalem this week looking into the Israeli attitude toward negotiations with the Arab states and searching for a way to break the stalemate in the Middle East.

OPTIMISTIC bidders rely on the fact that the defensive play against them is not always immaculate. An example is the diagramed deal, which helped the eventual winners to beat a strong team in an early round of the Brooklyn Knockout Team Championship last weekend.
RICHMOND, July 17 -- A three-judge Federal Court today rebuffed a challenge to the "winner take all" method of selecting Presidential electors.
CAIRO, July 17 -- Officials in Cairo said privately that the Iraqi coup was likely to impede efforts toward a settlement of Arab-Israeli impasse.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The National Association of Securities Dealers, whose members are among the main beneficiaries of the present "give-up" system of stock brokerage commissions, announced today that it would agree to the gradual abolition of give-ups.

Well-qualified Arab informants who have been traveling in the Middle East reported this week that two Israeli Mirage jets flew reconnaissance missions last month over the northeastern outskirts of Cairo, where President Gamal Abdel Nasser has his home.

SYRACUSE, July 17 -- James L. Buckley, Conservative party candidate for United States Senator, said today that his party's "demonstrated power to attract disenchanted Democrats" might give it a decisive role in the election of the next President.

SARATOGA, N. Y., July 17 -- Plots rarely thicken in Balanchine's ballets, but his "Slaughter on 10th Avenue," boasting both a plot and subplot for a change, falls into the pea-soup category. Tonight Richard Rapp, stepping into Arthur Mitchell's part of the hoofer for the first time, gave a distinctive twist to his double role in the New York City Ballet's local premiere of the work at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center.
Traffic on Bruckner Boulevard has been jammed -- or moments away from a jam for 40 years or so, according to some residents of the Bronx.
PARIS, July 17 -- The French Communist party called today for a meeting of all European Communist parties within the next few days on the Soviet-Czechoslovak crisis.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) -- Jeff James, a rookie right-hander, hurled his first shutout and drove in a run with his first major league hit as Philadelphia crushed the Chicago Cubs, 8-0, in the second game of a double-header tonight.

The combination of two of the most renowned trumpeters in jazz, Dizzy Gillespie and Miles Davis, each with his own quintet, opened a two-week run at the Village Gate on Tuesday night -- a run that jazz followers anticipated might become a nightly battle for musical supremacy.

It's an androgynous world or will be soon, says Mrs. Bird, a woman who has managed to be a suburban wife, mother, commuter, writer and statistical spouter without suffering any noticeable loss of femininity. As evidence of the desegregation of the sexes, consider Twiggy, the contraceptive pill, college kids who cohabit without marrying, and the trends to more education and work outside the home for women.
A FORMER world champion, Mikhail Tal of the Soviet Union, suffered a bitter disappointment in the third game of his best-out-of-ten-games match with his compatriot Viktor Korchnoi.

To the Editor: I applaud the excellent letter published July 2 by Anton Refregier on the projected colossal Post Office Building for New York City -- unadorned. I wish to make further comment on the subject.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 17 -- The Billy Haughton Stable entry of Bye And Large and Nob Hill was installed today as the 7-5 favorite for the $33,106.66 Commodore Pace at Roosevelt Raceway Saturday. This six-horse race is the first major race for 3-year-old pacers at the major harness tracks in the metropolitan New York area.
Mayor Lindsay has been secretly meeting with some of Senator Robert F. Kennedy's closest aides as the Mayor prepares to speak out more vigorously and more often on the war in Vietnam.

The Long Island Expressway, famed as metropolitan New York's biggest parking lot, is being topped by the parking situation in the skies above it. The scope of the aerial traffic jam at New York's jetports literally reaches across the United States. "We have already experienced the phenomenon of having transcontinental flights delayed on the ground in Los Angeles," Federal Aviation Administrator William F. McKee said the other day, "because of congestion at JFK."

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 17 -- The Rhodesia Front party announced constitutional proposals today calling for the declaration of a republic with a Rhodesian chief of state. At present, Queen Elizabeth II is chief of state.
Major savings banks in New York State had a net gain of $9.6-million in deposits in the first half of July, the state Savings Banks Association said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Theodore C. Sorensen, the lawyer and speech writer who served two of the Kennedy brothers, said at a South Dakota political dinner last weekend that those who had supported Robert Kennedy should look for a new candidate and should not back either Eugene McCarthy or Vice President Humphrey.
The drab tenements sitting in clusters along Eighth Avenue were deserted. The steamy heat pouring through the old brick buildings had driven the residents into the streets.
The city withdrew yesterday its request that the Public Service Commission order a temporary reduction in Consolidated Edison's gas rates.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 17 -- About 50 demonstrators, most of them Palestinians, met Ambassador Ball with banners criticizing the Middle East policy of the United States when he arrived here tonight from Amman, Jordan.
Intense heat and high humidity embraced the metropolitan area again yesterday, wilting its inhabitants, taxing its utilities, buckling its roadways and snarling its traffic.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A Revolutionary Command Council headed by Maj. Gen. Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr, a former Premier and Defense Minister, has apparently assumed control of Iraq, according to reports reaching here.
MOSCOW, July 17 (Reuters) -- The journal of the Soviet writers' union rejected today a call by a conservative literary critic for new editions of a wide range of books and plays praising Stalin.
The Interpublic Group of Companies has merged two more of its ad agencies -- Pritchard, Wood, Inc., and McCann/ITSM -- into Pritchard Wood Associates.
The Bank of America, the nation's largest, announced yesterday the promotion of Alvin C. Rice and Lloyd J. Sugaski to the posts of senior vice presidents.
A Cuban exile leader said yesterday that anti-Castro Cubans were responsible for file recent wave of bombings of consulates and foreign travel offices in New York.
The heat's on in the city, and health officials gave the following recommendations yesterday on how to keep cool and conserve your health:

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., July 17 -- Chests heaving, the boys propped themselves along the sideboards after an energy-draining skating session. Boom Boom Geoffrion's head snapped up, and in a French-Canadian accent he shouted, "Hey, get off there! What you think this is?"
MARIN CITY, Calif., July 17 (UPI) -- Military police arrested today nine servicemen, absent without leave from duty, chained to clergymen at a Presbyterian church "liberation'' service.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Striking electrical workers rejected today a new wage proposal by the Illinois Bell Telephone Company for settling a dispute that threatens removal of the Democratic National Convention from Chicago, where it is scheduled to open Aug. 26.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 17 -- President Tito will go to Prague tomorrow with a delegation of leading Yugoslav politicians in answer to an urgent request from Alexander Dubcek, the Czechoslovak Communist leader, informed sources here said today.

MOUNT VERNON, July 17 -- The Westchester Bulls of the Atlantic Coast Football League completed two nights of a try-out camp tonight at which a total of 178 candidates participated at Memorial Stadium. Sixty of the players were asked to return for the opening of the regular Bull camp tomorrow night.

The State Insurance Department moved yesterday to take over the pension and welfare funds of the Mason Tenders District Council, covering 10 New York City locals of the racketeer-infiltrated International Laborers Union of North America.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17 -- Secretary General Thant has told the Economic and Social Council that current economic reforms in the Communist countries indicate far-reaching benefits both for the Communists and for developing countries.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Justice Abe Fortas acknowledged today that he telephoned a business leader last year to complain about the businessman's public criticism of President Johnson's Vietnam war budget.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 17 -- Seeking to counter charges that only Governor Rockefeller of New York could run well against Democrats in the industrial states, Richard M. Nixon said today that he would "campaign very heavily in the cities" if nominated and would "do much better there than I did in 1960."

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 17 -- On the eve of the 50th Professional Golfers' Association championship, the field of 168 indicated uncertainty today on how the hot weather and the texture of the rough and greens would affect play.

HOUSTON, July 17 (AP) -- -- Danny Coombs gained his first pitching victory of the season and contributed a two-run single as the Houston Astros beat the Atlanta Braves, 5-2, tonight. The Braves had won six games in a row.
TRAVEMUNDE, West Germany, July 17 (AP) -- The crew of a West German Navy reconaissance plane spotted the 73-foot ketch Stormvogel tonight. Radio contact had been lost with her last Friday.

About 350 public school teachers who walked off their jobs in the Ocean Hills-Brownsville school district in May in sympathy with 19 teachers and supervisors who had been transferred out of the district by the local governing board have been asked not to return, the board announced last night.
PARIS, July 17 -- North Vietnam gave to United States delegates here today the names of three captured American pilots who are to be released.

IN the 20 years that Mrs. Audrey Dallison has been showing dogs in England, she has owned more than 1,000. She has had as many as 100 dogs at a time. But now there are just 20 at her Gosmore Kennel in Codicote. "I want quality, not quantity," said Mrs. Dallison.
The Celanese Corporation reported yesterday a loss of $50.6-million for the second quarter, as a result of two extraordinary, nonrecurring charges in connection with foreign operations.

A sense of impending crisis prevailed in Eastern Europe as Soviet leaders summoned the Czechoslovak Communist party's Presidium to a meeting tomorrow to demand modification of Prague's program of democratic reform.
On-the-scene observations of air traffic handling by Federal Aviation Administration controllers have turned up no evidence of a slowdown attempt, an F.A.A. official said yesterday.
The Government is considering the prosecution of four top editors of Ramparts magazine for alleged violations of the Selective Service laws.
LONDON, July 17 -- The price of gold continued to fall in the London bullion market today, dropping to $37.75 an ounce, the lowest in three months.

Domesticated raga rock emerged when unadulterated Indian music was pungently slipped into the mainstream of American culture, and no one of any artistic pretensions is unaware of the great Indian instrumentalists of our day.
The National Maritime Union was notified yesterday that the Government would seek a court order forcing the reinstatement of two ousted seamen who had opposed the present union hierarchy.

PITTSBURGH, Thursday, July 18 -- Here it was, 20 minutes into Thursday morning, and a 37-year-old man batting in a major league game for the first time in three years held the balance of power in more than six hours of baseball effort.

With temperatures reaching 114 degrees in one sunny spot on the floor of Yankee Stadium and with bleacher fans mercifully permitted to enter the shaded grandstand, Camilo Pascual and Mel Stottlemyre earned their salaries yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Air Force defended today its reassignment of reservists called to active duty after the Pueblo crisis in January.
FIRST things first, and it was a tremendous, joyful and heartening performance of Bournonville's "La Sylphide" that Erik Bruhn and Carla Fracci gave at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.
A 45-year-old woman was shot fatally last night at 140th Street and Cypress Avenue, the Bronx, after what the police said was an argument over the opening of a fire hydrant by children.
Nine children and two adults died in a fire that swept through a two-story home in the St. Albans section of Queens early this morning. Fire officials said the blaze,...
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A poll in six major cities indicates that Governor Rockefeller of New York would run strongly among Negro voters.
Mayor Lindsay named Fioravante G. Perrotta, his executive assistant, as the city's new Finance Administrator yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today that the National Funeral Directors' Association had agreed that the price of a funeral may be advertised, just like any other commodity.

Columbia University announced yesterday that Dr. Carl F. Hovde had been appointed dean of Columbia College, the university's under-graduate school for men. The college was the focus of the crippling student protests that began April 23.
MILWAUKEE, July 17 -- The road-runners, those indefatigable artists who thrive on slow, clay courts, struck again today.

BERLIN, July 17--The East German Communists resumed their attacks today against alleged secret links between Bonn and Prague, charging West Germany with interference in the internal affairs of Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A bipartisan compact to guarantee the Presidency to the candidate who receives the most popular votes next November is being drafted for submission to the leaders and candidates of both parties.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- Weather maps, charts and photographs will be relayed by a United States satellite to four continents in an experiment scheduled to start in September.
MOSCOW, July 17 -- The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party met today in an urgent session to endorse decisions on Moscow's deteriorating relations with the Czechoslovak regime.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The United States is reported to have advised the Soviet Union through private diplomatic contacts that an armed interventon in Czechoslovakia would imperil President Johnson's painstaking efforts to improve American-Soviet relations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 -- In recent days, the North Vietnamese negotiators in Paris have argued that despite a curtailment of bombing, the United States has intensified its air raids against their country.

The heavy - handed efforts of Moscow to bring Prague's Communist liberals to heel cast a Stalinist shadow that extends far beyond the borders of Czechoslovakia and threatens the U.S.S.R's own wider interests as well as those of many other nations.
Automation in the market for over-the-counter securities is nearing reality.
AUSTIN, Tex., July 17 (UPI) -- President Johnson announced today his intention to nominate eight new Federal judges.
Despite their best efforts, airline and Federal Aviation Agency officials acknowledged yesterday, they have found no way to prevent hijackings in the air.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Democratic national chairman was asked today to deny convention seats to all delegates favoring Senator Eugene J. McCarthy unless they promised to support any Presidential candidate the party might nominate.
MANY people have an attic full of memories, but Abercrombie Fitch has a warehouse that transcends memory. It hasn't been cleared to the corners in 75 years.

BALTIMORE, July 17 -- Mike Maliszewski, in his first game as a professional, scored a goal with a little more than 10 minutes remaining to give the Baltimore Bays a 1-0 victory over the New York Generals at Memorial Stadium tonight before 4,450 fans.

To the Editor: The Times's July 9 news report on the Japanese elections would seem to quell fears of your July 2 editorial, "Anti-Americanism in Japan." The anti-American Socialist party has been defeated. Japan's prosperity, continued economic growth, and ties to the United States are apparently supported by a majority of the voters.
ALBANY, July 17 -- A 70 per cent increase in cases of suspected child abuse in 1967 was reported today by the State Department of Social Services.

While almost everybody is counting up delegates to the nominating conventions for President in August, almost nobody is keeping an eye on another convention -- the judicial convention scheduled for Sept. 8 that will determine the quality of justice in the courts of New York City and State for years to come.

A spokesman for the American Friends Service Committee in Philadelphia said yesterday that the three airmen would leave North Vietnam for Vientiane, Laos, tomorrow aboard the regular International Control Commission plane.

The Continental Can Company had slightly lower sales and earnings in the second quarter of this year, but first-half sales and profits were the highest in the company's history, Thomas C. Fogarty, chairman, reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Tom McCraw scored on a balk by Tom Phoebus in the fourth inning tonight and the Chicago White Sox gained a 1-0 victory that snapped the Baltimore Orioles' seven-game winning streak.
Although the 10 per cent income tax surcharge has enlarged the hole in every consumer's pocket, it has particularly affected the economic condition of the "credit drunk."
STOCKHOLM, July 7 (Reuters) -- Jouko Kuha of Finland broke the world 3,000-meter steeplechase record tonight in the Juliaden international track meet.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A Treasury spokesman said today he knew nothing about any agreement involving gold sales by South Africa. He was commenting on reports from London that an agreement had been reached.
Li'l Abner, Daisy Mae and several other Al Capp comic characters will soon become part of the burgeoning franchised fast-food roadside restaurant business.

The City Planning Commission approved yesterday a 5,000-foot-long, $62-million traffic interchange in the Bronx. The proposal was described as one of the largest single road-construction contracts ever planned by New York State.
A tentative contract agreement was reached early yesterday between the American Telephone Telegraph Company and the Communications Workers of America covering 24,000 long-distance workers.

As if he were a grasshopper in red trunks and red shoes, Ismael Laguna used perpetual motion and perpetual punches to score a unanimous 10-round decision over Victor Melendez, previously undefeated, in last night's feature bout at Madison Square Garden.

To the Editor: The great size of the Senate version of the Housing and Urban Development bill is best seen when we realize that it calls for a twelve-fold annual increase in Federal subsidized housing programs over the rate of recent years.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday the following changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
OAKLAND, Calif., July 17 (AP) -- Jim (Catfish) Hunter survived a shaky start and hurled a six-hitter as the Oakland Athletics defeated the American League leading Detroit Tigers, 3 2, tonight.

Leonard Bernstein will conduct all the concerts given by the New York Philharmonic in at tour of Europe and Israel, which the orchestra will make in a five-week period beginning Aug. 24 and ending Sept. 28.
A citizens committee filed suit in Federal Court yesterday to have the United States Senate seat of the late Robert F. Kennedy filled at the general election this fall.

The Federal Reserve, in a step that Wall Street found significant since it came one day after a meeting of its policymaking Open Market Committee, reduced the interest rate yesterday on credit it extends to Government bond dealers on repurchase agreements.

WARSAW, July 17 -- Diplomatic sources here say the current relaxation of tensions between Washington and Moscow may have persuaded the Soviet Union and some of its Eastern European allies that they can intervene militarily without fear of Western repercussions.

PRAGUE, July 17--Reliable Czechoslovak sources reported today that Leonid I. Brezhnev, General Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, demanded that Alexander Dubcek, First Secretary of the Czechoslovak party, agree to a meeting Friday between the entire ruling bodies of both parties.
LONDON, July 17 (AP) -- Twiggy, the fashion model, announced tonight that she plans to be married to her manager, Justin de Villeneuve.

Trans World Airlines reported yesterday a second-quarter net profit of $13,724,000, or $1.33 a share. This included earnings of its wholly owned subsidiary, the Hilton International Company. In the same period last year, on a pro forma basis to include Hilton, net was $13,876,000, or $1.36 a share.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Senate voted today to transfer the Head Start program to the states under supervision of the Office of Education of the Health, Education and Welfare Department.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Following are excerpts from an unofficial transcript, made for The New York Times, of testimony today before the Senate Judiciary Committee on the nomination of Abe Fortas to be Chief Justice of the United States:

The Gulf American Corporaion, a Florida land development company whose earnings have declined sharply in the wake of an investigation of its sales practices and financial affairs, announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to a merger with the GAC Corporation, a consumer finance company.

In a world reeling with violent revolution, there is one revolution that almost everyone favors -- the revolution in world agriculture that has begun to produce record crops in a growing number of desperately hungry lands.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 17 -- Nemiah Wilson, obtained last week in a trade with the Denver Broncos for an undisclosed draft choice, informed the New York Jets today during training at Hofstra that he planned to play out his option this season.

GAP, Pa., July 17 -- At home on Sands Street in Brooklyn, not far from the old Navy Yard, 10-year-old Gary Hendricks would be wakened, perspiring, by a backfiring truck on the hot street below his tenement window.

PARIS, July 17 -- Maurice Couve de Murville, addressing the National Assembly as Premier for the first time, pledged today to carry out basic domestic reforms in many fields before the end of the year.
A member of the City Planning Commission charged yesterday that the commission was rushing important questions through to decisions without adequate study and analysis.

Researchers at the Battelle Memorial Institute have surveyed school boards in Ohio and concluded that most do not know what kind of education the public wants or needs and that even if the boards did, they would not know whether they were providing it.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Yves-Louis Demeer received today the first Frances Lehman Loeb award from the American Field Service.

ALTHOUGH the United States Army has achieved a notable sophistication in weaponry, tactical mobility and the development of such sensitive detection devices as "people sniffers" that register friend or foe according to body odor, the Army kitchen remains remarkably oblivious of progress.
Three persons were killed at the Brooklyn end of the Manhattan Bridge yesterday when their car was ripped apart, flattened and set afire when it was struck by a truck that was running out of control.

Directors of Avnet, Inc., voted yesterday to split the common stock on a three-for-two basis, increased the cash dividend and elevated Morton D. Weiner to president and chief operating officer. He succeeds and reports to Lester F. Avnet, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

MOSCOW. July 17 (UPI) -- Production and profits in the Russian Federation, which includes three-fourths of the Soviet Union. have soared above expectation since a new system of capitalist-type, in centives were introduced, it was announced today.
The Boston Symphony Orchestra is certainly no stranger to New York, but since it is not in the habit of playing here in summer, its appearance at Philharmonic Hall last night was unusual.

MIAMI, July 17 -- A Cuban hijacker, waving a pistol and what turned out to be a fake hand grenade, commandeered a jetliner with 64 persons aboard over Texas today and forced it to fly to Havana after retaining command of the plane during a stop for fuel in New Orleans.

LANSDOWNE, Pa., July 17 -- Edward J. Sponga, the 50-year-old Jesuit who left his position last Friday as the head of his order's 800-member Maryland Province to get married, said today that his bonds with the Roman Catholic Church were "legally severed" because he married a divorced woman.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 17 -- Judy O'Connor of the Norwalk Yacht Club became the junior heroine of Larchmont Race Week today by adding a first place to the one she gained Monday in the young people's portion of the sailing extravaganza.

ROME, July 17 -- A frolicsome breeze that was no respecter of persons whisked the small white zucchetto, or skull cap, off the head of Pope Paul VI today as he left the Vatican in an open car to drive to Castel Gandolfo in the Alban Hills for his annual summer holiday.

The United Parcel Service, which had anticipated a resumption of service twice in the last week, remained shut down yesterday in New York, Westchester and Long Island. Most of its drivers refused to obey the orders of their union leaders to cross the picket lines of striking mechanics.
New York State was accused yesterday by City Controller Mario Procaccino of holding back about $1.2-million in state lottery money owed to the city.
The 26-story, 10-year-old office building at 680 Fifth Avenue, at the southwest corner of 54th Street, has been purchased by the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company.

WATERFORD, Conn., July 17 -- One of the frustrations of being a playwright is that a critic always has the last word. This tradition is being broken here as playwrights and critics mingle, clash and learn at the fourth Playwrights Conference of the Eugene O'Neill Foundation.

Hardly to the surprise of his trainer, Warren Croll, the Aisco Stable's Prevailing won the $27,800 Great American Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday, leading from the start of the 5 1/2-furlong sprint for 2-year-olds.

Frank Wille, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday that he had accepted a bid of $15.3-million for the Intra Bank Building at 680 Fifth Avenue, from the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, Newark, N. J.

MONTREAL, July 17 -- The Council of Postal Unions rejected today a two-stage, 50-cent-an-hour raise offered by the Federal Government, shattering hope of avoiding a nationwide postal strike scheduled for 5 A.M. tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The National Commission on Urban Problems released a study today that showed that, if present trends continued, "America by 1985 would be well on the road towards a society characterized by race stratification along racial and economic lines as well as geographic separation."

LONDON, July 17 -- The proposed merger of Barclays, Lloyds and Martins Banks into the fourth largest in the world, would produce only marginal benefits for the British public, the Monopolies Commission said today in explaining why it had rejected the proposal by a vote of 6 to 4.
LONDON, July 17 -- President Kenneth Kvanda of Zambia, who is here seeking ,antiaircraft missiles from Britain, said today that he was having difficulty getting them.

RICHMOND, July 17 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said today that "a popular protest" could be expected if his forces were denied sufficient representation on the Platform Committee to take disputed issues to the floor of the Democratic National Convention.

To the Editor: Albert L. Kraus in his July 10 news article "The Money Machine" criticizes the Joint Economic Committee for recommending that the Federal Reserve increase our money stock, conventionally defined, between 2 and 6 per cent per year.

The bill authorizing the United States contribution to the financial replenishment of the International Development Association -- the World Bank affiliate that makes loans on liberal terms to poor countries -- is encountering some formidable roadblocks in Congress. If they are not surmounted the cause of multilateral foreign aid will suffer a serious blow and so will the prestige of the United States.

THE first priest of Italian extraction named to head a Roman Catholic diocese in New York State is a soft-spoken career administrator who is given to gentle, self-deprecating humor. At a news conference yesterday, he patted his bald head and smilingly asked reporters to be sure to "describe my hair" in their articles.

LONDON, July 17 -- James Earl Ray's American lawyer charged today that Ray, accused of having assassinated the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was being treated unfairly by American officials and the press.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 -- Vietcong troops have been warned by their leaders not to expect the Paris talks to bring genuine peace, but rather to rely on a general uprising to defeat the United States a captured enemy document indicates.

The square-rigger Danmark, training ship of the Danish merchant marine, arrived in port yesterday. Docking at Pier 16 on the East River between Fulton and John Streets, she will be open to visitors Friday from 5:30 P.M. to 8:30 P.M. and on Saturday and Sunday from 1:30 to 4 and from 6:30 to 8:30.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Housing starts declined during June for the second successive month to their lowest level of the year, but the industry expects an improvement later this year.
Soybeans and grain futures prices opened on a weak note and then turned irregular, closing on that note at the end of the day.
BONN, July 17 (Reuters) -- Britain, West Germany, Italy and the Netherlands agreed today to develop an advanced combat aircraft to equip their air forces in the next decade.
Two Columbia University women students were sentenced to jail and fined yesterday for their part in the campus disorders last April.
A 6.000-item collection of rare Chinese books that was hurried out of China to Hong Kong in 1949 as the Commumists took over, has just been presented to Columbia University.

The Penn Central Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter from non-transportation activities showed an increase of more than 57 per cent over a year ago, while its earnings from railroad operations plummeted by more than 70 per cent.
Television has gone gypsy for its coverage of the 1968 national political conventions.

GILFORD, N. H., July 17 -- A toy Manchester terrier, Ch. Renreh Lorelei of Charmoron, owned by Marie Elizabeth O'Neill and her father, Charles A. T. O'Neill of Philadelphia, was named best of 741 dogs at the Lakes Region Kennel Club fixture at the Gunstock Recreation Area today.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., July 17 (AP) -- The trial of H. Rap Brown on charges growing out of last July's civil disturbances was ordered removed from Cambridge today to Maryland's Harford County Circuit Court.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -Fred B. Black, long-time lobbyist friend of former Senate Secretary Robert G. Baker, was acquitted today on Federal income tax evasion charges after a retrial.

The Federal Government "cannot go on much longer with its present organization" of overlapping and conflicting agencies on domestic problems, and so the President should appoint an "executive officer" to mobilize and coordinate talent and resources in various departments for the home front.
Msgr. Francis John Mugavero, executive director of Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn since 1961, was named Bishop of the diocese yesterday by Pope Paul VI.
NEWPORT, N. H., July 17 -- The sun rose red over the forest and by 6 o'clock it was already uncomfortably hot.

At just about the time the temperature hit 90 degrees yesterday, Bill Sirois hit the throttle in his No. 90 Stern-winder and pulled away from the rest of the fleet to win the Hennessy New York Grand Prix race around Long Island and set a world speed record for motor-boats.
LAHAINA, Maui, Hawaii, July 17 (AP) -- Porpoise III, skippered by Bill Killam, crossed the finish line first today in the Victoria-Maui international yacht race.

ROME, July 17 -- Mila Schoen, the Milanese who really is the shrinking violet of the Italian haute couture, goes on soaring each season. The winter collection she showed this week puts her in the stratosphere of Italian fashion, a rather lonely place to be right now. Some women, who happen to have fortunes and good taste, feel there is only Mila Schoen now that Balenciaga's couture house in Paris is closed.
LONDON, Friday, July 19 -James Earl Ray, the accused assassin of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was put aboard a plane early today and flown back to the United States.
A United States Supreme Court justice has stayed a lower Federal Court ruling that would have permitted the distribution of anonymous political campaign literature in New York.

National Educational Television will present on Monday a one hour documentary film and discussion dealing with the intrigue surrounding the death of Ernesto Che Guevara, the Cuban revolutionary, in Bolivia.
Signs of a subtle easing in Federal Reserve credit policy multiplied during the week ended Wednesday, banking figures published yesterday showed.

PARIS -- The biggest mystery of French politics today is whether Georges Pompidou will follow de Gaulle as President of the Fifth Republic or follow Michel Debre, his predecessor as Premier, down history's incline towards obscurity.

Recent oil and gas discoveries on the Arctic Slope of northern Alaska indicate the presence of "one of the largest petroleum accumulations known to the world today," a leading oil industry consulting firm has reported.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, in Congressional testimony released today, accused the Defense Department's civilian bureaucracy of creating foreign policy problems by financing and conducting behavioral and social-science research abroad.

GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 18 (UPI) -- Dennis Ralston, professional from Bakersfield, Calif., easily beat Jaime Pinto Bravo of Chile, 6-3, 6-3, today in the first round of the Swiss open championships.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 18 -- Henri Levesque, the man from Normandy whose Roquepine is the 7-5 favorite to win tomorrow night's $25,000 Gold Division of the Challenge Cup Trot at Roosevelt Raceway, is a superstitious Frenchman.

One of the city's biggest landlords, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, said yesterday that it would provide more opportunities for Negroes and Puerto Ricans to move into three of its major apartment developments.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Vice President Humphrey indicated strongly today that he wanted Senator Edward M. Kennedy to be his running mate if he won the Democratic Presidential nomination.
BERNARD GOVIN'S caterpillar seating units do not move. They undulate rhythmically from side to side, up and down. They may bring back the cocktail party as a sit-down affair.
OTTAWA, July 18 (AP) -Canadian postal workers struck today for higher wages, halting mail service all across the country. No further negotiations are scheduled until Sunday.
Frankie DePaula of Jersey City was mentioned yesterday as a main-event boxer in the future at Madison Square Garden.

SCARBOROUGH - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., July 18 -- Craig Harmon of Winged Foot shot a five-under-par 65 to win the medal by six strokes as the 49th annual Westchester County Golf Association's amateur championship began today.
Three banks yesterday named three officials.

A young sailor charged with public drunkenness and turning in a false alarm at 1:10 A.M. yesterday was responsible for bringing firemen to a blazing house in Queens where they helped rescue four persons. Eleven others died in the fire.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A leading student organizer for Senator Eugene J. McCarthy predicted today that if Hubert H. Humphrey and Richard M. Nixon were nominated for President, large numbers of activists and young liberals would "stay at home" during the campaign.

Six men linked to Herbert Itkin -- the key Government informant in the James Marcus kickback case -- were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in an alleged kickback conspiracy involving a teamster union pension fund.
HONOLULU, July 18 -- President Johnson said today that the American pledge to help South Vietnam resist aggression would stand firm "against any deception."

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 18 -- Chlorine gas escaping from a water purification apparatus at the new swimming pool of the Bonnie Briar Country Club here made 90 persons ill in the Westchester County town this afternoon.
Arthur T. Roth, for 20 years a controversial figure on the American banking scene, stepped down yesterday as head of the Franklin National Bank.

"Cutie" and "The Rabbi" were put on ice yesterday by Federal Judge Irving Ben Cooper. They got a year-and-a-day each in prison for trying to beat the Government by having others cash in winning twin-double tickets at harness-racing tracks.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that Soviet military pressure on Czechoslovakia was weakening the prospects raised by recent progress in nuclear disarmament negotiations for an improvement in Soviet-United States relations.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission in a unanimous action today announced a freeze on new applications for AM radio stations so that it can evaluate future policy in the AM-radio service area.

IT was a strange debut at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, where Lupe Serrano and Royes Fernandez danced the leading roles in the American Ballet Theater's full-length "Swan Lake" for the first time in New York.

LONDON, July 18 -- Serge Diaghilev, the great ballet impresario, besides having an eye for dancers and choreographers, could also pick his painters and designers, and his choice of often young and unknown artists such as Bakst, Braque, Matisse and Picasso gave his ballets a dazzling appearance.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 18 -- For the first time, United States B-52 bombers dropped tons of bombs on surface-to-air missile sites in North Vietnam today.

BECAUSE commercial picture distribution is geared entirely to the release of feature-length films, anyone who makes short movies -- other than those that promote the virtues of Standard Oil or the social benefits of Listerine -- must be either subsidized by a government, committed to the are, or, simply, mad.
Adam Clayton Powell's parole from a 30-day jail sentence for criminal contempt of court was extended yesterday.
The Xerox Corporation developed record revenues and profits for the second quarter and first half of this year, the giant photo-copier machine manufacturer reported yesterday.

The National Institute off Mental Health announced grants totaling $12.6-million yesterday to finance the establishment of six local treatment centers for narcotics addicts, including one on New York's Lower East Side.
AKRON, Ohio, July 18 -- They called this "Rockefeller Thursday" in five of Ohio's most populous cities.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- J. Edgar Hoover said today that workshops dealing with "sabotage and explosives" for possible use against Selective Service facilities were conducted last month at the national convention of Students for a Democratic Society.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
An intensive review of transportation strategies covering marketing tactics and profits will be undertaken during October and November at the Transportation Center at Northwestern University.
NEWARK, July 18 (UPI) -- The Essex House Hotel in Newark, one of New Jersey's top hotels for decades, has closed because of bankruptcy, a deteriorating neighborhood and stiff competition.
Arthur J. Goldberg called on Congress yesterday to pass a gun-control law that would include Federal licensing and registration as well as a ban on mail-order sales.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., July 18 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood, eight times champion, was knocked out of the 15th annual Garden State Women's Golf Association match-play championship today at the Baltusrol Golf Club.
BRUSSELS, July 18 -- The Belgian Parliament voted legislation today to enable the Government to stop all further arms deliveries to Nigeria, including those under current licenses.
Winthrop J. Allegaert has joined Hayden, Stone, Inc. as vice president, secretary and general counsel, and will head a newly created legal division, the firm announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -Senator Jacob K. Javits said today that half the 15,750 Air Force reservists mobilized after the Pueblo crisis in January were being separated from their units and assigned as "filler personnel" throughout the Air Force.
WOODBURY, L.I., July 18 -- The Waldemar Medical Research Foundation will benefit from an Electronic Rock Bar-B-Q to be held on its grounds here on Aug. 4.
The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation reported yesterday a sales increase for the second quarter but a decline in net operating earnings, compared with the corresponding period last year.

ATHENS, July 18 -- Greece's army-backed Government announced today that it had abolished 6 out of 10 special military tribunals set up after the coup of April 21, 1967, to punish activities against the regime.
Prices eased in active trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Volume rose to 8,616,753 shares from 7,396,870 in Tuesday's trading.

On a humid night on which the ballplayers were slightly less comfortable than the fans, the Yankees, with some key hits and managerial brainpower, scored a 4-1 victory over the Washington Senators last night.

PITTSBURGH, July 18 -- Tom Seaver, the best thing that ever happened to the New York Mets and their myriad of spiritual relations, pitched a six-hit shutout tonight and defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-0.
TARRYTOWN, N. Y., July 18 -- After 18 months of study, the Hudson River Valley Commission today unanimously approved the state's projected Hudson River Expressway.

Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, announced a to national program yesterday of increase Negro financing of housing and business mortgage loans in urban areas.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Senator Strom Thurmond pressed questions upon Justice Abe Fortas for more than two hours today, forcing the jurist to decline repeatedly to answer on the ground that current Supreme Court issues were involved.
A FORMIDABLE field of experts, including seven who have taken part in world championship competition, assembled last week at the Middle Bay Country Club, Oceanside, L.I., for an annual Pro-Am event.

A four-month investifation by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz into the expenses and profits of the Salute to the U.S.O. benefit show at the new Madison Square Garden on Feb. 11 has resulted in the United Service Organization's getting an additional $110,679 from the Garden's owners.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 13 -- With the junior phase of Larchmont Race Week having been concluded yesterday, Long Island Sound's senior sailors returned to action today. They were greeted by cooperative breezes for the first time since the competition's start last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- On Feb. 1, 1966, Dr. Robert Quarles Marston, a physician and dean of a medical school, took command of a new Federal enterprise that was distrusted and feared by many American doctors.

UPPSALA, Sweden, July 18 -- The Fourth Assembly of the World Council of Churches extended a virtual invitation to the Roman Catholic Church today to seek membership in the Protestant and Orthodox body.
HANOI, North Vietnam, July 18 (Agence France-Presse) -North Vietnam released three captured United States pilots in a ceremony here today.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 18 (AP) -- Gov. Ronald Reagan would retain his office by a two-to-one majority vote if he were forced to face a recall election, the California Poll reported today.
LONDON, July 18 (AP) -- A young American designer saved the miniskirt from extinction at today's revival of one of the world's oldest fashion houses, Worth.

AREA A -- After a slow two-week period, catches have picked up this week. In the Atlantic City area, bays and inlets have been yielding kingfish and large fluke (5 to 13 pounds) in good quantity. Offshore fishermen have been pulling in small blues, dolphin and -- beyond the 20-mile line -- larger blues in the 12-to-16-pound class.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Chet Huntley, the radio-TV commentator, says two broadcasts concerning Federal meat inspection he made this year had nothing to do with his interest in an Iowa cattle-feeding enterprise.

MOSCOW, July 18 -- The harsh attack on the Czechoslovak reform leadership by the Soviet Union and four Communist allies who met in Warsaw was, in effect, an ultimatum to Prague to restrain its democratization program.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 18 -- Two long-time golfing rivals will meet tomorrow in the 36-hole final of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship tournament at the Country Club of New Canaan.

The rich loam that nourished ballet's development was European court dancing, an almost forgotten genre now totally shadowed by its buoyant offspring. The form was partially restored from its undeserved obscurity last evening at the Lincoln Center Library Auditorium by Wendy Hilton and Rosalyn Tureck in a program of scrupulously reconstructed 18th-century court dances.

City officials and community leaders met yesterday in the South Bronx to try to find ways to ease growing tensions between black and Puerto Rican residents following four deaths in two shooting accidents in less than a week.
JERSEY CITY, July 18 -- Final plans for the construction of a $45-million transportation center in the heart of Jersey City were made public here today by the Port of New York Authority.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The next director of the National Institutes of Health listed today knowledge above both money and manpower as the crucial element in future improvements in American health.
STANTON, Del., July 18 (AP) -- An 18-year-old apprentice jockey from Washington, George Cusimano, rode six winners, five in a row, at Delaware Park today.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 18 -- Marty Fleckman, who twice led in the 1967 United States Open as an amateur, led the Professional Golfers' Association championship today as a rookie.
A line of thunderstorms is expected to cross New York City tonight, bringing a break in the sweltering heat that has afflicted the city, the Weather Bureau said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- United States officials expressed deep concern today over the tension between Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union.

Following are the text of the letter sent to Prague by the Bulgarian, East German Hungarian, Polish and Soviet Communist parties, in a translation provided by the Soviet press agency Tass, and the Czechoslovak reply as transmitted by Reuters from Prague:
Plans for another major apartment development in the Lincoln Center area were announced yesterday. Plans for two others were recently made known by their sponsors.
The stock market weakened yesterday after its Wednesday hiatus and, despite a few partial recoveries, finished at the low point of the day.

PARIS, July 18 -- In what some Western diplomats regarded as a potentially important move, the North Vietnamese delegation to the Paris talks circulated a document today that rephrased one of Hanoi's long-standing demands.

Two Columbia University women students sentenced to 15 days in jail Wednesday for their part in disorders on the campus last April were released in $1 bail each yesterday on an appeal that charged the penalties were excessive.
TOKYO, July 18 (AP) -- Sea Land Service, an American company, will start a trans-Pacific containerized cargo service in November, the Trans-Pacific Freight Conference of Japan said today.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday a Federal grant of $814,000 for air-pollution control, which he hailed as moving New York "one step nearer its goal of clean by 1972."

More than 50 guest columnists have agreed to make regular or occasional appearances on "60 Minutes," the Columbia Broadcasting System's biweekly news magazine series that will have its premiere on Tuesday, Sept. 24, at 10 P.M.

The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, the industry leader, achieved record sales and earnings in the three and six months ended June 30, according to the report issued yesterday by A. H. Galloway, president and chief executive officer.
The cast in Janet Soares's new piece for the downtown Dance Theater Workshop trampled quite a lot of The New York Times underfoot Wednesday evening -- the want ads to be precise.
The Fluor Corporation, an engineering and construction company, reached a preliminary agreement yesterday to acquire the Pike Corporation of America, for stock valued at more than $125-million.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday a broadly expanded disclosure policy that would require listed companies to include information about major developments under negotiation or in the planning stages.

"The market feels like a million bucks," a corporate bond trader said exultantly yesterday afternoon, in a remark that captured the spirit of the credit markets all week.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The nation's economy soared strongly upward in the second quarter, but signs of an impending cooling off were already apparent, the Commerce Department reported today.

LOS ANGELES, July 18 -- The attorney for Senator Robert F. Kennedy's alleged assassin, Sirhan B. Sirhan, said today that he would seek another delay of Sirhan's arraignment when the defendant appears in Superior Court tomorrow.
A three-way acquisition apparently was nearing completion yesterday with the Federal Trade Commission playing two roles.

CAIRO, July 18 -- The North Vietnamese Ambassador to the United Arab Republic said tonight that his country would be "very thankful" to receive applications from dissident Americans who want to fight as volunteers on the Communist side in Vietnam.
The short interest position of stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange declined in the month ended last Monday to 20,397,154 shares from 22,215,479 shares on June 14.

Three top executives of the State Public Service Commission attacked Mayor Lindsay's criticism of the P.S.C. yesterday. They said the Mayor was "misinformed" about its rate-making for Consolidated Edison's gas service.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 -- This city's American Conservatory Theater "'will cease to exist here or anywhere else" unless $104,000 in pledged but unpaid contributions to the repertory company is collected before July 31.
The $16.9-miliion BrookLyn Heights Towers was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission at a special meeting at its headquarters, 2 Lafayette Street.
The first American discovery of a pulsar, one of the perplexing celestial sources of rhythmic radio pulses, has been made by two Harvard astronomers.
CHICAGO, July 18 (UPI) -- The Democratic National Chairman, John M. Bailey, said today he was "still holding out hope" that the party's convention would be held in Chicago.

The swift political events in Czechoslovakia over the last few months -- and the crisis mood in Eastern Europe now -- recall the turbulent period in the Communist bloc in 1956 that resulted in the Hungarian rebellion and the powerful Soviet military intervention that crushed it after 13 days.

Grandmaster Larry Evans of New York moved into a first-place tie in the United States Chess Championship Wednesday night at the Empire Hotel here by defeating the Rev. William Lombardy in the third round.

BONN, July 18 -- Willy Brandt, West Germany's Foreign Minister, sharply attacked the East German Government today for its role in the current political and psychological assault on Czechoslovakia by the Soviet Union and its allies.
