The General Electric Company will lose some of its position in the jet aircraft engine market, probably to the Pratt Whitney Aircraft division of the United Aircraft Corporation, a study issued over the weekend predicts. Pratt Whitney is already the leader in the field and G.E. is No. 2.

The first United States office of Aeroflot Soviet Airlines will be established in the two-story building at 45 East 49th Street, between Madison and Park Avenues. Aeroflot recently started the first regularly scheduled flights of a Soviet airline between Moscow and New York.
CLEVELAND, July- 21 -- Research and technology are bringing about a revolution in the treatment of the nation's sewage.

The American Electric Power Company reported yesterday new highs in earnings for the first half and 12 months ended June 30. The report placed first-half earnings at $50,858,000, 7.7 per cent above the $47,239,000 reported in the 1967 period.
PANORA, Iowa, July 18 -- A good July growth of corn and soybeans presses hard and green against Panora's lightly guarded flanks.
There is a good deal of talk these days about the interchange going on between popular and serious music, but the merger is taking place nowhere more plainly than at the Electric Circus.

A Japanese child psychiatrist, noting the extreme rarity of reading disability among Japanese children, has suggested that the disability may be the result of the language used rather than of a neurological disorder.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Johnson sent his South Vietnamese "counterpart," Nguyen Van Thieu, back to Saigon from Honolulu with a bagfull of political gains. But all the President brought home to Vice President Humphrey was more trouble.
MOSCOW, July 22 -- A tightening of ideological controls over Moscow's theaters has been ordered after a controversial season.
A white man and a Negro scuffled yesterday on the corner of the Avenue of Americas and 50th Street. The white man pulled a gun. A shot was fired.

While Red Sox backers from New England were beside themselves in the unfriendly surroundings of the Stadium (they turn out when the Bostonians are winning), Jim Lonborg recaptured the style that pitched the Red Sox to the pennant last year as he hurled six masterful innings and gained his first victory of the season.

A suspended policeman who was once under indictment for conspiring with members of the Mafia to murder informants has been offered immunity from prosecution if he will answer grand jury questions about the slaying of Alfred (Freddie the Kid) Sanantonio five years ago.

SCHROON LAKE, N.Y., July 22 -- The place of Schroon Lake in American history is secure. Here it was that Marjorie Morningstar, in Herman Wouk's novel about coming of age in the Adirondacks, swam across the moonlit waters to an adult summer resort and met the dashing Noel Airman (you may remember them as Natalie Wood and Gene Kelly in the 1957 movie, shot at Schroon Lake).

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 22 -- From the stereo speaker in the locker-room ceiling, a voice was singing, "Put on a Happy Face," but the New York Jets didn't have to be told that as they strolled out for afternoon practice today at Hofstra University.
PARIS, July 22 -- For the French Communists, who are still reeling from the shock of their election defeat, the crisis between Prague and Moscow came at a critical moment.

Broadway ticket prices will reach a new peak for a number of incoming shows during the 1968-69 season. More musicals than plays will be affected. The highest prices will be charged by two musicals, "Zorba," due the week of Nov. 17 at the Imperial Theater, and "Promises, Promises," arriving later that month at the Shubert Theater.
Prices dropped sharply on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in a relatively slow day's trading.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 22 -- The death last week of a 21-year-old South African police constable, Danie du Toit, in a clash with terrorists in Rhodesia has produced a sense of shock here.

A $2-million office building with 85,000 square feet of floor space is under construction on Central Park Avenue in Scarsdale. The four-story structure, to be called Executive Plaza, will rise on a four-acre tract.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 22 (UPI) -- The first boats crossed the finish line in the 333-mile Chicago-to-Mackinac Island race today after a series of squalls damaged at least seven boats and forced others to drop out last night.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -The head of one of the nation's major mutual fund complexes testified today that the shareholders of one of his funds, in effect, pay part of the cost of selling another of his funds -- and that he makes twice as much money from every share of the second fund that he sells.
MOST players know in theory that it is unwise to double a game contract that the opponents apparently think they will make, but in practice they still seem to do it with disastrous results.

The July 5 editorial on formation of the Airport Security Council at Kennedy International Airport to coordinate anticrime agencies pessimistically observes, "[T]here are reasons to doubt it will be successful."
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- The Republican Platform Committee today began work on the defense plank to be submitted to the national convention in Miami Beach next month.

The Weyerhaeuser Company had a 77 per cent increase in second-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 18 per cent, while half-year profits rose 55 per cent on a sales gain of 14 per cent, the international forestproducts company reported yesterday in Tacoma, Wash.

Earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), the world's largest petroleum producer, rose 15.7 per cent in the quarter ended June 30, and 14.2 per cent in the first six months of this year, the company reported yesterday.

TUMBA, Sweden -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin was due any minute at the shiny industrial plant in a rural suburb of Stockholm. While newsmen waited, they were offered crackers and pineapple juice, fortified with fish meal. For grosser appetites, beer and cheese were offered.
LONDON, July 22 -- British officials disclosed a new plan today to overcome political obstacles and get emergency relief to Biafra.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -Senator William Proxmire announced today that the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, which he heads, will hold hearings on the new Federal Reserve proposal for sweeping reforms in its discount mechanism.
TRAVEMUNDE, Germany, July 22 (AP) -- The 73-foot ketch, Stormvogel, maintained a slight lead today about 550 nautical miles from the finish of the Bermuda-Travemunde trans-Atlantic yacht race.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 22 -- The 23-year-old daughter of a retired Michigan executive was killed here Sunday night in what the state police described as a shooting accident.

ST. PAUL DE VENCE, France, July 22 -- Joan Miro came to Alexander Calder's birthday party yesterday and tonight Mr. Calder had a chance to return the compliment. The Philadelphia - born sculptor, turned 70 today and Mr. Miro had already rounded 75 when they met at St. Paul de Vence on the Cote d'Azur.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 22 (AP) -- A major upset in the women's singles was the highlight today in the opening of the 60th annual Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship at the Merion Cricket Club.

It is a discouraging indication of the "mad momentum" of the arms race that the Senate on June 24 by a vote of 54 to 31 authorized the preparation of an appropriation bill that would start the actual deployment of the "Sentinel" antiballistic missile system.
ATLANTA, July 22 -- Don Cardwell, showing how a manager could trust a man over 30 years old, pitched a five-hitter for the New York Mets tonight and defeated the Atlanta Braves, 5-2.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- A Federal district judge rejected as inadequate today an integration plan submitted by South Holland School District 151, south of Chicago.

MOSCOW, July 22 -- The Soviet Union disclosed tonight that it had compromised on the terms of a meeting with the Czechoslovak Communist leadership, agreeing that the Soviet party's entire Politburo would go to Czechoslovakia.
" I'm frustrated," Mrs. Lee Oliver said yesterday.

It was opening night for The Traveling Puerto Rican Theater. Parks Commissioner August Heckscher came in a gray suit and a green bow tie. The rest of the audience arrived in shirtsleeves, sneakers, slacks and baby carriages.

ALEXANDRIA, United Arab Republic, July 21 -- As the 2,000-year-old temple of Dendur was loaded aboard a freighter bound for Manhattan today, this ancient seaport rang with Arab longshoremen's shouts of "Iwaa!" -- "Look out!"
Like many Spanish youngsters, Miguel Sandoval, a bank director's son, hoped to make good in life. That is, he wanted to become a bullfighter.

BONN, July 22 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger asked his Defense Minister, Gerhard Schroder, today "to examine the possibility" of changing the time or place of a major military maneuver scheduled to begin near the Czechoslovak border Sept. 15.
An impasse within the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee has prevented the passage of two bills affecting the operations of inland waterway companies.

Soviet acquiescence in the Czechoslovak demand that if any meeting between leaders of the two countries is to take place, it must be on Czechoslovak soil, offers a ray of hope that the Kremlin will not overreach itself in its dangerous test of will with the Prague regime.
The leisurely demeanor of Abercrombie Fitch, the mecca of affluent sportsmen, crumbled yesterday before a rushing, grabbing, sun-tanned throng that just couldn't resist an exotic bargain.

PRAGUE, July 22 -- The Soviet Union has revived its demand that Czechoslovakia consent to the stationing of Warsaw Pact troops along her frontier with West Germany, according to informed Czechoslovak sources.

SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., July 22 -- A 46-year-old man smashed the plate glass window of a sporting goods store on the main shopping street here tonight, grabbed a revolver and shells and then came out and opened fire on passersby.

The Koppers Company of Pittsburgh makes things to make buildings. Things like pavement sealers, laminated arches and beams, pressure-creosoted pilings and even rot, decay, termite-proof wood. Not exactly the stuff that whiz-bang, yak-filled advertising is made of.

Referring to the [Robert G.] McCloskey-[Nelson W.] Polsby letters [June 20 and July 2] on the Vice President's role, I agree with Professor McCloskey that Vice Presidents have often differed from Presidential policies, including our most recent Vice Presidents.
COLD soups, salads and fruit may be the backbone of warm-weather meal planning, but a hot bread adds interesting contrast.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Justice Department has been called before the Senate Judiciary Committee to answer charges that it is "propagandizing" the Senate in behalf of Abe Fortas.

The securities industry, confronted with a volume of trading and paperwork that has remained high, even during the current downward course of stock prices, acted yesterday to continue its once-a-week shutdowns into next month.
HENRY VIII. By J. J. Scarisbrick. 560 pages. California. $10.95.
The last few weeks' television series on the Negro and his problems might well be termed the Era of Splendid Masochism as far as whites are concerned.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 22 (UPI) -- Fort Marcy survived a claim of foul today and gained a nose victory in the 27th running of the $118,500 Sunset Handicap, the closing-day feature of the Hollywood Park meeting.

Vice President Humphrey sharply criticized Senator Eugene J. McCarthy yesterday, contending he did not discuss "crucial issues" on the home front and limited himself to "complaint" about Vietnam rather than developing a peace plan.
BUCHAREST, July 22 -- Observers here see two reasons for Moscow's insistence on having negotiations with Prague take the form of a meeting of the entire party leaderships.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 22 -- All 1,600 members of the Suffolk County Police Department are being equipped with Chemical Mace, the controversial spray that has been publicized as a weapon against street rioting.
NEW DELHI, July 22 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi told Parliament today that Soviet arms aid to Pakistan would heighten tensions on the subcontinent and add to India's defense burden.

SAN JUAN, P. R., July 22 -Gov. Roberto Sanchez Vilella, rejected yesterday by his party for a second term, began consultations today that many observers here expected would lead to an independent candidacy.
CIESZYN, Poland, July 22 -- Some of the Soviet troops that have been withdrawn from Czechoslovakia are stationed in woods less than three miles north of this Polish city on the Czechoslovak border.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 22 -- Rhodesian Air Force jets have gone into action against black terrorist infiltrators near the Zambezi River, which forms part of Rhodesia's border with black-ruled Zambia to the north.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -The final version of the housing bill, which is expected to be sent soon to President Johnson for his signature, contains major new lending and investment powers for savings and loan associations.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -The Treasury bill rate fell sharply at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed today.
Prices of precious metals on commodity markets fell here yesterday in sympathy with the decline in the price of gold on the world market.

The head of the Uniformed Firemen's Association charged yesterday that it was not a lack of policemen that was responsible for the growing number of attacks on firemen fighting fires but the fact that the policemen were being "held back" from making arrests.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 22 -- The new Iraqi Foreign Minister warned foreign newsmen today not to take "revolutionary" rhetoric too seriously and pledged that Iraq would honor all her foreign agreements. Meanwhile, the new President, Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr, told Iraqi soldiers with rhetorical vigor that "bribery and corruption" had been rampant in the regime that was ousted last Wednesday in a military coup.
The stock market took its second worst beating this year as the list fell sharply yesterday with declines outnumbering advances by a five to one ratio.
AUSTIN, Tex., July 22 (AP) -- President Johnson put in a full work day at the LBJ Ranch today.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Vice President Humphrey's campaign headquarters admitted today that one of its prize catches had gotten away.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The United States formally protested to the Soviet Union today against continuing Soviet allegations of American complicity in Czechoslovakia's defiance of Moscow.

ATHENS, July 22 -- A Greek Orthodox theologian and philosopher predicted today that Orthodox churches would soon be confronted with the same pressures to adapt traditional doctrines to modern thought that had already produced radical changes in Protestant and Roman Catholic churches.

The New York Yankees played a winning engagement yesterday without lifting a bat or throwing a ball. They came to Harlem to greet several hundred enthusiastic youngsters participating in a block party on 127th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

United Air Lines, the nation's biggest, said yesterday that air traffic delays might force it to cancel a number of flights this month because many of its pilots were running out of prescribed flying time.

PARIS, July 22 -- Can a haute couturier concentrate on seams and silks, on jewels and furs, once he has seen the Sorbonne seized and Paris paving stones being thrown like Ping-Pong balls? That's the question looming larger than life on the first day here of the new winter collections.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley predicted tonight that the deadlock would be broken tomorrow in a 76-day strike that has threatened to force a change in the site of the Democratic National Convention.

ROSELLE, N. J., July 22 -- The manager of a branch office of the First National Bank of Roselle was shot and killed today when he tried to wrest a pistol from the hand of a bandit dressed in women's clothes.
BERKELEY, Calif., July 22 -Dr. Agnes Fay Morgan, a pioneer in developing the science of nutrition, died here Saturday at the age of 84. She suffered a heart attack early this month.
Barrages of bottles, cans and garbage spattered Avenue in the East Village last night and early this morning in a tense confrontation between policemen and residents.
A contract dispute between the Hellenic Lines and its office workers yesterday halted operations of two of the company's freighters at 57th Street on the Brooklyn waterfront.

Students, faculty and administration members will work together on newly formed committees at Barnard College to make policy decisions in the areas of student housing, curriculum and other student affairs.

A series of moves to speed the conversion of Jamaica, Queens, into a model "multi-purpose urban center" became known yesterday with appointment of a former Regional Plan Association president to press the coordination of public and private programs.

PARIS, July 22 -- North Vietnamese negotiators charged today that the Honolulu meeting between President Johnson and President Thieu of South Vietnam showed that the United States intended to intensify the war in Vietnam.

The Defense Department said yesterday that the Army was the sole United States manufacturer of the explosive that, according to the police here, was placed in front of the French tourist office in Rockefeller Center and the Mexican Consulate in Newark.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 23 -- Two Vietcong battalions were reported surrounded by South Vietnamese troops in the coastal province of Binhthuan late yesterday. The fighting was described by South Vietnamese sources as developing into a major engagement.
Richard M. Nixon was reported yesterday in the Louis Harris poll to be running behind his two potential Democratic rivals. Vice President Humphrey and Senator Eugene J. McCarthy.

LAST year, Russ Rogers of Newark was ranked fourth among the world's 400-meter hurdlers, but his campaign to make the United States Olympic team is putting him face to face with four months of financial crisis. Though Nick Lee never tried the 400-meter hurdles until last month, he is already one of the world's fastest, but he, too, has money problems ahead.
Two dozen friends and advisers to the Kennedys gathered yesterday at Hyannis Port, Mass., with Senator Edward M. Kennedy for a five-and-onehalf-hour discussion.
LONDON, July 22 -- The Government was urged today to direct the great private boarding schools of England to give half their places to students sent there by the state at public expense.

A second aide of City Council President Frank D. O'Connor filed a claim yesterday for damage done to her automobile by some of the 1,500 young men and women who demonstrated outside of City Hall on July 10.
Prices on the London stock market closed mixed yesterday. Some leading industrial issues eased.

THE good old summertime is undergoing an agonizing reappraisal. From the ghetto to the middle-class suburb, parents and children have come to regard the two-month to three-month vacation from school as a vacuum rather than a carefree interlude.

All the major New York banks -- with the exception of the Bankers Trust Company -- have put through general salary increases for clerical employes recently to help offset increases in the cost of living and to remain competitive in a generally rising salary market.

CINCINNATI, July 22 -- The nation's governors adopted unanimously today a resolution praising President Johnson for "his long and devoted public service," a move designed to lure him into a personal appearance here tomorrow night.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., July 22 -- Goose Goslin broke down and wept, Joe Medwick said, "It was a long time coming" and the widow of Kiki Cuyler introduced her grandchildren. And that was how three new members entered the Baseball Hall of Fame today.

As bond prices continued to muscle their way upward yesterday, $1.33-billion of Federal Government securities were tentatively priced to yield 1/4percentage point less than a similar financing four months ago, and investors clamored to buy them.
A Molotov cocktail was thrown at the feet of two policemen in Coney Island last night. It shattered and scattered flames over the sidewalk at 28th Street and Mermaid Avenue, but no one was injured.

WEATHERSFIELD, Vt., July 22 -- Near the spot where a ferry once landed passengers from the New Hampshire side of the Connecticut River, a man, his wife and his children were faintly visible in the gathering mist and darkness.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 22 -- Effective shortly before midnight tomorrow, an armistice will exist between harness racing fans who frequent Roosevelt Raceway and the mutuel machines they have been battling there since the start of the second home stand on the night of May 24.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today that drug abuse control was impossible without scientific research and public education as well as law enforcement.
THE wife of Josef Smrkovsky tells the story that when she was about to marry him, he warned her that life would not be free of trouble. "And," she adds, "it certainly hasn't been."
DETROIT, July 22 -- One year ago this city, reputed to be the nation's most progressive in race relations, exploded in the nation's worst riot.

VIENNA, July 22 -- Austria, fearing the approach of a MoscowPrague showdown, is haunted by the memory of hundreds of thousands of refugees who poured into this country from Hungary in a similar crisis almost 12 years ago.

A young rock group, a relatively new reader of poetry, and a perennial favorite in folk song joined to give last night's concerts at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park. An audience of 2,500 attended the first of the twin programs.

IF smart money is what makes profits in the stock market, then it is appropriate that the chief product of a company whose shares appreciated nearly 3,500 per cent in four months should be called "SMART."
A seaplane carrying four businessmen commuters from Wall Street to their homes in the Westport, Conn., area flipped over on its back as it was about to take off in the East River yesterday afternoon.
The State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission has decided to contest the release of 600 addicts now under compulsory civil commitment for rehabilitation.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Justice Department used the new Federal open housing law for the first time today to charge three subdivisions in Baton Rouge, La., with discrimination against Negroes who wanted to buy homes.

Disregarding the united opposition of seventy-five regional and national conservation organizations, the Hudson River Valley Commission has approved construction of the proposed expressway along the east bank of the Hudson River between Tarrytown and Ossining. This is not the last word, however. That is the prerogative of the Federal authorities who still have a chance to take a more farsighted view.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee took a hand today in efforts to exempt the postal service from the Congressional mandate for personnel cutbacks.
The city's newly expanded Board of Education will hold its first informal meeting tomorrow.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 22 -- Governor Rockefeller left the 60th annual Governors Conference for a few hours today to fly to North Carolina for some hurried politicking.

In what he thought was a guest appearance on television for the purpose of publicizing Mayor Lindsay's Operation Sports Rescue program, Lew Alcindor became involved last Friday in a discussion of why he did not try out for the United States Olympic basketball team.

An executive of the Consolidated Edison Company acknowledged yesterday under cross-examination that it had failed to apply to the benefit of its gas customers, in the form of lower rates, a Federal income tax credit of $5.6-million it received in 1967.

MEMPHIS, July 22 -- James Earl Ray pleaded not guilty today to a charge that he murdered the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. last April 4. His trial was set to begin Nov. 12. The date was picked to avoid the upcoming elections.

ROME, July 22 -- A military investigating commission has cleared Gen. Giovanni de Lorenzo, former commander of the mobile police, of suspicion of having plotted a military coup in 1964. But it censured his heavy-handed, unauthorized security measures.
Six Mississippi organizations announced yesterday that they had formed the Loyal Democrats of Mississippi to challenge the credentials of the state's delegation to the Democratic National Convention.

Major Art contributed a major upset in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The outsider in the betting in the field of eight, and with a pickup jockey riding him, W. Arnold Hanger's color - bearer nevertheless came through with a decisive triumph, at $28 for $2.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 22 -- The 1968 version of the New York Giants' football team assembled 70 strong here today. Fifty had prior pro experience and 20 were rookies. This was seven fewer than expected because of three retirements, three Army obligations and one case of parenthood.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 22 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu returned today from the Honolulu conference with President Johnson and told his nation that the United States would strengthen the South Vietnamese Army, bar a coalition government and support the war even after the November elections in the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Interest rates on conventional home loans rose sharply during June, climbing to almost 7 per cent for the first time in history.
The Off Broadway theater is currently enjoying its best summer season ever, while Broadway, which reports a generally brisk trade, is feeling the effects of the annual July slump in theatergoing.
PRAGUE, July 23 -- Czechoslovakia waited today between the acts of the drama that pits her against her hostile allies.

Thomas P. F. Hoving, former City Parks Commissioner, testified yesterday that he was "amazed, annoyed and angered" when he first found out how little space the community was going to get in the gymnasium that Columbia University proposed to build in Morningside Park.
LONDON, July 23 (UPI) -- David Broome, on Mister Softee, won the Horse and Hound cup, first championship event of the Royal International horse show, which opened here today.
The Gulf Oil Company led a continuing parade of petroleum producers reporting earnings gains yesterday.

Laughter and song exploded from the young men gathered on a smooth lawn under old trees. They gibed at one another and submitted to satirical thrusts. They were reformed narcotics addicts on Hart Island fighting to rejoin society.

LONDON, July 23 -- Cecil Harmsworth King, deposed British press executive, asserted at a stockholders' meeting today that his recent dismissal as chairman of the International Publishing Corporation was "a conspiracy of a particularly squalid kind."

ATLANTA, July 23 -- This was a big night for the boys in Room 452, another tough one for Noc-a-Homa and a victorious one for Tom Seaver of the New York Mets, who defeated the Atlanta Braves, 2-1, with Cal Koonce's help for the last six outs.

Cragwood Stable's Pamir, who had the distinction of going postward the favorite five times in his previous six appearances, again was sent out as the choice -- a heavy one -- in yesterday's featured $12,000 Court Molloy at Aqueduct.
PEKING -- The question of who finally is to direct Chinese scientists and technologists engaged in basic research is apparently not yet settled.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 23 (AP) -- Top-seeded Bob Hewitt of South Africa, within a point of defeat in the Pennsylvania lawn-tennis championship, recovered today to defeat Tito Vasquez, a game little Argentine Davis Cup player.
The Dow Chemical Company and other producers of chemicals and related products reported yesterday better performances for the first quarter of the year despite the 10 per cent tax surcharge.

The Poor People's Campaign with its mud-beset Resurrection City did not win all its goals this year. It didn't expect to, and its goals weren't ones which could be won all at once in a single stroke. But the experience appears to have been valuable to the campaign's leadership.
Paul O'Dwyer charged yesterday that anti-Semitism was "lurking behind all the mumbo-jumbo" of the Senate committee hearings on the confirmation of Abe Fortas as Chief Justice of the United States.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday new highs in total operating revenues for the six and 12 months ended June 30. However, net income in both periods was reduced by $1,340,000, or approximately 4 cents a share, by the 10 per cent Federal surtax, which was retroactive to Jan. 1.
Pan American World Airways and Mohawk Airlines announced some minor changes in schedules yesterday as a consequence of the increasing congestion at airports.

Despite some complaints of lack of police protection for firemen at fires, Mayor Lindsay contended yesterday that the policemen and firemen had worked out a cooperative effort in all areas where there are tensions.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee approved today a House-passed bill to make the Maritime Administration an independent agency.

The Soviet Union is proving once more that it is terrified of freedom. It has been brutish with the Czechs. Having failed to persuade them that even a little liberty is a dangerous thing, it is trying to bully them into submission.

Yesterday was a dark one for the New York Jets. Donald C. Lillis, the club's president, died. Dennis Randall, who had just been promoted to regular right tackle on defense, walked out of the training camp at Hofstra University and the Army took Emerson Boozer, the star halfback.
CINCINNATI, July 23 -- The man causing the most political consternation at the National Governors Conference is an uninvited former member: George C. Wallace of Alabama.

BRUSSELS, July 23 -- The executive commission of the European Common Market decided today to allow France to impose quotas on imports from her partners in the community and to aid her own exporting industries.
The stock market suffered its fifth consecutive decline yesterday although a late recovery trimmed many earlier losses.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk is reported to be worried that Soviet portrayals of alleged "imperialist" underground activity in Czechoslovakia may be used as a pretext for military intervention.

The first comprehensive report on the positions of most of the 33 yachts that started the trans-Atlantic race from Bermuda to Travemunde, West Germany, on July 3, was received yesterday. It had Stormvogel just over 600 miles from her destination. The positions were taken at noon, Greenwich Mean Time, (8 A.M. Eastern Daylight Saving Time) on Monday.
Four disk jockeys for two Spanish-language radio stations were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on perjury charges growing out of a payola investigation.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- The United Automobile Workers and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced the formation today of an alliance to organize unorganized workers and pursue social and political action projects.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Gun control forces lost another fight today as the House refused to require state licensing of gun owners.
CINCINNATI, July 23 -- President Johnson struck out tonight at the "irreconcilability" of the Communist forces in Vietnam and at the American critics of his war policy.
DETROIT, July 23 -- New car sales in mid-July continued strong with automobile manufacturers reporting 241,991 retail deliveries, 3 per cent above the 234,076 a year ago.
The city's top rent official and leaders of the real estate industry disagreed sharply yesterday over the extent of rent rises in apartments not under rent control.
VIENNA, July 23 -- Austria's small but influential Communist party warned today against international speculation that the Soviet Union might intervene militarily in Czechoslovakia.
Vice President Humphrey declared last night that the quest for peace was the big job of the next President and, in developing the theme, aimed an obvious gibe at Senator Eugene J. McCarthy.

Grandmaster Robert Byrne of Indianapolis and Grandmaster Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., a six-time United States champion, tied for the lead in the United State chess championship af- after the sixth round Monday night at the Empire Hotel. Each has scored 4 1/2 points.
The Democratic State Committee's selection of 65 at-large delegates to the party's national convention was challenged yesterday in Federal Court in Manhattan.

TORONTO, July 23 -- In six days, Canada's nationwide strike of postal workers has caused widespread inconvenience and expense but no major disruption to work and play by 20 million Canadians and summer visitors.

Scholars who study communism and the Soviet Union have an "in" amusement these days, playing a record called "My Darling Party Line -- irreverent songs, ballads and airs." It presents ditties sung and chiefly written by Joe Glazer and Abe Brumberg, two employes of the United States Information Agency.

THE Nassau-Suffolk Knockout Team Championship ended recently in a victory for Jimmy Greenwood and Danny Lewis of New York, Ralph Pollenz of Freeport, L.I., and Emmet Pollenz of East Meadow, L. I. They headed a field of 22 teams in a double elimination event, which lasted through the 1967-68 season.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 -- The Vice Commander of the Seventh Air Force, Maj. Gen. Robert F. Worley, was killed today when his jet reconnaissance plane was shot down by enemy ground fire.

PARIS, July 23 -- One of the Palestinian hijackers who diverted the Israeli airliner to Algiers took over the controls of the four-engine jet and brought it down to a smooth landing, according to passengers who arrived here tonight.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 -- The South Vietnamese Government, in a surprise move, is to try the peace candidate in the presidential election last year on a charge of having urged the formation of a coalition government as a step toward peace.

STRATFORD, Ontario, July 23 -- The opening - night crowd at the Stratford Festival's "Three Musketeers" last night may have wondered about the posters of Humphrey Bogart and Marlene Dietrich in the lobby.

JERUSALEM -- Jerusalem is one of the world's most famous cities and one of the most unfortunate. It has been a site of warfare almost since it was founded, the scene of blood sacrifice, murder and sectarian strife.
Friends and relatives of Robert F. Kennedy are considering a number of memorials to the late Senator, including college scholarships for bright slum youngsters and fellowships for slum workers.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Senate and one of its committees moved today to exempt nearly 800,000 jobs from a Congressional mandate for manpower reductions in the executive branch.
Two policemen were hit by thrown bottles last evening in a Coney Island area plagued by four successive nights of disturbances.

SOUTH CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 23 (AP) -- A series of small explosions ruptured a tank filled with deadly chlorine gas tonight at a petrochemical plant here, forcing thousands to evacuate their homes over a 12-block area.

Moses M. Weinstein, the Democratic County leader of Queens, was sworn in yesterday as Acting Speaker of the Assembly. He said immediately that he would fight to keep the Speakership in the event that the Democrats still controlled the lower house of the Legislature next January.
When the Newport Jazz Festival programed five big jazz bands in the course of one day early this month, a disturbing impression left by this marathon was the essential similarity of the arrangements.
CLEVELAND, Wednesday, July 24 -- Mayor Stokes this morning attributed Cleveland's violence to "a fairly well-definable group," but said he felt the disturbance "is not a riot."

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Officials of the Fidelity Group of mutual funds insisted today before a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing that the small brokerage firms that received special, indirect payments from the funds had performed services other than just selling fund shares.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Deputy Attorney General Warren Christopher defended as routine today a Justice Department memorandum that has been criticized as "propaganda" in support of Abe Fortas's nomination as Chief Justice.
JERUSALEM, July 23 -- The Government today denounced the hijacking of the E1 A1 jet as "airborne piracy" and said it viewed the incident with the greatest gravity.

Hundreds of youths who had been protesting a speech here by Vice President Humphrey roamed through the midtown area last night, tying up traffic on side streets and along Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.
BONN, July 23 -- West Germany is seeking to put a rein on the high-stepping foreign mutual funds operating in this country -- and the foreign fund managers are crying foul play.

BONN, July 23 -- The Interior Ministry of the State of Bavaria reported today that East German soldiers and workers had begun setting up a "security zone" along the East German border with Czechoslovakia.

Striking insurance agents, supported by hundreds of dockworkers, disrupted traffic and scuffled with the police yesterday during picketing at the main offices of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
" I LEARN how to approach people, make people like me. It is very helpful."

" It was not Martin Luther King who emancipated the modern Negro, but Stepin Fetchit." That opinion came yesterday from Stepin Fetchit himself, as the 76-year-old Negro comedian attacked a television program's portrayal of Negro history for "taking me, a Negro hero, and converting me into a villain."

NEWTONVILLE, N. J., July 23 -- A train collided here this evening with a bus carrying 39 migrant farm laborers, killing nine of the laborers and injuring 16. Two of the dead are believed to have been children.

ATHENS, July 23 -- How far the Greek Orthodox Church in the United States should go to maintain cultural ties with the Greek homeland has become a major source of debate at the current Clergy-Laity Congress of the Archdiocese of North and South America.

RICHMOND, July 23 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit has returned to a lower Federal court for further consideration the question of the extent to which an agent of the Central Intelligence Agency enjoys immunity in testimony that allegedly is slanderous.

The Museum of Modern Art is establishing an Edward Steichen Archive containing the celebrated photographer's numerous exhibition catalogues, correspondence, notebooks, taped and written interviews, and magazines and newspaper articles about him.
Ellen Stewart, founder of Cafe La Mama, said yesterday that her avant-garde stage group would move into new headquarters at 74A East Fourth Street in late September.
The Norfolk Western Railway, traditionally one of the top money-makers in its industry, reported yesterday that its net income in the quarter ended June 30 rose to $19.4-million, or $1.80 a share.

WITH the summer visiting season in full swing, the Friday night exodus is marked by weekend travelers clutching shopping bags full of goodies for the families at the other end of the line. If there are children on the list, F. A. O. Schwarz has several new toys that should gladden the hearts of the recipients without putting much of a dent in the exchequer.

With its technological and managerial sophistication, this country ought to be able to provide the best, rather than one of the worst postal services in the world. That dream probably could be realized if Congress enacted the substantive recommendations of the President's Commission on Postal Organization as set forth in the splendid report Towards Postal Excellence.
TOURS, France -- The place to dine after a hard day of chateau-hopping this year is the newly three-starred Barrier here.

Wells, Rich, Greene, the most talked about agency in town, has just joined the list of Procter Gamble ad agencies. Since P. is the biggest advertiser in the world ($220-million just in the United States last year) it is a list that most ad men long to be on.
WALL STREET'S take-over tacticians have been using the "special bid" with increasing frequency and success. The most recent practitioner of the art is Bear, Stearns Co.
Twelve women picketed a New York Times classified advertising office yesterday to protest what they called the unfair and illegal segregation of sexes in the newspaper's help-wanted advertising.

Interest rates continued to move downward impressively yesterday. The Government's $1.33-billion certificate offering sold out and moved up in price while the Bell System sold a big triple-A bond issue at an interest cost a quarter point below an issue marketed a month ago.

The president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York said yesterday that Manhattan and Bronx political leaders had agreed to cooperate in seeking well-qualified nominees for the Supreme Court and Civil Court.

Barring a marked slowdown in the pace of trading in the stock market, the present practice of closing the market on Wednesday is likely to continue indefinitely, key securities industry sources predicted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee refused today to restore any of the $970-million slashed by the House in President Johnson's "bare bones" foreign aid request and whittled $23-million more from the authorizing legislation.

Will success spoil Henry H. Fowler? Five months ago, Fortune magazine was calling for his resignation. Today, the Secretary of the Treasury is basking in the sunshine of accomplishment and acceptance. Credit the bankers in cities and small towns across the United States. Credit the French university students.
An American insurance company has arranged with the Soviet Union to place package tourist policies with Ingosstrakh, a Soviet Government agency.

YONKERS, July 23 -- With the switch from Roosevelt Raceway (which closed tonight) to Yonkers Raceway for tomorrow night's reopening of the Westchester harness racing plant, punters are reminded that horses that stopped in the stretch at the Nassau County course may forget to do so here.

The Legislature has unanimously passed a bill creating 125 additional judges. This had been defeated a half dozen times in earlier years because the political parties had failed to agree in advance as to how the new jobs were to be divided between them.

NEWARK, July 23 -- Police Director Dominick A. Spina was shot at in his home early today. He said Negro terrorists may have tried to kill him, and that his life was saved because he happened to stoop down to pat his dog, Nero, just as a shotgun blast roared over head.

The next big postal rate increase will soon be levied on first class mail. Those mailers have no lobby, and there is where the money is. They could have and should have a lobby. Banks, utilities, oil and insurance companies account for much of first class mail, 85 per cent of which is used by business.

VITO (BABE) PARILLI has been around. When he was a rookie quarterback in pro football, Sammy Baugh was still playing for the Washington Redskins. Parilli was tested as Otto Graham's successor with the Cleveland Browns. He was with the Packers when Green Bay was known as the "Siberia" of the game. He performed with the Ottawa Rough Riders of the Canadian Football League.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange acted like a bouncing ball yesterday -- up and down all during the session until near the close, when a determined upward trend set in, only to be stopped by the bell. Over-all, the day's march was downhill.

ALGIERS, July 23 -- Twenty-one Israeli passengers and crewmen aboard an El Al airliner hijacked early this morning were detained here with the Boeing 707 jet, the official Algerian press agency reported.
Representatives of a wide variety of civic groups came together here yesterday on a call from Mrs. Martin Luther King Jr. to support demands of organized relief recipients.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the city's hopes for a peaceful Sept. 9 -- the day the public schools reopen -- depended upon the Board of Education's willingness to begin immediately to transfer its powers to neighborhood school boards.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 20 -- Chief of Police Rocky Pomerance lowered his muscular 260-pound frame into a swivel chair at headquarters today, reached for his favorite black, straight-stemmed Italian pipe and contemplated an approaching assignment: the security of the Republican National Convention.
UPPSALA, Sweden -- Standing with her eyes closed and her feet close together, a young woman allowed her limp body to be passed slowly from hand to hand by four men standing in a small circle.
DETROIT, July 23 -- A wealthy Detroit publisher, his wife and four children have been found shot to death in their summer home on Lake Michigan, 275 miles northwest of here.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- When Senator Edward M. Kennedy returned to Washington one day last week to sign papers that had been accumulating in his absence, he hesitated in his car outside the Old Senate Office Building.

CAIRO, July 23 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser urged the Arab world tonight not to be provoked prematurely into another war with Israel, saying that "we must have patience in order to score victory in the end."

HONG KONG, July 23 -- A recent pronouncement from Chairman Mao Tse-tung appeared today to have opened the way for a revival of higher education in Communist China, at least in the field of science and engineering.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Scheduled airline flights may have to be restricted to cope with increasing air congestion, a Federal Aviation Administrator official warned today.

CHICAGO, July 23 -- Striking telephone company electrical workers agreed today to provide volunteers to install communications equipment in the International Amphitheater, clearing the way for the Democratic National Convention to open there as scheduled Aug. 26.

THE United States Auto Club is experimenting this season with a format for Championship Trail races that resembles the baseball double-header. It is a pair of races on one program, a part answer to the fans' demand for bigger races.

The International Paper Company, the world's largest paper producer, achieved record second-quarter sales and an 8.2 per cent increase in earnings over a year ago, Edward B. Hinman, president, reported yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Wednesday, July 24 -- The police used Brink's armored cars last night to seal off an East Side Negro area after eight persons were killed -- three of them policemen hit by bursts of automatic gunfire from snipers in an apartment building.

MOSCOW, July 23 -- The Soviet Union announced tonight that large-scale maneuvers of support and supply troops were under way in the western part of the country, including areas near the Slovak region of Czechoslovakia.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 23 -- A head was the margin Sunny O'Brien held over Bobby Ed at the finish of the closing night's $25,000 invitation pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Black Sire, the show horse, was only a nose out of second place in an exciting race for New York-breds.

THE literary critics have not yet gone to work on Aldous Huxley -- though he has been dead now for nearly five years. His death of cancer at 69 on the day President Kennedy was assassinated nearly caught the press off its guard. When the tributes finally came, they centered on the man rather than on his art.

MRS. HENRY J. KAISER never thought it was Indian enough and Mr. Kaiser used to complain because the banana tree outside his bedroom wasn't very prolific. But aside from that, the Kaisers' Honolulu estate was everything the late construction tycoon wanted.

TRAVEMUNDE, Germany, July 23 (AP) -- The American yacht Rage, skippered by Homer Denius of Melbourne, Fla., closed in to challenge Stormvogel for the lead today in the Bermuda - to - Travemunde trans-Atlantic yacht race.

World shipbuilding reached a record level during the second quarter of this year, Lloyd's Register of Shipping reported yesterday. A total of 1,836 ships classified as ocean-going and aggregating 14.1 million gross tons were under construction on June 30.

SAIGON, July 23 (AP) -- General Worley, who was born Oct. 12, 1919, was graduated from pilot training at Brooks Field, Tex., in May, 1941, and was commissioned a second lieutenant in the Army Air Corps.

The Rexall Drug and Chemical Company is planning to add housewares to its diversified operations through a proposed acquisition of the privately held West Bend Company. of Wisconsin, for approximately $64-million of Rexall common and preferred stock. Justin Dart, president and chairman of Rexall, also reported increased sales and earnings for the second quarter but slightly lower profits for the initial six months.
A mortgage loan of $1.6-million at 7 per cent annual interest for a 10-year period has been placed on the 19-story apartment house at 857 Fifth Avenue, at the northeast corneer of 67th Street.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 23 -- An Arab guerrilla organization, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, declared today that it was responsible for hijacking the Israeli airliner and forcing it to land at the Algiers airport.
CHIASSO, Switzerland, July 23 (AP) -- A group of Swiss and West German companies have successfully tested a new export route to Japan -- by train across the Trans-Siberian Railway.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 24 -- Enemy gunners renewed their attacks on cities and military installations early this morning in what appeared to be a stepped-up campaign of terror directed at civilians as well as the military.

As the jet speeds toward the city at 600 miles an hour, the pilot suddenly announces that he expects an hour's delay in the terminal area before the plane is cleared to land. Before long, the jet is circling aimlessly in a holding pattern and passengers begin to grow restless.
About 250 policemen were sent into the Spanish-speaking section of the Lower East Side last night after youths in a crowd of 300 tossed bottles at Tactical Patrol Force policemen.
The Yankees continued to make one the hard way last night as they defeated the Boston Red Sox, 4-1, with the deciding run coming home on a bases-filled walk.
The youth and excitement that have marked this most unusual tennis season were reflected yesterday in the first series of rankings for the tennis player of the year.
Seasonal lows were hit by most commodity futures contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., July 23 -- Willis Reed, the captain of the New York Knickerbockers, said today he was seeking a multiple-year contract. Reed made the statement while touring the team's training facilities.
LONDON, July 23 -- The court of last resort for the Commonwealth and British colonies held today that all laws and orders made by the rebel. Government of Rhodesia were without legal effect.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Three out of four Mayors who examined the question "Is the Big City Dying?" answered "no" today. But they admitted that they were practicing the "politics of hope."
ALBANY, July 24 -- The Consolidated Edison Company of New York and seven other major utilities in the state want permission to increase their rates as their taxes increase.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -Stereotypers struck Washington's three daily newspapers today, preventing publication of tomorrow's editions of The Washington Post, a morning paper.

The Lytton Financial Corporation, the troubled Los Angeles savings and loan holding company, reported yesterday a net loss of $9.2-million for the first half of the year, including a special charge of $7.6-million for possible losses on outstanding loans and real estate owned.

The removal from Brooklyn of the American Machine and Foundry Company is another blow to the economic welfare of this borough and the city. This, along with the closing down of the Brooklyn Army Terminal, the removal of the Bethlehem Steel Company and many others in the South Brooklyn-Bush Terminal industrial complex, is the natural result of the finding that industrial automation has made it economically unfeasible to continue operation in these outmoded plants.
Strikes showed a strong dampening influence on earnings reports issued by leading metals producers yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The United States had an inflow of $213-million worth of gold in June, marking a major reversal from the pattern of heavy outflows earlier this year, the Treasury Department reported today.

ATHENS, July 24 -- The Government today called on delegates of the International Transport Workers' Federation, who are to open their annual meeting Sunday, to visit Greece before beginning a debate on a proposal for a worldwide boycott of Greek shipping.
The new $72-million super-liner Queen Elizabeth 2 stands poised at her builder's yard on the Clyde in Scotland nearly ready to go.
Pushing the lower jaw toward the back of the head for 10 minutes three times a day can relieve the excruciating pain of tic douloureux, a Texas neurologist has reported.

ATLANTA, July 24 -- After having made an error that might have prevented a run, Bob Johnson lined a single to center with two out in the 10th inning tonight to give the Atlanta Braves a 3-2 victory over the New York Mets, the team for which he hit .348 last year.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy has left an estate in New York estimated at $250,000 to $300,000, according to lawyers for his family. His will was filed for probate yesterday in Manhattan Surrogate's court.

The refusal of Justice Fortas to discuss the application of his legal philosophy in terms of past cases on the grounds of the separation-of-powers principle ironically contradicts the present direction of the Supreme Court itself.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Johnson ordered all Government departments today to begin using envelopes that will not jam the Post Office's automatic mail processing machines.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Federal Trade Commission held today that the Sperry Hutchinson Co. of New York had illegally restrained trade in overseeing the issuance and redemption of S. H. Green Stamps.

CLEVELAND, July 24 -- Fred Ahmed Evans, a prominent black nationalist here, predicted in April, 1967, that on May 9 of that year there would be major racial confrontations across the nation.

STRATFORD, Ont., July 24 -- There is a lot not to like in the production of Chekhov's "The Seagull" that opened last night on the picture-frame stage of the Stratford Festival's downtown theater, the Avon.
UTICA, N. Y., July 24 (AP) -- Two former champions and the state junior titleholder splashed to victory today in the second round of the New York State men's amateur golf championship.
There were multiplying signs yesterday that the nation was undertaking a broad effort to come to grips with the air-traffic crisis that overtook it early this month.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 24 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan of California told Alabama Republicans today that neither party could win the Presidency without the South and that George C. Wallace's third party effort would neutralize the South this year.

CHILMARK, Mass., July 24 -- The manmade opening from Chilmark Pond to the Atlantic Ocean was only 25 feet wide and kneedeep near the top of the flood tide and it seemed as if the tide, plus the strong southwest breeze that had sprung up in the afternoon, might close it.

A DECLARER who is establishing a side-suit can often be inconvenienced if he is forced to ruff in the hand with the side-suit. West tried this plan on the diagramed deal, but found that South had a satisfactory counter.

JERUSALEM, July 24 -- The Israeli Government was employing every diplomatic means at its disposal today to persuade Algeria to return the Israeli passengers and crew and the El Al jetliner that was hijacked yesterday over the Mediterranean.
Not quite a generation ago the city fireman was a friendly neighborhood figure, a tall man in a blue shirt who made instant, cooling showers in the hot summer streets by opening hydrants.

YONKERS, July 24 -- Rain and a Yonkers Raceway opening (or reopening) are virtually synonymous. More often than not, the elements frown on such occasions at the Old Hilltop harness racing course and tonight's return of action, beginning a 74-card stand, was in keeping with the established pattern here.

SYRACUSE, July 24 -- A man employed as a part-time teacher in a Federal program at Utica College, a division of Syracuse University, was arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents here yesterday after boarding an airliner leaving for Boston allegedly carrying concealed weapons in a suitcase.
Puerto Rican leaders on the Lower East Side formed a committee yesterday that will seek to restore peace in the area.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, called the 3-M Company, reported record-breaking sales and earnings in the second quarter, lifting half-year earnings 11.5 per cent over last year.

Jim J. won the $27,950 Gravesend Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday, but neither his owner, Harold Polk, nor his trainer, Eddie Yowell, was on hand to see him do it. They had planned to come by helicopter. from Monmouth Park, Jim J. home grounds, but the thunderstorm prevented the trip.

TWO ballets by Kenneth MacMillan gave a certain Scots accent to American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Mind you the Scots accent was more in the letter than the spirit, but the ballets in question did show the two aspects of Mr. MacMillan -- his interest in pure dance and dance drama -- to interesting effect.
LONDON, July 24 -- A major primary aluminum industry costing more than $300-million will be established in Britain by three international companies at three different sites.

A former Harlem teacher whose license was revoked for taking children to a memorial program for Malcolm X last winter has been appointed director of New York University's new Martin Luther King Jr. Afro-American Student Center.
Kenyon Eckhardt, which eight months ago became the sole world-wide agency for Helena Rubinstein, Inc., unveiled the first campaign the other morning at the agency.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Predictions of a protracted war have faded out of recent declarations by the North Vietnamese leadership, which now seems to be stressing a shorter struggle.
The president of the newly enlarged Board of Education warned yesterday that "there are those who are seeking to divide the new board members from the old and to polarize the two groups."
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Congressional pressure mounted here today for a solution to the air traffic delay problem plaguing New York and other large cities.
There are little kites and big kites; there are silk, papier mache, papyrus and even fiber-glass kites; there are box kites, diamond kites and Indian fighting kites.

Paul O'Dwyer, the Democratic Senate candidate, charged President Johnson yesterday with responsibility for undermining both the Paris peace talks and Hubert H. Humphrey's bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

An estimated 36,000 commuters on 74 trains, were delayed up to an hour yesterday morning when two cars of the Boston-New York Express, the Owl, derailed near Grand Central Terminal. There were no injuries.

PRAGUE, July 24 -- A Communist party spokesman said today that Czechoslovakia saw room for compromise in the coming talks with the Soviet leadership, but no prospect of change in her general political line.

LAGOS, Nigeria, July 24 -- A little over seven months ago eight intrepid Czechoslovak university students set out on a 14,000-mile journey from Prague to Lambarene to visit the leprosarium that Albert Schweitzer founded in Gabon in 1913.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark. -- When Winthrop Rockefeller was elected Arkansas's first Republican Governor since Reconstruction days, the business and professional men of the Marion Hotel Coffee Shop Breakfast Club gave him an innocent little white lamb.

NEWARK, July 24 -- More than $3-million in counterfeit $20 Federal Reserve notes, destined for distribution through organized criminal channels, were confiscated in Bricktown, N. J., today by Secret Service agents. They also rounded up eight persons allegedly involved in the production of the bogus bills.

PORTHCAWL, Wales, July 24 (AP) -- Jose Legra of Spain, the European featherweight boxing champion, stopped Howard Winstone of Wales in 2:02 of the fifth round tonight and won partial recognition as world champion.
The airlines appealed yesterday for Government action to help end the delays that have plagued passengers using New York's airports for more than three weeks.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that record trading volume helped increase the net profits from securities commissions last year for its member organizations.

MOSCOW, July 24 -- The weekly newspaper Literaturnaya Gazeta said today that the West Germans were attempting to exploit the liberalization in Czechoslovakia to break the country away from the Soviet bloc.
IN the Sicilian Defense between Carangelo, a Brooklyn expert, and the New York grandmaster Nicholas Rossolimo, Black's performance rounded out an ideal lesson for the aspiring student.

A Mafia figure, a powerful garment trucking official and a deceased union leader were said yesterday to be among seven persons who shared a $160,000 kickback to arrange a $1.5-million loan from a union pension fund.

With due respect to Secretary General U Thant, I wish to differ with him on the question of the sincerity of the Nigeria Government in sending food through "mercy corridors" to the starving millions of Biafrans.
LONDON, July 24 - The House of Commons today condemned one of its Members for "gross contempt of the House" in leaking committee testimony to a newspaper.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- American companies have borrowed or arranged to borrow more than $3-billion abroad so far this year, six times as much as the level last year, it was disclosed today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 24 -- An agreement for the development at Fort Slocum of one of the world's largest nuclear-fueled electric generating plants was signed today by officials of New Rochelle and the Consolidated Edison Company.
A solid price recovery in wheat yesterday was trimmed in later dealings as buying by commercial houses dried up.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A bill to curb interstate mail order sales of long guns and some ammunition cleared the House today after four days of bitter debate.
NEWPORT, R. J., July 24 -Modestly, almost quietly, the eighth annual Newport Folk Festival began this afternoon at Festival Field here.

The Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat) reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first half and second quarter. The report placed first-half operating revenues at $14,252,000 compared with $6,963,000 a year earlier.

The recent appointment of the Rev. Milton A. Galamison to the Board of Education is a disgrace. How the Mayor of New York can reward this man who has helped to create chaos for thousands of pupils through his inspired school boycotts and who has been in jail on nine occasions is something I will never understand.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The tattered remnants of the highway beautification program -- known as the "Lady Bird bill" -- barely remained today in a final version agreed upon by a House-Senate conference committee.

A parade of witnesses told local delegates to the Democratic National Convention yesterday that the nation must revise its priorities and meet unfulfilled promises to its poor. The consequence of inaction, the witnesses said, would be deepening division and violence that could inflict "mortal wounds" on the country.
NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., July 24 -- Richard M. Nixon will break his four-month silence on the war in Vietnam next week.
Longer-term Government securities, after climbing sharply on Monday and Tuesday, fell back a little yesterday, but Treasury bills kept on advancing.

NEWARK, July 24 -- Police Director Dominick A. Spina said today that investigators were "checking out a few names" and a New York State license number after the attempt that was made on his life early yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, -- An editor whose paper had been closed by Government decree sat in his cramped office six months ago and told why he had little hope for South Vietnam.

New York City's Puerto Ricans are still struggling up from the bottom of the city's economic pyramid. They have made gains, but they have also suffered setbacks. They believe they don't get all the neighborhood services they should. And their leadership is once again split by new dissension.
BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, July 24 -- Czechoslovak military uniforms and vehicles are conspicuous sights in this capital of Slovakia these days, but civilian life looks placid enough.
WICHITA, Kan., July 24 -- Although all the assignments have not been made, Governor Rockefeller's organization for the Republican National Convention, which opens in 12 days, has begun to take shape.

In many ways, Julian Brown is a typical member of his freshman class at Dartmouth College. A graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy, where he played on the football and basketball teams, the 18-year-old youth can recall a comfortable and intellectually stimulating childhood as the son of a college professor who now teaches at Virginia State College in Norfolk.

Colt Industries, Inc., offered yesterday to acquire the Crucible Steel Corporation in an exchange of stock valued at some $205-million. Crucible welcomed the offer. George A. Strichman, chairman and president of Colt, said the tax-free exchange of Colt common and preferred stock would have a market value of at least $48 for each outstanding share of Crucible common.
HILLSBORO, N. C. -- "Our house is neither famous nor historically great," Mrs. Robert Murphy declared, "but you may find it interesting and we love to share it."

Fear of Mafia retaliation has kept a suspended policeman from testifying before a grand jury that is investigating a five-year-old murder, a prosecutor said yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Senator Thruston B. Morton of Kentucky, a key operative in Governor Rockefeller's efforts to win the Republican Presidential nomination, said today that former Vice President Richard M. Nixon's campaign had "peaked" too soon, as it did in 1960.
City and state narcotics officials were angrily accused last night of "shutting out" the Harlem community in the fight against drug addiction.
BONN, July 24 -- The West German Defense Ministry has agreed to shift its controversial maneuvers away from the Czechoslovak border, a ministry spokesman announced today.
THE Norwich is one of the smallest terrier breeds. The ideal height is 10 inches at the withers, with a weight of 11 pounds, and the breed comes in two varieties, with pointed or drop ears.

An increase in the general interest ceiling from 6 per cent to 7.25 per cent, which became effective in New York State July 1, has apparently caused some confusion among owners of one-family and two-family houses with mortgages.

CAIRO, July 24 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser has told King Hussein that the Egyptian armed forces will not be completely rebuilt and ready to do battle with Israel before 1970, well-informed Arab sources reported today.
THE AMK Corporation has apparently won out over the National General Corporation in its bid for the Great American Holding Corporation, whose assets exceed $587-million.
PRO football's off-the-field problems with its players are not over so long as John Wooten, the former star guard for the Browns, continues to brood and plot in Cleveland.
CLEVELAND, Thursday, July 25 -- Mayor Carl B. Stokes ordered all National Guard troops and white policemen withdrawn yesterday from a six-square-mile area on this city's troubled East Side.
