At home, the two races are poised in uneasy equilibrium between those individuals and forces pushing for fratricidal conflict and those working for constructive programs and an essential reconciliation. The nation's political institutions are under siege from the radicals of both the far right and the far left.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 24 (AP) -- Bob Hewitt of South Africa and Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico, the top-seeded players, were beaten in the Pennsylvania lawn-tennis championship today.

INTERLOCHEN, Mich., July 24 -- It's a summer camp, all right, and the kids do have their overnight hikes and weenie roasts, but there are a few things that make the National Music Camp here just a bit different from Camp Kitchiekootchie in Maine or Minniehoh-haha in Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Senate voted by a narrow 46-45 margin today against setting up a new device by which the Federal Reserve System could pump money directly into housing areas in times of tight money.
LONDON, July 24 -- British youths would be able to vote for Parliament at the age of 18 instead of 21 under changes in electoral laws recommended today by the Government.
Elston Howard disclosed yesterday that an ailing throwing elbow threatened his career.

The Penn-Dixie Cement Corporation last disclosed night that it had acquired about 201,000 shares of the Continental Steel Corporation through its special bid on the New York Stock Exchange for 250,000 shares at $62 a share.
WESTPORT, Conn. -- Associate Justice Abe Fortas sums her up dispassionately; his voice is measured and free of partiality; the glance he directs at the slight woman in the big yellow sun hat is not.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The opponents of Abe Fortas's nomination as Chief Justice fell silent today on a note of satisfaction, for the seven days of hearings have produced delay and a grab bag of anti-Fortas issues.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Treasury bill rate fell dramatically at today's auction from last month's levels, the Treasury disclosed today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 24 -- South Korean Marines ambushed two enemy platoons near Hoian this morning shortly after the oily had undergone a mortar barrage and a fierce ground attack.
DANANG, South Vietnam, July 24 -- For the last month, allied troops have been building a barbed-wire barrier around Danang designed to reduce enemy infiltration and rocket attacks.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- An authorization of $390-million for military aid was tentatively approved today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
ATLANTA, July 24 -- Organizations challenging the regular party delegations to the Democratic National Convention from Alabama and Georgia are pressing their cases before national party officials.
The stock market was quiet and unchanged yesterday. But business in the financial community went on -- if not as usual, then almost so.

The National Association of Securities Dealers announced yesterday that its board of governors had approved what it called a "special crash program" to deal with the back-office paperwork problem on Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Representative Frank Thompson Jr. of New Jersey, a leader in the House Democratic liberal bloc, announced today his support of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota for President.

PARIS, July 24 -- The United States asked North Vietnam today if it had intended in recent statements to soften the phrasing of one of its demands and thereby open the way toward progress in the talks here.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., July 24 -- A laser that could be built in a home workshop with $25 to $50 worth of materials, using ordinary commercial dyes to generate the laser beam itself, has been developed by researchers at the International Business Machines Corporation's Watson Research Center.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Sponsors of a bipartisan plan intended to prevent George C. Wallace from stalemating this year's Presidential election said today that four candidates had endorsed it. They also said the plan had gained wide acceptance since it was proposed earlier this month.
LONDON, July 24 -Workmen are struggling to convert an extravagant Edwardian theater, most recently used for Cinerama, into London's second opera house.
Michael Medved, chairman of Kennedy Students for a New America, announced yesterday that 5,000 members had endorsed Governor Rockefeller for the Republican Presidential nomination.
HONG KONG, July 24 -- In a new get-tough policy, troops are shooting to kill in an effort to stop factional fighting in Kwangtung that has been growing in frequency and violence in the last month.

Without fanfare and before East Harlem was really stirring, Vice President Humphrey drew a cheering crowd of 500 yesterday morning when he dedicated 118th Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues, as a play street.

The Senate seat left vacant by the death of Robert Kennedy has yet to be filled. The mourning period has passed. Certainly a man in high public office with wide contacts, such as Governor Rockefeller has, could, by now, have made a decision as to the qualifications of any one of several men he would wish to appoint to the Senate.
The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday earnings declines in the second quarter and first half, despite sales gains in both periods.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The development of an American "land-bridge" to be created along the lines of the Communications Satellite Corporation was proposed here today by Senator Frank E. Moss.
CINCINNATI, July 24 -- Over the protests of a handful of its members, the National Governors Conference rejected today any coordinated national approach to the problem of gun controls.
" The Riddle of Lester Maddox," a play about the Democratic Governor of Georgia, will be presented Oct. 3 at Theater Atlanta in Georgia.
Mayor Lindsay was warned yesterday by City Council President Frank D. O'Connor against "any City Hall interference, actual or circumstantial, in the day-to-day operations of the Police Department."

TRAVEMUNDE, Germany, July 24 (UPI) -- The American yacht Ondine and the Italian naval yacht Stella Polare passed the tip of Denmark today, sharing honors on the first leg of the trans-Atlantic sailing race from Bermuda to Travemunde.
The Rockland National Bank has signed an $8-million lease for 40,000 square feet of space at Blue Hill, a 225-acre office community being erected by Uris Buildings Corporation in Orangetown, N. Y.
THE TRIAL OF THE ASSASSIN GUITEAU. By Charles E. Rosenberg. 289 pages. University of Chicago. $5.95.
White racism forces the American Negro to lead a life of "cultural paranoia" and often pushes him over the brink into true paranoid schizophrenia, a black psychiatrist said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Nobody loves George Wallace but about 15 or 20 per cent of the people, depending on which poll you read.

PARIS, July 24 -- There is a lot of remarkable talent in the French haute couture, but on the third day of the fall collections it seemed to be in hiding. The Paris collections are full of fumbles. So far, no designer has a really interesting point of view to put across.
Dan Flavin, an artist who works with fluorescent light, has extinguished his exhibit at the Whitney Museum because the art next door made too much noise.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A bipartisan group of 26 Senators introduced legislation today aimed at the creation in poor areas of the country of community-controlled enterprises that would operate essential community services, such as day care centers, out of the profits of businesses they would own.

LONDON, July 24, (Reuters) -- United States Equestrian Team riders took the first three places today in the Nizefela Stakes on the second day of the six-day Royal International horse show at Wembley Stadium.
CHICAGO, July 24 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley endorsed Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts today for Vice President.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Five weeks before one of them is chosen as the Democratic nominee for President, the main question for Hubert H. Humphrey and Eugene J. McCarthy has become, who catches whom?

HARTFORD, July 24 -- Mayor Lindsay reacted to last night's disorders in Cleveland by angrily blaming Congress for making what he charged was "hollow rhetoric" of the report of the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Vice President Humphrey called in specialists on Vietnam and other Asian problems today to help prepare a detailed statement on the war issue.
TRENTON, July 24 -- New Jersey conservationists are opposing a plan that utility companies contend would preserve scenic Sunfish Pond atop Kittatinny Mountain in Warren County.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Five weeks before one of them is chosen as the Democratic nominee for President, the main question for Hubert H. Humphrey and Eugene J. McCarthy has become, who catches whom?

Dr. Allan M. Cartter, chancellor of New York University, said yesterday that he was reviewing the appointment of John F. Hatchett as director of the university's new Martin Luther King Jr. Afro- American Student Center.
NEW ROCHELLE, July 25 -- Mayor Lindsay -- like his New Rochelle counterpart -- "looks with favor" on the Consolidated Edison Company's plan to build a nuclear-powered generating plant on Fort Slocum.
DETROIT, July 25 -- Profit of the General Motors Corporation rose in the second quarter and first half of this year but failed to keep pace with record sales, the company reported today.

The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled yesterday that the Federal Maritime Commission had not had "sufficient provocation" to order the dissolution of the Calcutta, East Coast of India and East Pakistan-U.S.A. Conference.
The problems of the Broadway theater, and a few possible solutions, were examined yesterday by a dozen representatives of the industry.
Leaders of 45 local unions or labor councils representing 125 international unions gave Paul O'Dwyer strong indications of labor support yesterday in his bid for the United States Senate.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The pressures of the election campaign are mounting up, and maybe it should be noted, even at this early date, that the American Presidential electoral system demands more energy, patience, and wisdom that most ordinary mortals possess.
SUDDENLY a frown clouded the face of Fenton Hardy, the world-famous detective father of the Hardy Boys.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved the smallest foreign aid authorization bill in the history of the program today after pruning $25million from military assistance grants.
Twenty-three firemen were injured, none seriously, when a four-alarm fire swept through a row of stores in a business section of the Bronx yesterday afternoon.
There are several things wrong with fire hydrants, the Creative Arts Academy, a summer project for poor youngsters at the High School of Music and Art, has decided.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The House stood firm today for cutting off Federal loans and grants to students who take part in serious campus disturbances.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25 -- The number of Americans killed in combat dropped last week to the lowest figure of the year in the absence of any large-scale military operations by either side.
ATLANTA, July 25 -- That hallowed baseball lament, "one bad pitch," undid Dick Selma again tonight as Joe Torre's three-run homer gave the Atlanta Braves a 4-2 victory over the New York Mets.

LONDON, July 25 -- The Barclays, Lloyds and Martins banks called off their proposed three-way merger today after the Government announced its opposition. But Barclays quickly made an offer to take over Martins on its own.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 25 -- The Summer National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League begin here tomorrow and continue for almost two weeks.

TRAVEMUNDE, West Germany, July 25 (AP) -- S. A. (Huey) Long of New York, who briefly had considered withdrawing from the race, brought his 73-foot ketch Ondine into port first today in the Bermuda - to - Travemunde yacht race.
Harlem, eagerly caught up in a marked increase in artistic and cultural self-expression, is nearing a crossroads.
The Federal Maritime Commission yesterday ordered the North Atlantic Westbound Freight Association to halt its investigation of Container Marine Lines.
Santos, one of the world's elite soccer clubs, yesterday yielded to the American dollar by selling one of its starting players, Eliseu, to the New York Generals of the North American Soccer League.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 25 -The pop and jazz worlds have no monopoly on happenings or jam sessions. The Newport Folk Festival had one tonight and called it "Free Form Folk."

LONDON, July 25 -- A backdown by the London financial community's Take-Over Panel in a dispute involving the American Tobacco Company and its British financial advisers stirred a new controversy tonight over the effectiveness of self-policing in the British securities business.

Someday of the Hobeau Farm proved a popular performer at Aqueduct yesterday. Backed into heavy favoritism by the crowd of 25,888, she responded satisfactorily enough, winning the six-furlong sprint for older fillies and mares by a length and a quarter.

BOSTON, July 25 -- Aides of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said today that Vice President Humphrey had refused to meet him in a debate unless it was held the week before the Democratic National Convention.

Two rival groups of college students, one on the East Coast and one on the West Coast, plan to set off in opposite directions on Aug. 19 in a cross-country auto race aimed at showing the electric automobile as the car of the future.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 -The possibility of two stanchly conservative Republicans representing California in the United States Senate is agitating many knowledgeable Democrats and moderate Republicans.

A probationary patrolman working in a blue uniform in the tense Coney Island section of Brooklyn was hit in the head by a brick last night after he broke up a craps game at West 25th Street and Mermaid Avenue.

Grandmaster Larry Evans of New York, a former United States champion, maintained the lead in the United States Chess Championship at the Empire Hotel here Wednesday night by drawing his game with Master Bernard Zuckerman, also of New York. Thus, Evans has scored 5 1/2 points out of 7.
Paintings headed the list of best sellers in the auction season just ended at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

JERUSALEM -- There has been a recent change of emphasis in secret efforts to find Middle Eastern peace. Israeli feelers now concentrate on Amman, not Cairo, evidently having concluded that peace with Jordan -- the "Palestine problem" -- should precede peace with Egypt -- the "Sinai problem." But no settlement anywhere is yet in sight.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today that there appeared to be less evidence of conspiracy to cause big-city riots than in the last few years.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Reports of current Soviet military maneuvers, said to be among the largest in Soviet history, have aroused both keen interest and unusual reticence among high Government officials here.
NIAGARA FALLS, July 25 -- The first major project in the planned rebuilding of downtown town Niagara Falls, a $20-million office building complex, was announced here today.

You are to be commended for Thomas A. Johnson's July 21 news article on civil rights. Through this well-presented analysis it is becoming apparent that a significant number of black people want to do things themselves.
Two new proposals for tighter controls over air traffic in congested areas were put forward yesterday at a airline meeting called to deal with the current crisis on the airways.
NEWARK, July 25 -- Newark's Police Director, Dominick A. Spina, was indicted by an Essex County grand jury today on charges of willfully refusing to enforce the state's gambling laws.
LONGBINH, South Vietnam, July 24 -- The buses from the airport rumble into the camp, creaking to a halt and pushing clouds of hot dust into the heavy air.
" There's a Girl in My Soup" will close tomorrow night after its 322d performance at the Music Box. The comedy will begin a 12-month tour next Tuesday in Central City, Colo.

LONDON, July 25 -- Sir Fitzroy Maclean, a strong-minded Scot who dropped behind the German lines in World War II to make contact with Marshal Tito's Partisans, has voiced a feeling that is widespread here about the West's role in the Czechoslovak crisis.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- Congress's retreat from its order to cut Government payrolls ran into objections today and the Post Office Department proceeded with plans to cut mail service, starting this weekend.
THE PATCH COMMISSION. By Frederick Crews. 173 pages. Dutton. $3.95.

The appeal of George Whitmore Jr. from his conviction a year ago for attempted rape and assault was held in abeyance yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court pending a lower court hearing on the question of his identification by the victim.

Forty undercover agents investigating the growing traffic in stolen handguns along the Brooklyn waterfront made four arrests and seized at least 27 stolen guns in a series of raids early yesterday. A fifth man was being sought.
The city's Council Against Poverty heard complaints last night that it was operating on obsolete data and failing to realize how conditions were worsening in some sections.
The average delay on airline flights from Chicago to Kennedy International Airport on Wednesday was three hours and 14 minutes.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Governor Rockefeller asserted tonight that the central longterm goal of United States foreign policy should be the transition "from a relationship of conflict to one of cooperation with the Soviet Union."

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 25 -- The drip method will be one of the techniques employed by youthful "architects'' here on Aug. 3, when Guild Hall's youth committee, headed by Mrs. Carlo Grossman, sponsors its second annual Sand castle competition.
Increased earnings were reported yesterday by several of the nation's largest petroleum companies and the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced an increase in its quarterly dividend rate.
THE New York Mets last year went through 27 pitchers, 27 other players, three coaches, a manager and a president. The only one who left voluntarily was the president, Bing Devine.

Estimates of the number of people who are already dying of starvation each day in the Nigerian secessionist state of Biafra vary from 200 to 3,000. Estimates of the number who face starvation in the months ahead vary from one to ten million.

A leading Wall Street stock brokerage concern announced yesterday plans to open a branch in Harlem -- the first branch there of a major member of the New York Stock Exchange or the American Stock Exchange.

Ron Kramer, the best tight end in pro football not so many years ago, is looking for a job. Kramer, who helped the Green Bay Packers so much in winning their first two league championships under Vince Lombardi in 1961-62, was given his unconditional release by the Detroit Lions yesterday.
The Uniformed Fire Officers Association yesterday voted a "job action" -- the refusal to perform nonfirefighting duties -- to back up demands for more manpower.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 25 -- The 12-man Cabinet of President Rene Barrientos Ortuno resigned tonight in the political crisis that has resulted from the publication of the captured diary of Ernesto Che Guevara.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 25 -- The New York Yacht Club cruise, an old and distinguished sailing event that in recent years also has included predicted log racing for a scattering of powerboats, assembled here today for a start tomorrow to Rhode Island and Massachusetts ports.

PRAGUE, July 25 -- The progressive leadership of the Czechoslovak Communist party is reliably reported to fear that its control over conservative members of the Presidium, the party's ruling body, is slipping.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 25 -- Janio Quadros, the last democratically-elected President of Brazil, was detained by the federal police for two hours this morning in the port of Santos, as a result of his recent criticism of the Government.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 25 -- The week-old Iraqi regime is showing signs of fissure between the young officers of the army who staged the coup d'etat of July 17, and their political partners of the Baath (Socialist) party.
A fight over the selection of the next Democratic national committeeman from New York is developing among the state leaders of the party.
WARSAW, July 25 -- The Polish Communist party again attacked the Czechoslovak leadership today amid signs that Poland's armed forces were involved in major military preparations.
An extraordinary credit helped the Allied Chemical Corporation to register increases in its net income for the second quarter and the first half of the year.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 25 (AP) -- Four seeded players -two Americans, a South African and an Australian -reached the men's semi-final round today in the 69th annual Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club.
NAIROBI, Kenya, July 25 -- Little signs of democracy are bursting out in strange ways and in unexpected places in Kenya.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts has drafted a plain and unambiguous statement taking himself out of consideration for the 1968 Democratic Vice-Presidential nomination.
" THEY are kind of monumental jewels," Warren Platner said of his 500-pound, $6,000 desks that may well become status symbols in executive offices across the land.

CLEVELAND, July 25 -- Mayor Carl B. Stokes ordered the police and Ohio National Guardsmen to return to the East Side tonight. He abandoned the Negro citizens' patrols he had established in the area after an outbreak of looting.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- Mayor Daley said today that Senator Kennedy was considering whether he would accept a draft as the Democratic party's Vice-Presidential nominee.
Heidi, that sweet Swiss miss, is hitting the comeback trail -- this time in the ad game.

YONKERS, July 25 -- Each winner of her respective division in the 13th annual Hudson Filly Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight accounted for the season's fastest clocking by a diagonally-gaited distaff sophomore performing on a half-mile track.

MONTREAL, July 25 -Montreal's newly acquired National League baseball franchise, which has already lost two of its original seven board directors, now faces an Aug. 15 deadline that if not met, could cost the city its chance to own a major league team.
The National Dairy Products Corporation reported yesterday that its half-year results were the highest in its history.

CANTERBURY, England, July 25 -- More than 450 bishops of the worldwide Anglican Communion journeyed to the birthplace of English Christianity today for a stately prayer service marking the opening of the 10th Lambeth Conference.
As seasonal and profuse as the flowers of spring, campaign buttons are in bloom again.
Complaints from workers about physical attacks in slum areas are now so common that many unions and employers here are involved in serious studies of the problem.

Most of the governors at their annual conference did not find the keynote speech of John W. Gardner to their liking. The former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, who now heads the Urban Coalition, cut through the sham surrounding the problems of the cities and pointed to some painful truths.
PARIS, July 25 -- There were lots of surprises in the new Courreges collection today, but, the biggest shock of all came from seeing so much black -- even on legs.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., July 25 -- The New York State Commissioner of Education, James V. Allen Jr., has ordered the Newburgh School District to begin "promptly" to develop a plan for the elimination of racial imbalance in the city's 14 elementary schools.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- The nation's capital was hit by a newspaper blackout for the first time in nearly 20 years today as striking stereotypers stayed off their jobs in a dispute over a new contract.
WOBURN, England, July 25 (AP) -- Angry villagers accused the Duke of Bedford today of having turned his stately home into a hippie haven and complained that they had to pick up the rubbish.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -Vice President Humphrey offered tonight a plan to establish a more effective line of communication between citizens and their Government, including the White House.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 25 -- A pink and white tent big enough for 500 dancing guests will be erected for a benefit cocktail party Aug. 25 on the grounds of the Irving Hotel here.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois endorsed Governor Rockefeller of New York for the Republican nomination for President today.
James Farmer, Republican-Liberal candidate for Congress from the 12th District in Brooklyn, opened his campaign last night by calling for "the end of the old plantation politics of the past."
CLEVELAND, July 25 -There was a large crowd at 125th Street and Superior Avenue at 2 P.M. today as firemen poured water on the smoldering ruins of several damaged stores.
LEE, Mass., July 25 -- This week's program at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, featuring the Pennsylvania Ballet, has appropriately, been dedicated to Ruth St. Denis.

WYANDANCH, L. I., July 25 -- A petition to dissolve the troubled, predominantly Negro school district here and merge it with more affluent white districts has been rejected by the State Education Commissioner as "impracticable at this time."
GENEVA, July 25 -- The disarmament conference here is expected to turn its attention soon to the problem of barring the use of the sea bed as a hiding place for nuclear missiles.
Two events in the Middle East this week tend to sustain the pessimistic opinion of many Americans that relations between Israel and the Arabs are steadily deteriorating.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined sharply yesterday in active trading. The exchange's index lost 39 cents, closing at $28.35.

William Price Fox, an author known for strange and comic tales about the South, has scored what he considers a real triumph in Hollywood. "Me and Dad," he said here yesterday, "have been engaged by a film company as technical advisers on setting up moonshine stills."

A sharp rise in the location and expansion of industrial plants at waterside sites occurred during the second quarter of the year, Braxton B. Carr, president of The American Waterways Operators, Inc., reported yesterday.
Demands for better housing, more jobs and more parks in a predominantly Puerto Rican area of the Lower East Side emerged yesterday from this week's disorders there.

As the tax-exempt bond market yesterday was winding up its second strongest week so far in 1968, the Housing Assistance Administration announced plans to sell $129,045,000 of bonds, and New York State announced plans for a $81-million sale.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits urged the Johnson Administration today to stop all bombing of North Vietnam and to call for a cease-fire in an effort to break what he called a "double stalemate" in the war and in the Paris negotiations.

" LOVERS," the pair of oneact plays by Brian Friel that opened last night at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, makes an admirer of the author feel a little like the father of a very bright kid who has brought home an all B-plus report card.

The First Western Financial Corporation, a deeply troubled Las Vegas, Nevada, savings and loan holding company, reported yesterday a loss of $3.95million for 1967, in contrast to a loss of $21.4-million in 1966.
The Board of Estimate initiated a move yesterday to double all metered water rates in the city. The increase would affect 188,891 water customers of the city.

AREA A -- White marlin are being caught off Barnegat and on a recent overnight trip the Fish Hawk took seven of these oceanic scrappers. So-called Jersey bonita, from 2 to 4 pounds, are also being taken from boats as are small bluefish.
Edward J. Bock, a 51-yearold executive who has spent 27 years with the Monsanto Company, was elected yesterday president and chief executive officer of the large chemical producer.

PRAGUE, July 25 -- The ruling Presidium of the Czechoslovak Communist party tonight removed from a high party post a general who had aroused the anger of the Soviet Union by demanding revisions in the Warsaw Pact, the East European military alliance.

The head of the commission investigating the student uprisings at Columbia University questioned yesterday whether it was not "rather naive" to have expected there would be no injuries when the police were called in to clear students out of occupied buildings.
The Ford Foundation gave $315,000 yesterday to the National Student Association to finance the increasing power of college students in educational reform.
Pan American World Airways reported yesterday that its earnings declined both in the second quarter and first half this year despite record revenues for both periods.
A Long Island housewife who came to the city to shop yesterday decided on the spur of the moment to telephone her husband for a luncheon date.

MOSCOW, July 25 -- Two members of the Soviet Union's ruling group, which was rumored to have left for a planned conference with the Czechoslovak leaders over their democratization effort, were still in Moscow today.
THE Dow - Jones industrial average has plumeted almost 25 points in the three trading days this week. But, to hear the analysts talk, it's not the mutual funds that are selling.

BOSTON, July 25 (AP) -- A survey of seven days of network television programs showed 84 killings in 85 1/2 hours of programing in prime evening hours and on Saturday morning, The Christian Science Monitor said today.

More than 100 brokerage houses in the United States have unwittingly become involved in the allegedly illegal distribution of a highly speculative Canadian mining stock that appreciated 1,650 per cent in 10 months.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 26 -- Truong Dinh Dzu, the peace candidate who ran second in the presidential election last year, was sentenced today to five years of hard labor for having urged the formation of a coalition government as a step toward peace.

The effort of the Association of the Bar to get the four legal parties to agree to nonpartisan screening of their prospective judicial candidates for election is a praiseworthy attempt to remedy the disgraceful failure of the Legislature to provide proper statutory machinery for this purpose. At best, however, it is a stop-gap solution.
Inventory building in anticipation of a possible steel strike on Aug. 1 helped a number of large and small steel producers register good gains in the second quarter and first half of year.
The North American Rockwell Corporation and the Martin Marietta Corporation, both diversified aircraft producers, made more money in the June quarter this year than in the comparable 1967 period.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- About 100 Negro youths invaded an open supermarket on Chicago's Near North Side tonight while about 1,000 other Negroes were gathered outside to protest the store's hiring policies.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The National Automobile Dealers Association protested today that its members and the car-buying public were being hurt by what it termed unfair competitive practices of automobile manufacturers.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., July 25 -- Nineteen-year old Bill Shulha, the only invited player in the 47th annual Long Island amateur golf championship, made himself feel right at home today by taking medal honors with a one-under-par 69.
The Federal Reserve is continuing subtly to relax the pressure that it has been applying to the money market.

The Ogden Corporation took another step in the development of its transportation complex yesterday when it announced the acquisition of Bulk Transport, Inc., which has been owned and operated by Oriental Exporters, Inc.

LONDON, July 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Mary Chapot, a star of the United States Olympic Equestrian team, won the Queen Elizabeth II trophy today at the Royal International Horse Show at Wembley. It is one of the most coveted trophies in the world.

PARIS, July 25 -- The impression is growing among American officials and allied diplomats that any significant breakthrough on scaling down the Vietnam war is unlikely before the Democratic party convention in late August.

LANSING, Mich., July 26 -- Gov. George Romney of Michigan said today that the three leading candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination had failed to arouse either his enthusiasm or that of the public.
Albert Shanker, head of the United Federation of Teachers and leader of a 14-day strike in New York City's schools last autumn, is facing the threat of a strike by some of his own union's employes.

A hand grenade exploded in the Greenwich Village offices of the Grove Press early yesterday. The police said it was apparently a retaliatory stroke by Cuban exiles for the publication of excerpts from the diary of Che Guevara in the current issue of Grove's monthly magazine, Evergreen Review.

MIAMI, July 26 (AP) -- The executive director of the Florida Land Sales Board gave Gulf American Corporation temporary authority today to put 8,000 new acres on the market, but the board said he had acted without its approval.

I must take issue with Henry Tanner's inference in the July 7 week in Review "Now de Gaulle's Real Job Begins" that Frenchmen disapproved of de Gaulle's rapprochement with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Legislation aimed at reducing the average investor's cost of buying and owning mutual-fund shares was approved by the Senate today.

Mayor Lindsay stepped out of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Health Center in Brooklyn shortly after 5 P.M. yesterday and with a wave extended an invitation to a city health official: "C'mon Jim, I'll show you the neighborhood."

TORONTO, July 26 -- With the Canadian dollar riding high, the Bank of Canada has been pumping money into the economy to combat what looks like an incipient slowdown or leveling off of business expansion.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- President Johnson took two hours from his schedule today to give firsthand, personal briefings on foreign policy to two Presidential candidates -- George C. Wallace and Richard M. Nixon.

It is to be wondered whether exercises in Presidential exhortation -- asking business and organized labor to curb their appetites for higher prices and wages -- have any relevance or usefulness at a time when inflationary pressures are manifest.

LONDON, July 26 -- A witty collection of tips for visiting Anglican bishops on where to find free sherry and good carafe wine has attached controversy to the 1968 Lambeth Conference.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Saturday, July 27 (UPI) -- The American air base at Udron was raked by small-arms fire last night, a United States Embassy spokesman said today. The attack was believed to be the first against a United States basc in Thailand.

Varying degrees of approval have already been given by most of the leading candidates to the plan to assure election of the Presidential nominee who receives a plurality of the popular vote in November.

Mayor Lindsay's credibility was questioned last night and he was subjected to taunts, the mildest of which was "windbag."

The bond market rested yesterday from its exertions of the last couple of weeks and ended practically unchanged from Thursday's levels. "We've had three weeks in a row now of very impressive gains and after such a violent move it's not surprising that the market's a wee bit toppy and tired," said one trader of corporate bonds. Moreover, Fridays during the summer are most often very slow with little demand for fixed-income securities.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Democratic political figures and government officials took time out from their campaigns and jobs today to attend the funeral of Mrs. Margaret Price, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
CLEVELAND, July 26 -- A Black Nationalist figure was charged today with three counts of first degree murder in the gun battle that erupted on this city's East Side Tuesday night.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy announced in Boston today that it would be "impossible" for him to run for Vice President this year.

William H. Booth, chairman of the city Commission on Human Rights, informed the National Organization for Women yesterday that he intended to schedule a hearing shortly on the organization's complaint of discrimination through segregation by sex of newspaper employment advertising.

YONKERS, July 26 -- Rival-time, a pacer once partly-owned by Wilt Chamberlain, discounted the disadvantage of the No. 8 post, went to the top early and proceeded to win the M.Y.R. (Monticello, Yonkers, Roosevelt) one-mile race at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

WATERLOO VILLAGE, N. J., -- Herb fanciers who grow their own confess to being a little bit of everything: part gardener, part cook, a little bit of witch, part storyteller, a touch of historian, puzzle-maker, botanist and sentimentalist.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 26 -- Joseph William Koontz, a 23-year-old blond with blue eyes, has startled the training camp of the New York Giants by catching almost every pass thrown his way during the first week of practice.
Mayor Lindsay is expected to authorize an increase in the size of the Fire Department by at least 500 men within the next few days.

Antonio (Tony Ducks) Corallo, a reputed Mafia chieftain, was sentenced yesterday to three years in prison for conspiring to bribe James L. Marcus, the former Water Commissioner, in "a broad-gauged plan to corrupt those in public service."
Ohio medical scientists have discovered that at least some of the Indians of yesteryear were not so hale and hearty as legend would have it.

CLEVELAND, July 26 -- Negro residents of the East Side and helmeted policemen stood beneath shade trees with brown, fire-scorched leaves today and watched a yellow bullodzer flatten what had been the home of the Rev. and Mrs. Henry L. Perryman.
The United States is completing secret studies on arms control to prepare for talks with the Soviet Union on curbing the nuclear missile race.
Two recent events point up the serious mishandling by the city administration of civil disorders and their resultant adverse effects upon civil rights.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- At age 10, Betty Galloway is getting a patent on her bathtub toy, an efficient producer and - launcher of bubbles. So far as Patent Of fice officials recall, she is the youngest girl to be awarded a patent. Betty lives in Georgetown, near the South Carolina coast.

The ebullience of normal life in the streets returned yesterday to a Lower East Side neighborhood. Residents attributed it -- and the calm of the night before -- to the withdrawal of the police Tactical Patrol Force.

MALCOLM BOYD'S BOOK OF DAYS. By Malcolm Boyd. 215 pp. New York: Random House. $4.95. LOVE, LOVE AT THE END. Parables, Prayers and Meditations. By Daniel Berrigan, S.J. 118 pp. New York: The Macmillan Company. $4.95.

LIGHT lovers! Watt worshippers! Devotees of "current" art! You can now ditch your comfortable canard that the low-voltage Whitney Museum isn't really plugged in. With such a patron as RCA picking up part of the tab, the museum has just switched on "Light: Object and Image," a show of work by seven artists more or less struck by light.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 27 -- Crews of 107 one-design racing sloops enjoyed one of the better sailing days of the season on Long Island Sound today when the Echo Bay Yacht Club staged the first half of its 58th annual regatta. It will be concluded tomorrow.

PITTSBURGH, July 27 (UPI) -- The chief negotiators for 11 major steel companies and the United Steelworkers of America said today they had failed to reach a "basis for settlement" of their wage contract dispute covering 400,000 steel workers in the United States and Canada.

IF YOU happen to be in East Hampton before Aug. 11, you can go to Guild Hall there and see a pleasant collection of American prints dating from 1670 to this year, but don't let your heart break if you miss it.

WASHINGTON, July 27, (AP) -- President Johnson signed a bill yesterday that was designed to clarify and strengthen a law barring foreign ships from fishing activities in United States territorial waters and a contiguous 9-mile fishery zone.

PRAGUE -- Czechoslovaks say that not since the days of their nation's founder, Thomas G. Masaryk, half a century ago has one man represented a Czechoslovakia as united as Alexander Dubcek does today. For the leaders of a Communist party, which has never won a free election in any country, this is a unique accomplishment.

ATHENS, July 27 -- The General Assembly of the Greek Orthodox Church of America appealed today to Hanoi, Peking and Moscow to find a way at the Paris talks to end the war in Vietnam. It gave its full backing to President Johnson's attempt to seek a "just and equitable" solution.

Out on Eighth Avenue, the big marquee is a skeleton. Around on 49th Street, the high vertical maroon marquee with "Madison Sq. Garden" on it curls next to an old fire escape. On the sidewalk, a plywood fence surrounds the abandoned building, dirty and depressing to anyone who remembers it aglow.
LONDON -- Americans of German background can be Lutheran without knowing German. Most Roman Catholics have no connection with Italian language or culture.
SCRANTON, Pa. July 27 -- Artemus of Province was best in show today at the Lackawanna Kennel Club's 39th annual show in a field of 709 entries.

I thoroughly appreciated the most enlightening graphic account about Kennedy Airport's international arrivals. The treatment given to completely fagged travelers at the end of a long international flight causes similar reactions in me, and, I feel sure, many thousands more.

PUERTO RICO is one of the leading vacation centers in the Caribbean and, as such, it has had to handle an ever-increasing volume of air traffic. In the fiscal year that ended this June, 4,000,000 passengers used San Juan International Airport, an increase of 500,000 over last year.

POINT O'WOODS, Fire Island, L. I. --It's been called a "Brooklyn Southampton," a "WASP kibbutz," and "the world's most restricted summer community." But to the 1,000 persons who summer here, Point O' Woods is a little bit of heaven, and their goal is keeping it that way -- even if it means building a fence to keep others out, which they have.

MY argument goes like this: young playwrights as a rule do not need grants or subsidies from foundations. They can use them certainly -- who can't? -- but they don't really need them. Middle-aged and older professional playwrights -- most of them -- do need help desperately, if they're going to take off the year or two necessary to bring forth a reasonably respectable play, with all the sturm und drang inevitable in that process.

KANSAS CITY, July 27 -- A state-wide industrial development finance corporation, the first of its kind in Missouri, has been formed to provide private investment capital for "new industry and for expansion of existing plants which cannot get funds elsewhere," according to Adrian Harmon, chairman of the Missouri Bankers Association's committee on long-term financing for industrial expansion.
The perils of writing caustic editorials without knowing the facts is illustrated in your editorial comments [July 21] on House rejection of the Wild Rivers bill.
INTRODUCTION of direct Aeroflot and Pan American World Airways service from New York to Moscow gives travelers bound for Asia a wider choice of routes and saves them mileage.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 27 -- Windigo II, a 73-foot gold-plater owned by Walter S. Gubelmann of Oyster Bay, L. I., scampered round the course with all the alacrity of a running deer to gain the Queen's Cup in today's New York Yacht Club cruise sailing.
IT'S not just Mexico City where an Olympiad is being played this summer. Would you believe Miami Beach? Chicago?

When Congress raised income taxes by ten per cent, it also instructed the President to submit proposals for the comprehensive reform of the tax system during this calendar year. There have been no efforts to institute tax reforms since President Kennedy's ill-fated measures of 1962. The Johnson Administration, taking its cue from the cynic who aptly remarked that "One man's tax loophole is another's divine right," has fastidiously avoided the reform issue.
The New York Mets, the youngest team in baseball, paid due respect to their elders last night on Old-Timers Day, then knocked off the Cincinnati Reds, 5-2.

Professional football turns from talk to action this week. The preseason schedule begins in both leagues, National and American; a new scoring rule will be tried out for the first time, and seven stars of the past will be inducted into pro football's Hall of Fame at Canton, Ohio.
UNLESS PEACE COMES. A Scientific Forecast of New Weapons. Edited by Nigel Calder. 243 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $5.75.

WHEN Ben Kerner's mother heard about Lou Hudson, she was furious. She had watched her son, the basketball promoter, prosper from modest beginnings in Moline, through troubles in Milwaukee to jackpot success in St. Louis. She rooted for his teams, chatted with his friends, and paid just as much attention to his business as one would expect from a lively, elderly lady who is one of the countless real - life counterparts of Molly Goldberg.

Trustees of a synagogue were turning a littered backyard into a vest-pocket park. Merchants were putting up funds for improved street lighting. A young cultural group was planning a series of playlets and art exhibits.
GRANDMASTER Bobby Fischer of New York, the United States chess champion, overwhelmed a 14-man round robin during the recent Seventh Israel International at Natanya.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 27 -- Ruth S. Cohen, a 10-year-old figure-skater of Woodmere, L. I., won her third consecutive title today at the 12th annual Lake Placid free-skating championships at the Olympic Arena.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Hubert Humphrey suffered a couple of hard knocks in his quest for the Presidency in a week that saw Lyndon Johnson, at Honolulu and Cincinnati, take a stiff position on peace negotiations, and Ted Kennedy, at Boston, take an even stiffer position against running for Vice President.
NOBODY LOVES A COCKROACH. By Bill Ballantine. Rhymes by Charlotte Russell. Illustrated by Toby Ballantine. 340 pp. Boston: Little, Brown Co. $7.95.
Prices declined sharply in active trading on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market last week.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., July 27 -- A young Negro shed a pair of wide, dark sunglasses reluctantly this week during a public speaking course at the State University Agricultural and Technical College.

WASHINGTON -- "The public interest is clearly violated by . . . any wage settlements that extend the recent disturbing pattern." -- President Johnson's Cabinet committee on price stability in a statement last week.

In the face of rising workloads, the city's Fire Department has expanded a new rotation system to relieve heavily burdened fire companies.
A husky Negro with a drooping mustache sat in a hot little apartment in Harlem a few days ago and talked to a 19-year-old boy with asthma, no job and an occasional taste for heroin.

ATHENS, July 27 -- Three leading Greek political prisoners, held without trial by the country's army-backed regime have initiated a test case by petitioning the chief prosecutor of the Greek Supreme Court to end their "illegal detention."

MANHASSET, L.I., July 28 -- Like mellowed wine, Tony Vincent is still an old smoothie. The New York stockbroker, a former internationalist, played almost errorless tennis today as he won the national clay-court championship for men 35 years and over for the fifth time at the Shelter Rock Club.

The Memorex Corporation, makers of precision magnetic tape, has agreed in principle to buy the photographic products business of Technicolor, Inc., the color-film processor, through an exchange of shares.
Customs collections during the fiscal year that ends tomorrow soared to a record $2.9-billion dollars, according to a report issued by Lester D. Johnson, Commissioner of Customs.

LENOX, Mass., July 28 -- If nothing else, the Tanglewood programs of the Berkshire Music Festival had variety over the weekend. This afternoon's program, conducted by Josef Krips, was strictly bread - and - butter, with Beethoven's "Pastoral" Symphony, Strauss's "Don Juan" and Stravinsky's "Firebird" Suite.

BETHANY, Conn., July 28 -- Ch. Shalfleet Starlight of Foxden, a 4-year-old gray brindle greyhound owned by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Farrell Jr. of Darien, won her eighth best in show today at the 50th Elm City Kennel Club all-breed dog show and obedience trial at the Bethway Stables and Kennel Club grounds.
The big jet airliner from London, rushing toward its final approach to Kennedy International Airport here at more than 200 miles an hour, lost radio contact with the ground.

ROME, July 28 -- The most drastic measure to keep Rome from strangling on its wheeled traffic since Julius Caesar banned all chariots from the city in daylight hours will go into effect Thursday, the first of the month.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 28 -- Lieut. Arthur Ashe of Richmond spoiled Marty Riessen's farewell to amateur tennis today by winning the men's singles title in the 69th annual Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship.

Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, said yesterday that if airlines did not reschedule flights to relieve congestion the Federal Government should force the changes.

MIAMI BEACH, July 28 -- Richard M. Nixon's search for an ideal running mate now involves three parallel tests of public and political opinion.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 28 -- United States aircraft losses have increased in the last few days and military spokesmen cannot explain why.

Not every old New York movie palace is condemned to die to make way for a glass-and-steel monolith. Nor must it fade away into the sad anonymity reserved for theaters that play last-run commercial films or first-run sex movies.

HUE, South Vietnam, July 28 -- Premier Tran Van Huong reopened the main highway bridge in Hue today. He said that he was "very ashamed" that the Vietcong had been able to blow it up during the Lunar New Year offensive.
A 16-story apartment house at 309 West 57th Street, just west of Eighth Avenue, has been bought by Zohar Ben-Dov, a real estate investor, for cash over mortgages totaling $1,075,000.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., July 28 -- Duane Hayden, who daily keeps in trim by running over an old training track near his home designed for steeplechase horses, ran away with the Long Island amateur golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Western diplomats believe that a seeming concession by Czechoslovak reformers to their Soviet critics last week has actually alarmed, rather than placated, the Kremlin on the eve of the two leaderships' meeting.

LOS ANGELES, July 28 -- Vice President Humphrey vowed today that he would continue to campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination in crowds and public places, particularly in Negro communities, in spite of any possible risk to his safety.

MIAMI BEACH, July 28 -- A secret head count made for Governor Rockefeller of New York's 92 delegates to the Republican National Convention shows that Richard M. Nixon has substantial potential strength in the delegation.
LONDON, July 28 (UPI) -- Britain's second heart transplant patient died tonight. Gordon Forde, 48 years old, never regained consciousness following a three-hour operation on Friday.
Those who used to live in Jamaica, Queens, or who passed through on buses or commuter trains, would be surprised at changes in the city's third largest shopping area.

It seems to me that the July 22 letter of Donald Moss fails to reach the depth of what was happening in the harassment of Mr. Justice Fortas. Of course, dignity and demeanor have ". . . fled the hall of the Senate."

BUDAPEST, July 28 -- A Czechoslovak tourist coach pulled up at the baroque St. Stephen's Basilica today, and 40 or 50 passengers got off and mingled with the sightseers from Austria, West Germany and other Western European nations.

The Rev. Milton A. Galamison, who was sworn in last Wednesday as a member of the Board of Education, predicted yesterday that schools would be "chaotic" in the coming year unless the board decentralized the city school system.
AVIGNON, July 28 -- The Living Theater, which has been in self-imposed exile for the last few years, tonight canceled its remaining 16 performances at the Avignon Festival.

EAST FARMINGDALE, L. I., July 28 -- Eight persons, including a Long Island couple and two granddaughters, were killed tonight when two light aircraft collided over this Suffolk County community and crashed in flames.
Maritime Overseas Corporation has placed an order for two 61,440-ton tankers with Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

PRAGUE, July 28 -- Members of the Presidium of the Czechoslovak Communist party, accompanied by President Ludvik Svoboda, arrived tonight in the Slovak city of Kosice on their way to their fateful meeting with Soviet leaders concerning the future course of Czechoslovakia.
The stockholdings of Jules Caesar Stein in his MCA, Inc., were worth $102,112,447.75 at Friday's closing price on the New York Stock Exchange.

New orders for machine tools, an important economic indicator, rose in June by 9.9 per cent from the May level, but were down 8.7 per cent from the June, 1967, level, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported over the weekend.

CAPTREE STATE PARK, L. I., July 28 -- A Coast Guard helicopter dropped two pumps to a boat with 49 person's aboard that was foundering at sea today off Fire Island, and the boat was able to return safely to port.
Two West Coast charter airlines reported happily last week on their experience with the king-sized versions of the DC-8 jet transport.
The next time Perlman's Shell Service in Troy has a job for a part-time service man, it will consider hiring a woman.
TWO distinct winning methods are illuminated in the following games from the current United States Championship at the Empire Hotel.

CLEVELAND, July 28 -- The center-field scoreboard in Municipal Stadium exploded with a fireworks display five times today as the Cleveland Indians made use of the home run -- an unusual weapon for them -- and tight pitching to sweep a double-header from the New York Yankees, 3-2 and 4-1.
After struggling for more than a week, a House-Senate conference committee has produced a "compromise" Federal highway bill which is intolerably bad.

LANGHORNE, Pa., July 28 -- With two miles to go, a bracket on the auxiliary tank of Al Unser's Lola-Ford broke, causing the tank to drag along the track surface. The tank ruptured, spilling fuel, and Unser barely made it to victory.

Sales of the country's leading chain-store organizations rose by 9.3 per cent in June over June, 1967, a survey by The New York Times indicated yesterday. While this was the 85th month in succession that sales advanced over the year before, the showing represented a drop from the May performance.

PARIS, July 28 -- The French Government is in the process of preparing basic educational reforms, which are intended to satisfy some of President de Gaulle's bitterest enemies and to displease some of his staunchest followers.

I have read with great concern the proclamation made by Pope Paul VI at the Vatican on July 22, and have also noted with equal grief the role which the Pope has secretly played through the Roman Catholic charitable agency Caritas when he said "We have hired planes and we have tried to do what we could with difficulty, risks and much expense" to send aid in food and medicine to the rebels in Biafra.

JERUSALEM, July 28 -- In the last 10 days, the Israeli Defense Minister, Maj. Gen. Moshe Dayan, has made two trips to the occupied area on the west bank of the Jordan River and the Gaza Strip that have disclosed a great deal about current Israeli thinking toward the future of those areas.
Less than four years after the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge was dedicated, scores of steel and concrete workers have returned to build access roads and ramps for the bridge's hitherto unused lower tier.

LOS ANGELES, July 28 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan said today that Negro militants who silenced Vice President Humphrey here last night were "monsters" with a "disquieting similarity" to members of the Hitler Youth who disrupted public discussion in Nazi Germany.

BALTIMORE, July 28 -- The next time the Tigers and the Orioles see each other, it will be the weekend before Labor Day and the shadows will fall a little earlier. Then it may be time for pennant excitement.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he had no intention of starting a fight over the provisions of the 1968 Republican platform.

The most promising aspect of the proposal to establish community development corporations and development banks in the urban slums is the support it has received, cutting across both political and racial lines.
LONDON, July 28 -- When European bankers talked last week of currencies under pressure and worsening trade gaps, they were more likely to be discussing France than Britain.
AROUND and around the track she goes -- a tiny woman who looks as fragile as a piece of porcelain. When she stops, the other joggers breathe a sigh of relief.

Stanley Kunitz will receive the 1968 Fellowship of the Academy of American Poets today, his 63d birthday.
The present furor over cancellations of automobile, property and burglary insurance tends to overlook another security blanket that may be whisked away by insurers: group health protection plans.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 28 -- Bolivia's political future appeared uncertain today as various centers of power planned strategy in reaction to the naming of a military Cabinet last night.
LONDON, July 28 (AP) -- Bill Steinkraus, 41-year-old United States team captain, won the final event tonight at the Royal International Horse Show at Wembley Stadium.

Your July 3 editorial on the Catholic Church's re-examination of the Galileo case would have been more convincing were your own record unsullied in the field of academic freedom. From out of nowhere, Sullivan, Stauffer, Colwell Bayles has suddenly moved into second place among agencies with the most executive vice presidents. Time magazine reports that Pope Paul VI has given an unequivocal "no" to the practice of birth control by Roman Catholics. The weekly news magazine, in its issue of Aug. 2, quotes what it describes as an unofficial translation of a 34-page encyclical scheduled to be issued today in Rome.

FREEHOLD, N. J., July 28 -- Freehold Raceway, owned by the Southern Maryland Agricultural Association of Prince George's County, Md., never has had a single day's $1-million mutuel handle. The closest was the $983,733 poured into the machines here last Aug. 12.

Although "it's always New York City guidebook time," according to Robert Ritz of Brentano's Fifth Avenue store, the salespeople of the nearby Scribner's store say that this is the peak sales season for such books.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 28 -- A team of local experts jumped into the lead after the first session of the Master Mixed Team Championship at the Leamington Hotel here today.
MOSCOW, July 28 -- "Time is running out," the Soviet Union warned today in a sharp attack on the Czechoslovak reformers that presaged a grim mood for the imminent showdown discussions.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 8 -- What was to be a decisive meeting tomorrow on the draft charter of the proposed Andean Group is getting started with considerable indecision on whether the six-member common market is to be or not to be.
The jet age apparently has made respectable the renting of hotel rooms by the hour.

Grandmaster Larry Evans of New York, a former United States champion, moved into undisputed first place at the end of the ninth round in the United States Chess Championship yesterday. He defeated Herbert Seidman of New York, a former Marshall Club champion, at the Empire Hotel, bringing his score to 7 victories out of 9.

Cast changes of notable interest marked the close of the American Ballet Theater's highly successful season at the Metropolitan Opera House over the weekend. But it is perhaps a repeat performance that should be mentioned first.

Local councils of churches across the nation have been investing money and manpower this summer to help avert civic unrest, according to a survey made by the Association of Council Secretaries Journal.

ELMIRA, N. Y., July 28 -- Paul O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, today rejected a compromise position on Vietnam reached by Utah supporters of Vice President Humphrey and Senator Eugene J. McCarthy.
PITTSBURGH, July 28 -- If there is a peaceful steel labor settlement, it will take users 10 months to work off excess inventory.

ST. PAUL, July 28 (AP) -- Dan Sikes charged from four strokes back with a 30 on the first nine today, shot a seven-under-par 64 and won the $20,000 first-place money in the Minnesota Golf Classic by one stroke from Ken Still.

A smoky blaze in the Time-Life Building yesterday afternoon routed patrons of the Tower Suite and La Fonda del Sol restaurants and the staff of Sports Illustrated magazine, who were working to meet their Sunday deadline.
ADEN, Southern Yemen, July 28 -- Dissident tribesmen supported by Saudi Arabia have revolted against the Government of this former British protectorate, the Government said today.
SAN JUAN, P.R., July 28 -- The Very Rev. Terence J. Cooke, Archbishop of New York, arrived yesterday for a week's stay in Puerto Rico, the homeland of about one-third of his parishioners in New York.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 28 -- Once more, for a month -- as it has almost continually since 1863 -- this community will become the capital of the thoroughbred horse-racing realm on this continent. Beginning tomorrow, and continuing for 23 racing days subsequent, the New York Racing Association will conduct the famous meeting that is the traditional "break" in this state.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 28 -- A state of emergency and a curfew were kept in force in Grand Rapids today in an effort to halt racial disturbances that have hit the city for the past two nights.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff is one of the most popular politicians ever to have come out of Connecticut.

ATLANTA, July 28 -- An official report prepared secretly by the State Sovereignty Commission has disclosed details of a four-year campaign by the commission to harass and discredit the civil rights movement in Mississippi.

A former stock broker-dealer was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on fraud charges asserting that 25 of his customers lost $75,000 because he allegedly failed to carry out their orders.

The National Committee on Employment of Youth said yesterday that a nationwide survey showed that business and Government had failed to meet their goals of providing enough summer jobs for the nation's youth.

The National Gallery of Art announced plans yesterday to construct a large building adjacent to its classical landmark on Constitution Avenue, on one of Washington's most important sites, the junction of Pennsylvania Avenue and the Mall.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 29 -- A spokesman of the Popular Front For the Liberation of Palestine, told foreign newsmen here today that the 12 Israelis still held prisoner in Algeria were exchangeable for Palestine Arabs held prisoner in Israel.

PARIS, July 29 -- A North Vietnamese spokesman contended today that recent actions by the South Vietnamese Government against its domestic political critics showed that the regime had panicked in the face of peace sentiment in Saigon.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that the preliminary results of his state-by-state national poll indicated that Richard M. Nixon would have trouble defeating Vice President Humphrey in the November elections.
The city's 11th television station and the second to broadcast in Spanish will make its debut on Sunday at 4 P. M.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- Exemption of the Post Office Department from the Federal manpower cutback was advanced another step by the House today over objections that the Administration was blackmailing the public and the Congress.

Magnuson, chairman of the Senate Committee on Commerce.
CLEVELAND, July 29 -- As Mayor Carl B. Stokes and Joseph McManamon, Public Safety Director, met at City Hall with the police today, somebody was scribbling with a pencil on a corridor wall.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 29 -- Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson ordered all county departments today to halt the hiring of personnel and the purchasing of new equipment because increasing welfare costs, largely attributed to the Medicaid program, had caused a budget deficit.

ROME, July 29 -- Five years of uncertainty over how the Roman Catholic Church would view modern methods of birth control ended today with the official presentation of a papal encyclical letter that upheld the prohibition on all artificial means of contraception.

MARION, Mass., July 29 -- Bolero, a 73-foot yawl chartered by Robert S. Robe Jr., made the most of a sparkling, windy day on Buzzards Bay today to gain the Astor Cup, one of the traditional prizes of the New York Yacht Club cruise. Bolero has made a career of winning the cup. This was her fifth victory over a 19-year span.

EAST FARMINGDALE, L. I., July 29 -- Federal investigators said today that a change in landing instructions preceded the mid-air collision of two light planes here last night in which eight persons were killed.

MIAMI BEACH, July 29 -- Elated supporters of Richard M. Nixon declared today there were "in excess of 700 delegates ready to vote for his nomination" at the Republican National Convention here next week.
Supreme Court Justice Peter T. Farrell denied the motion of Mrs. Alice Crimmins for a new trial yesterday, and set Aug. 9 for her sentencing.

Construction contracts in June declined to $5,589,481,000 from $6,170,471,000 in May but still remained slightly higher than the year-earlier level, it was reported yesterday by the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill, Inc., the business publisher.

FOR more than half a century, trout and salmon flies dressed (fashioned) with fur or fur fibers have become increasingly scarce. Reliance has been placed on feathers, wool or synthetic materials.

PITTSBURGH, July 29 -- Members of the United Steelworkers of America received a hopeful report on contract negotiations from the union's high command today, less than 60 hours short of a strike deadline.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 29 -- Residents of this resort area can bolster their art collections next weekend without gallery hopping. The works of 18 artists will be for sale at the annual exhibition a, St. John's Episcopal Church on South Main Street.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J. July 29 -- Clark Graebner of New York and Charlie Pasarell of Puerto Rico, the Davis Cup players, scored victories in contrasting form today as the 42d annual Eastern grass-court tennis championships opened at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

BOB GIBSON, who will pitch against the New York Mets in Shea Stadium tonight, is a victim of discrimination, the latest in a long line of worthy men subject to a peculiarly stubborn and unchangeable bias. This particular discrimination has nothing to do with skin color, ethnic origin, social class or system of beliefs.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 29 -- Gen. Alfredo Ovando Candia, commander of Bolivia's armed forces, said today that he understood that the new military Cabinet probably would be replaced in 20 days by civilian ministers.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass. -- If Ray Caldwell wanted to manufacture golf-club shafts, vaulters' poles or plumbing fixtures he could perhaps, given his talents, be as prosperous as A. J. Foyt. He says there are many ways to make money, but: "We want to remain racing-car company.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the United States would not curtail the bombing of North Vietnam further until Hanoi went on record with a commitment to reduce its war effort.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., July 30 -- The favorites advanced with more difficulty in the second round of the Eastern grass-court tennis championship today.
MEMPHIS, July 30 (AP) -- Strict new guidelines enjoining "interviews or press conferences for publicity" were handed down today by the judge who will preside at the murder trial of James Earl Ray.

The party that mattered socially at the Republican National Convention in Miami Beach has been canceled -- called off at almost the last minute because of what one of the elegant hostesses called "these troubled times."
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The cigarette smoker whose occupation exposes him to dust, gas or fumes has a heightened risk of the lung disease emphysema, a survey by the American Cancer Society shows.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Final budget results for the fiscal year 1968, ended a month ago, showed a deficit of $25.4-billion, much the largest since World War II, the Treasury and the Budget Bureau reported today.
PITTSBURGH, July 30 -- The steel industry and the United Steelworkers agreed today to a new three-year contract raising wages at least 44 cents an hour and improving fringe benefits.

New York University, which has been striving to extend its services to the Negro community, has been caught in a most unfortunate cross-fire over its hiring of a militant Negro minister-teacher as director of its new Martin Luther King Jr. Afro-American Student Center.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 30 -- The United States command announced tonight that the military accreditation of John S. Carroll, correspondent of The Baltimore Sun, would be lifted for 60 days instead of six months, as ordered last Saturday.

DENVER, July 30 (AP) -- Management of The Denver Post was accused of improper use of Denver Post, Inc., funds in a Federal Court suit filed yesterday by The Herald Company of New York, a Samuel I. Newhouse newspaper property.

WARSAW, July 30 -- Informed sources said today that the Soviet Army had concentrated combat units in Poland capable of armed intervention in Czechoslovakia and that the Soviet troop movements in the last three days had assumed dimensions in excess of a simple show of force.

In the current crisis over Czechoslovakia, the Soviet demonstrations of military power are not solely intended to make the Dubcek regime more compliant to Moscow's wishes. If this were the only goal, the Soviet Union could have more conveniently used for this purpose its "maneuvering" troops within Czechoslovakia, rather than withdrawing them and resorting to the costly and potentially much more explosive war games along the U.S.S.R.'s western frontier.
LEE, Mass., July 30 -- Norman Walker and Company, along with Nala Najan, opened the sixth week of the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival with a program of dances from the East and West.

More than 70,000 New Yorkers converged on the Sheep Meadow in Central Park last night to demonstrate in behalf of a slate of candidates that included Hector Berlioz, Richard Strauss, Igor Stravinsky and a favorite son, William Schuman.

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., July 30 -- Pam Carmichael, who makes a habit of it these days, scored a double at the Orange County Fair horse show tonight. She rode Lansonette to the large junior working hunter championship and Chance Step to the small junior working hunter title.

PEORIA, Ill., July 30 (AP) -- Mayor Robert J. Lehnhausen declared a 9 P.M. curfew tonight for persons under 21 after 10 policemen and a reporter were wounded by gunfire in a predominantly Negro neighborhood.
HIRAM, Ohio, July 30 -- It has taken the Cleveland Browns three years to eliminate the cliques, the cults and the conflicts that Jim Brown left as his mark on this football team.

Your July 9 editorial "To Right a Wrong" relating to the recent Democratic State Committee meeting, and alleging a "daylight robbery," results in what I am sure is an unintended insult to our black and Puerto Rican communities.
Silver futures recovered a little yesterday from a decline in commodity trading Monday, but the spot price for silver, as quoted by Handy Harman, fell by 5 cents an ounce to $2.21.
The stock market barely managed to hold its own yesterday as advances outnumbered declines by a slight margin in the slowest trading in months.

Grandmaster Larry Evans of New York maintained first place in the United States Chess Championship when he adjourned his game with Dr. Anthony Saidy of Los Angeles at the end of the semi-final tenth round at the Empire Hotel here Monday night.

BALTIMORE, July 30 -- In a game that will be the last for some, many of the New York Jet rookies did not distinguish themselves tonight as the Baltimore Colt rookies produced a 27-14 victory before 26,488 spectators at Memorial Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- For large numbers of people, the endearing qualities in Hubert H. Humphrey are his exuberance, his expansiveness, his unbounded, unflagging, uncritical optimism. The impossible is well in hand. The delectable mountains are not at the horizon but just across the street and scalable.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- The Senate paid final tribute today to Senator Robert F. Kennedy, with eulogies that transcended party lines and erased old political enmities.

In a lease calling for more than $2.5-million in rent, the National Association of Accountants has signed up for the entire 23d floor of a new office building going up at 919 Third Avenue.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk urged both sides in the Nigerian civil war today to show the utmost restraint in their military operations.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., July 30 -- "You take the average wife," 50-year-old Tom De Caro said here this morning, leisurely unfolding his Morning Telegraph on a poolside table at Price's Motel. "They'll say, 'Ooh, your husband plays the horses?' They think of you as some kind of nut, a shady character, a guy that's really down and out.
DETROIT, July 30 -- Twenty-two seconds is not the fastest anybody ever ran around the bases, but for a pitcher with a strained knee it's not bad.

MIAMI BEACH, July 30 -- Mayor Lindsay arrived here today with what his advisers call a "one-in-a-million" strategy to win the Republican Presidential nomination if the party's national convention becomes deadlocked.

WHEN Howard Regis Leary was appointed two and a half years ago commander of the largest municipal police department in the world, many of "New York's finest" were frankly skeptical that any outsider could ever master the Byzantine operations and politics of the New York Police Department.
LAIKHE, South Vietnam, July 29 -- The tanks crawl past the rubber trees in the jungles around this base camp, churning up mud and lurching into rice paddies that are murky and deep.

KOSICE, Czechoslovakia, July 30 -- After a long day of discussion with their Czechoslovak counterparts, the leaders of the Soviet Union were reported to have stamped out of the two-story Junction Club in Cierna at 10:30 last night and boarded their train.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 30 -- The attendance pattern at the Saratoga race track today was more formful than that of the competition.
" FUTZ!' is the regular tenant at the Actors Playhouse. But every Monday night a very different kind of play comes to call. And it is a charmer.

MIAMI BEACH, July 29 -- Harold E. Stassen claimed today more votes for the Republican presidential nomination than anyone else was willing to credit him with. Furthermore, he offered to bet a good steak dinner that his estimate of delegate strength was better than that of skeptical newsmen.

MIAMI BEACH, July 30 -- The same Gallup Poll that dimmed Governor Rockefeller's Presidential hopes yesterday turned out today to show him leading both major Democratic candidates in all the area outside the South.
GENEVA, July 30 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council called today for international action to put an end to the damage man causes to the world around him.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Senate voted today to exempt the Post Office Department from the mandatory manpower cutback.

LONDON, July 30--It was natural, I think, that an age that could adopt so firmly Antonin Artaud's phrase "the theater of cruelty" should find itself more attuned to the Roman tragedies of Seneca than to the Greek tragedies of Sophocles.

SDE BOKER, Israel -- David Ben-Gurion, Israel's first Premier, is now a gnomish old man living a simple life on this kibbutz in the baked Negev. His wife died last year and, solitary by choice, far from his children, he works, contemplates and reminisces.
Interest rates on new bond issues were lowered further yesterday despite the hesitation that has developed in the fixed-income securities market's advance this week.
A calm strategy for blunting the impact of Pope Paul's renewal of the ban on birth-control measures is evolving among progressive Roman Catholic theologians, priests and even a few bishops.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Air Transport Association said yesterday that it had chosen the Martin Marietta Corporation, Baltimore, to manage a joint airline-industry flight test and evaluation of collision avoidance devices.
Calvin Williams, operator of Brooklyn's largest fleet of unlicensed taxis, was indicted yesterday by a grand jury investigating the recent outbreaks of violence against licensed cabs.

Secretary of State Rusk has repeatedly denied any connection between his refusal to permit an official of the Seafarers International Union to be extradited to Canada and the union's subsequent contribution of $100,000 to Democratic party war chests. We have no reason to doubt the Secretary's denial. The case does, however, raise some issues which so far have received surprisingly little official attention since The Wall Street Journal first exposed the story.

IN a loft in Greenwich Village, part studio, part living quarters, a slender, quick-moving, sandy-haired man of 39 who looks and acts 10 years younger has spent part of the last few days packing his paintings for a one-man show at the Talisman Gallery in Falmouth, Mass. (The exhibition is to be by courtesy of the Rehn Gallery here, which is giving him a one-man show in September and October.)

Senator McCarthy's proposal that the United States delay deployment of new offensive and defensive strategic missiles pending "speedy agreement" on a mutual moratorium with the Soviet Union places the problem in proper perspective.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The X-15 rocket plane that crashed last Nov. 15 near Johannesburg, Calif., re-entered the earth's atmosphere on its side, went into a spin and broke apart about 12 miles above earth.
The Budd Company and the Gindy Manufacturing Corporation, a producer of truck trailers and containers, announced yesterday that Budd had agreed to acquire Gindy through a tax-free share exchange.
