The rhythm method of birth control, the only contraceptive technique held acceptable by the Roman Catholic Church, is reported to result in an average of about 20 pregnancies a year among every 100 women using it.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Some meats preserved by exposure to radiation may be unsafe for human consumption, two Food and Drug Administration officials told Congress today.

Schlumberger, Ltd., an international oil-field services and electronic instrumentation concern, announced last night in a surprise move a preliminary agreement to acquire the business properties and assets or J. Ray McDermott Co., Inc., engineers and builders of offshore drilling platforms and production facilities.

A collection of 70 Italian frescoes from Tuscan churches and monasteries, many accompanied by the preparatory drawings for them, will be brought here for a two-month exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art to begin in mid-September.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 30 -- More than 100,000 tons of tomatoes ripening rapidly on 200 New Jersey and Pennsylvania farms may have to be plowed under if the two-day strike against the Campbell Soup Company continues for a long period.
Vincent L. Broderick, the former Police Commissioner, urged Governor Rockefeller yesterday to call a special session of the Legislature to enact "effective gun control laws."

MIAMI, July 30 -- The Miami News said today that a Cuban security official told two of its reporters in Cuba that the Castro Government strongly disapproved of the hijackers who have been diverting planes to Cuba.

A sharp increase in fees for private planes landing or taking off in peak hours goes into effect today at Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark airports in an attempt to ease congestion by encouraging private planes to use smaller airports.
A shortage of seamen in skilled ratings is nearing the crisis stage and is delaying the departure of a number of freighters loaded with military cargo for South Vietnam.

The 20-story office and commercial building at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, across from the main branch of the New York Public Library, has been sold for more than $5-million to a group of investors.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Following is the official transcript of an impromptu news conference President Johnson held today in the Cabinet Room of the White House:
UTURU, Nigeria, July 30 -- An atmosphere of death and despair hangs over this hilltop Roman Catholic seminary in secessionist Biafra -- now an emergency hospital for more than 300 starving children.
The Most Rev. Terence J. Cooke, Archbishop of New York, affirmed support yesterday for Pope Paul's restatement of the ban against the use of artificial methods of birth control.
SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., July 31 -- When Patrick Devito says he is going to take you fishing he means it.

ROME, July 31--Pope Paul VI spoke today of his spiritual suffering during the preparation of his encyclical renewing the Roman Catholic prohibition on artificial means of contraception. He asked Christian spouses to understand it and find inspiration in it.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Antipoverty officials quietly abandoned today a program for two youth gangs that Senate witnesses said took Federal funds to buy firearms and marijuana.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -Home buyers and home owners bore the brunt of a sharp increase in consumer prices in June.

GENEVA, July 31 -- As many as 30 to 40 per cent of the children trapped in famine areas by Nigeria's civil war will die, a World Council of Churches doctor said today after his return from the stricken African nation.

MIAMI BEACH, July 31 -The final stage of Governor Rockefeller's campaign to win the Republican Presidential nomination began today with the establishment of a tactical organization that includes five former national party chairmen.
DETROIT, July 31 -- Dennis McLain moved one victory closer to taking his wife on a trip this October, pitching a four-hitter as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Washington Senators, 4-0, tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -Galo Plaza, Secretary General of the Organization of American States, warned today that a "crisis of confidence" was growing in Latin America over the United States' willingness to honor its commitments under the Alliance for Progress.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 31 -Two of the most famous players in the history of the game added one more national title to their large collections at the Hotel Leamington here last night. Oswald Jacoby of Dallas and Helen Sobel Smith of Detroit teamed with two other Dallas players, Jacoby's son Jim and Minda Brachman, to capture the Master Mixed Team Championship with a total of 37.54.

MIAMI BEACH, July 31 -- Following are excerpts from statements on crime and violence made today to the Committee on Resolutions by former Vice President Richard M. Nixon, Gov. Ronald Reagan of California and Mayor Lindsay:

CLEVELAND, July 31 -- The police, in reconstructing the shootings here eight days ago that led to 11 deaths, said today that the outbreak did not begin with the removal of an abandoned car, as they had reported earlier.
The body of a girl who was raped and thrown to her death down the airshaft of a Lower East Side tenement was identified yesterday as that of a 13-year old runaway from Vickery, Ohio.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., July 31 -- Jim Osborne, the mystery man of the United States Davis Cup team, served notice today that he was not "tagging along for the ride" to the challenge round in Australia.
MIAMI BEACH, July 31 -The first of the major Republican Presidential candidates came to the party's convention city today, insisting that he would not really become a candidate for another week.

Four local unions of food handlers and A. P. stores in metropolitan New York and New Jersey reached agreement yesterday on new contracts providing for package increases of $27 to $31 a week over a period for three years.
MEXICO CITY, July 31 (UPI) -- Mexico's student insurrection spread to two state capitals today and troops moved into the streets to quell the demonstrations, as they had earlier in Mexico City.

BOSTON, July 31 -- Manager Ralph Houk, who said he had come to dread ninth innings this year because the Yankees have lost so many games that way, found one to his liking tonight when the Yankees scored five runs in the last inning and defeated the Boston Red Sox, 7-3, at Fenway Park.
As a result of increasing head injuries, the Police Department announced yesterday the purchase of a new helmet that affords the policeman much more protection.

An organized drive by relief clients has thrown the city's welfare program into a state of crisis and near-chaos and may force reform in a system called "bankrupt" and "antiquated" by its administrators and "lawless" and 'self-defeating" by its critics.
KOSICE, Czechoslovakia, July 13 -- The postponement of the conclusion of talks between Czechoslovak and Soviet leaders at the frontier village of Cierna, 60 miles from here, came suddenly tonight.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 31 -- Police Chief Ralph C. Petrone was reinstated today after a Superior Court judge threw out his suspension on a charge that he falsified his application to become a policeman 25 years ago.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 31 -- Paul O'Dwyer, Democratic Senate candidate, said today that the sentencing of the peace candidate, Truong Dinh Dzu, to a five-year term of hard labor by the South Vietnamese Government "had seriously undermined the peace negotiations in Paris."

New bipartisan support has been given the plan to insure that the Presidential candidate winning a plurality of the popular vote would be elected by the House of Representatives if no candidate receives a majority of the votes in the Electoral College. Six leading Senators have now asked their fellow members of the upper house to endorse the proposal, originally put forward by Representatives Goodell of New York and Udall of Arizona.
LAKE FOREST, Ill., July 31 -- The St. Louis Cardinals were the professional football team cited in a recent article in Sports Illustrated as one burdened with a racial problem.

PARIS, July 31 -- North Vietnamese negotiators brusquely rejected today what they termed an "extremely absurd demand" voiced yesterday by Secretary of State Dean Rusk for authoritative word that Hanoi would exercise restraint if the United States stopped all the bombing of North Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, July 31--Presidents Tito of Yugoslavia and Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania are understood to have met in secret late last week to coordinate a political strategy aimed at deterring any Soviet military intervention in Czechoslovakia.

The name of Sherwood, Mills Smith, architectural firm of Stamford, Conn., has been changed to The SMS Partner-ship/Architects. The firm was founded in 1946 by Thorne Sherwood, Willis S. Mills and Lester W. Smith.
Two suspended Federal agents were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to use $20,000 in seized counterfeit bills to buy narcotics for resale on the illicit market.
PARIS, July 31 -- The French Government called today for international action to end the 14-month-old civil war in Nigeria on the basis of the right of self-determination.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -The Senate passed a $1.94-billion foreign aid authorization bill today after beating back attempts to restore part of the $1-billion slashed from President Johnson's original request. The vote was 46 to 28.
CHICAGO, July 31 -- With the Democratic National Convention scheduled to open here in 26 days, a prominent Chicago Negro said today that the city was on the brink of a racial "eruption."

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The nation's largest mutual-fund complex, Investors Diversified Services, endorsed today what the rest of the securities industry has been fighting -- an end to fixed sales commissions on stock-exchange transactions.

JERUSALEM, July 31 -- The Israel Festival, a month-long movable feast of music and dance, opened last night with a concert in the courtyard of the Citadel of David, in the former Jordanian sector of Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -President Johnson said today that the 5 per cent across-the-board steel price increase announced earlier in the day by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation would, if followed by the rest of the industry, have "dire economic consequences for our nation."
Huntington Hartford said yesterday he planned to revive Show magazine, probably in mid-December.

City officials, representatives of two firemen's unions and mediators met last night in an attempt to avert a slowdown by the firemen, scheduled for 8 A.M. today.

ALBANY, July 31 (AP) -Vessels plying the New York State canal system through June 30 carried 12.9 per cent more cargo tonnage than was transported during a similar period last year, the State Transportation Department said today.

The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange yesterday did not release any changes in insiders' holdings.

LOS ANGELES, July 31 (UPI) -- A bomb that damaged the British consulate here is believed to have been planted by three anti-Castro Cubans using an automobile with New Jersey license plates, the police reported today.

PARIS, July 31 -- The black winter coat, banished for the last six or seven years, comes out so often in the new Paris collections that after the first 40 of them, they all begin to blur before your eyes.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 31 (AP) -- Cynthia Potter of Houston gained an upset victory in the women's one-meter springboard diving and the PanAmerican champion, Bernie Wrightson, took the men's 3meter springboard diving event today at the opening of the 18th National Amateur Athletic Union swimming meet.
PRAGUE, July 31 -- Informed sources expressed optimism today over the outcome of the talks between Soviet and Czechoslovak leaders as the people were awaiting the end of the meeting.
The Standard Oil Company of California, following the trend of almost all other major oil companies reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30.

SMITH CENTER, Kan., July 26 -- Take Smith Center, "The Heart of Uncle Sam," Smith Center calls itself. And it's almost true. The very geographical center of the continental United States lies just a few miles north and east of this sun-blistered prairie city of 2,769.

POCANTICO HILLS, N. Y., July 31 -- The Harris Poll reported tonight that Governor Rockefeller could defeat either of the Democratic Presidential hopefuls and that Richard M. Nixon could defeat neither.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 31 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright remained in trouble in Arkansas' turbulent politics today after salvaging a narrow victory over three opponents in yesterday's Democratic primary.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Treasury Department offered today a six-year note yielding 5.70 per cent interest to pay off securities maturing in August, and to raise $1.5-billion in cash.

LONDON, July 31 -- At his general audience today, from his summer residence at Castel Gandolfo, Pope Paul VI told pilgrims what has been apparent to everyone for the last few years -- that the decision on whether to continue the Roman Catholic prohibition on artificial birth control has caused him no little spiritual suffering.
Price increases of one to 5 per cent to take effect Aug. 15 were announced yesterday by the appliance division of Admiral Corporation on its 1969 refrigerators, freezers and electric ranges.

VAIL, Ariz. -- This little settlement, nestled in the foothills of the Rincon Mountains, about 20-miles southeast of Tucson, was formerly a stagecoach stop and inn during Arizona's territorial days. The siesta-like atmosphere remains, but the place has changed.

The Air Traffic Controllers get my vote for the outstanding professional group of 1968. Their action has finally focused attention on the outrageous flight conditions that exist not only in the New York area but in all other major cities of the United States; where air conges tion gets worse each day and passenger safety declines.

Dana Valery, a lissom brunette with a voice that is bigger than her slim figure would indicate, is clicking at the Plaza's Persian Room in the first week of a three-week stand.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 31 (AP) -- South African gold sales on the free market in May and June resulted in an increase of $102.48-million in gold and foreign assets held by the reserve bank at the end of last week, the bank said today.

James L. Buckley, Conservative candidate for the United States Senate in New York, detailed his reasons yesterday for opposing George Wallace for President.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 4 -- Governor Rockefeller taunted Richard M. Nixon today, implying that the former Vice President was afraid to face questions from the public, the press and delegates to the Republican National Convention.

NORWICH, England, Aug. 2 -- It is rare that any artistic organization, once established, ever completely changes its direction. But that is precisely what has happened to Ballet Rambert, Britain's oldest ballet company, now more than 30 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- An individual's personal privacy must be the primary consideration in the establishment of a computerized data system by the Federal Government, a House subcommittee said today.

The first building in a 176-acre industrial center in New Jersey being developed by the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company in association with a construction concern will be ready in the fall. The building will be occupied by the American Poclain Corporation, sales representative of Poclain, S.A., France, manufacturer of excavating equipment.
The nation's big retail chains continued in July to turn in sales figures well above those for the 1967 month. Several record highs were achieved.

On the first Sunday since Pope Paul VI issued his encyclical banning all forms of artificial birth control, the American Roman Catholic hierarchy conveyed to the man in the pew yesterday its unbending suport for the Pope's position.
With six business days left for the registration of rifles and shotguns under the city's new Firearms Control Law, only 40,000 of an estimated total of 300,000 guns have been registered.
WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Aug. 4 -- The bluff north of the Lincoln Tunnel entrance provided a backdrop early today for towering flames that engulfed a riverfront warehouse.
BUDAPEST, Aug. 4 -- Hungarian Communist party leaders are expected to meet in the next few days to discuss the result of the Soviet-bloc talks in Bratislava.
Three Air Force pilots released by North Vietnam arrived at Kennedy International Airport last night.

There's no end in sight to the decline in interest rates that has been taking place since late May. This is the dominant view of Wall Street's fixed-income securities dealers, a consensus based on discussions with scores of Government, corporate and tax-exempt bond dealers and traders.

New York City announced over the weekend that it has filed suit in Federal Court charging eight plumbing manufacturers and a trade association with conspiring to fix the price of plumbing fixtures installed in public housing, schools and other public building.
In hot midsummer, some Americans begin to think in terms of a cool new car -- and not the eye-catching new models that appear in the fall.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 4 -- At least 50 members of the Lindsay administration are on vacation here this week. They are not spending much time at the beach, however. Most are too busy on the ninth floor of the Americana Hotel, which has become Lindsay - for - Something headquarters in everything but name.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Jack Nicklaus breezed to his first tournament victory in more than nine months today, winning the Western open for the second straight year by a three-stroke margin.

PRAGUE, Aug. 4 -- In a subdued victory announcement to the Czechoslovak people tonight, Alexander Dubcek, the Communist party leader, said that the week's East European conferences had provided "new scope" for the country's liberalization.
IPSWICH, Mass., Aug. 4 -- John Updike's first play, which unlike his best-selling novel, "Couples," names names and tells all about Ipswich, opened and closed with one performance here yesterday.

ADEN, Southern Yemen, Aug. 4 -- The armed forces of the People's Republic of Southern Yemen today claimed a sweeping victory and the routing of a force of rebel tribesmen in the Fourth Province. They also claimed the capture of the important mountain stronghold of Sawda, 20 miles from Sayed, capital of the Aulaqi sector, where the tribesmen are concentrated.

GROTON, Conn., Aug. 5 -- A strike that has halted construction and overhaul work on 16 nuclear submarines at the Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics Corporation went into its fourth week today with no immediate prospect for settlement.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Antiwar groups announced plans today for "militant" demonstrations Aug. 28 outside the Democratic National Convention here.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 5 -- Every political convention opens with a dispensable day. It is planned weeks in advance by six bores and a sadist. Today's was programed last May in a Turkish bath in Cincinnati, and from transcripts of the discussion it is possible to reconstruct how it was done.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 5 -- The Republican party, smarting under charges that it is "lily white," moved today to take in more Negroes in the future.

LAPPEENRANTA, Finland, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- The 112-year-old Saimaa Canal, captured by the Soviet Union in the 1939-40 war with Finland, was reopened today after 29 years in colorful ceremonies attended by 3,000 spectators. The canal now runs through 12 miles of Soviet territory.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 5 -- Governor Rockefeller clung to his hopes for the Republican Presidential nomination today, but he and his advisers could produce little evidence that he was gaining ground.

For the last 125 years, the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York has been advertising its services to the public. And since the company, familiarly known as MONY, is only 125 years old, that seems to be a pretty good record.
The long and persistent decline in wheat futures prices has led many traders to study their charts, hoping to find a bottoming out. But yesterday it was a matter of wishful thinking.

What was that three-pointed device that appeared over the weekend in front of the Subtreasury Building at the corner of Broad and Wall Streets? City residents may not have recognized it as a combine, but farm dwellers would have, because that's just what it was.
Short-term interest rates continued to decline yesterday, and Government securities dealers reported a heavier-than-expected demand for the Treasury's new notes yielding 5.70 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Rev Leon H. Sullivan, pastor of Zion Baptist Church and founder of the Opportunities Industrialization Center, announced today the opening of a second entirely Negro-owned and Negro-administered factory.
A man-made radioactive element has been successfully tested as a tool for the detection of low grade gold and silver ores.

Like the architecture of Miami Beach or the orations of Senator Dirksen, the Republican platform is seductive, implausible, occasionally self-contradictory and blatant in its willingness to please. In contrast to the austere ideological manifesto proclaimed by the Gold-waterites four years ago, the document to be submitted to the Republican Convention today represents a return to the genial tradition of promising something to everybody.
The corporate take-over trend is spreading to the banking industry. At present, there are three fights for control of important regional banks, either brewing or already flared into the open.

The Port of New York Authority disclosed yesterday that it was willing to drop its nine-year-long insistence that only the Great Swamp of Morris County, N.J., was suitable as the site for a fourth major airport for the metropolitan area.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 5 -- The state promised today to produce a surprise witness who will testify he saw Huey P. Newton, co-founder of the Black Panthers, shoot Patrolman John Frey with the policeman's own gun.
The London Stock Exchange closed quietly firm yesterday. Sentiment was helped by selective buying, which reflected good corporate news and the more settled situation in Czechoslovakia.

The much-heralded marriage between the communications industry, in the form of the Western Union Telegraph Company, and the data-processing industry, as represented by the Computer Sciences Corporation, has been called off.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 5 -- With a smile as wide as Biscayne Bay, Richard M. Nixon and his confident entourage blew into this convention city late this afternoon, one day later than his principal rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination, but perhaps 100 times more confident.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 5 -- Mayor Lindsay, who had snubbed the national Republican leadership twice in the last four years, was cheered for more than three minutes tonight by the party's national convention.
CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 5 -- Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff opened his re-election campaign today with a handshaking tour through the picturesque farm country of Connecticut's northwest corner.

JONES BEACH, L. I., Aug 5 -- Buildings sprang up all along the shoreline here today, but no laws were violated and no view was obstructed. The most the 115 edifices did was make a succession of insignificant bumps on the silver stranded shore.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 5 -- Lights burn down upon the innocent, cameras turn with neatly regulated zeal upon the hand-clapping emissaries, and a well-ordered convention proceeds along its well-ordered, way.
Prices made a modest advance in the face of declining volume on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
The city will begin accepting applications today from home-improvement contractors and salesmen for licensing under the city's Home Improvement Law enacted April 22.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 5 -- Spectators at the Republican National Convention were forced today to open shopping bags and briefcases before being allowed to enter the convention hall.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 5 -- Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Niekerson said today that the Board of Supervisors should not renew the franchises of the 17 bus companies in the county until they have improved their service.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted today a rule change permitting registered investment companies to hold more than 10 per cent of the outstanding voting securities of unregistered small business investment companies.

The 10-story building at 125 Barclay Street, where The New York World-Telegram and The Sun was published, has changed hands again. The leasehold, which was sold a few months ago to a group of investors headed by Herbert Goldstein, has now been resold to the Sylvan Lawrence Company, which plans to modernize the building for office tenancy.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that elderly plaintiffs were entitled to have their cases moved ahead of those of younger litigants on the state's long trial calendar.

ADDIS ABA-BA, Ethiopia, Aug. 5 -- Lieut. Col. Odumegwu Ojukwu, the Biafran leader, said here today at the opening session of talks seeking peace in Nigeria's civil war that only political sovereignty could assure his secessionist people's survival.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 5 -- Acoustical engineers have recovered from an early Ediphone recording cylinder the voice of the late author, Edgar Rice Burroughs, as he dictated part of a novel called "Tarzan and the Madman."

FREEHOLD, N. J., Aug. 5 -- With the thermometer pushing 90 and 11,182 punters pushing one another, Freehold Raceway, the country's oldest pari-mutuel harness racing track in continuous operation, opened today with a maximum of confusion and a minimum of comfort.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- The Belle Haven Club crew of Greenwich, Conn., with Jane Colihan as helmswoman, sailed into a 3-point lead off Larchmont Y.C. today after the first three races of the 30th anniversary Long Island Sound girls' championship regatta.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 5 -- The Israeli air strike yesterday in Jordan was clearly designed to have as much of an impact on the Government in Amman as it did on the Arab guerrilla headquarters that were the target of the bombs.
Economic research must relate to social problems of the day, John R. Meyer, president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, pointed out yesterday in the bureau's annual report.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Aug. 5 -- On Nov. 1, 1966, Richard M. Nixon was campaigning through southern Pennsylvania on almost the last of those punishing tours on behalf of Republican Congressional candidates that ultimately proved successful enough to launch him into the 1968 Presidential picture.

BUFFALO, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills, using rookies freely for the first time in an exhibition game, defeated the National Football League Detroit Lions, 13-9, tonight in 90-degree-plus temperature.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 5 -- Eight star-studded teams battled in the quarter-final round of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship here this afternoon, survivors of an original entry of 80 teams.

MOSCOW, Aug. 5 -- The specter of "counterrevolution" in Czechoslovakia that evoked cries of outrage and alarm from the Soviet Union seems in Moscow to have disappeared abruptly into the mists of unhistory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, suggested today that all 109 members of the International Monetary Fund, at their annual meeting here at the end of next month, formally join in the decision of the seven former 'gold pool" countries, made last March, not to buy or sell gold in the free markets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The United States Court of Appeals here has overturned the disorderly conduct conviction of Arthur Kinoy, a New York lawyer who was dragged from a House Un-American Activities Committee hearing two years ago after vigorously objecting to the committee's procedures.

A FOLDAWAY rotisserie broiler that can be used indoors or out has been introduced by Nautilus Industries, Inc., a division of the Tappan Company in Freeland, Pa. The appliance, called the Showcase, can be used on counter tops or hung on walls.

Usually at his best when desperate, Emile Griffith will oppose Gypsy Joe Harris tonight at the Philadelphia Spectrum in an important 12-round bout that will shape the immediate, if not the distant, future of the middleweight division.

Bard, Inc., owned by Davol, and half interests in Bard-Davol, Ltd., and Bard-Davol International, Inc., foreign sales companies.

The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it would install a new electronic quotation display system at each of its 11 trading posts to provide automatically to brokers and specialists data on the market for each security traded there.

AVIGNON. France -- Now that the time of vacations has brought a period of relative peace to Paris, this old walled city that for 100 years six centuries ago was a seat of Popes has become a place where the young of France, including the hot-blooded "enrages," are making the scene.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has decided to compete with the other two major networks in the lucrative field of late-night, talk-variety shows. C.B.S. announced yesterday that it had hired Merv Griffin, already a star in the talk-show format, to be host of a show, beginning in the fall of 1969.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 5 -- The New York Jets' scouting report on Lee White, their top draft choice, said he had size, quickness, strength, balance and was hard to knock off his feet.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 8 -- Dick Dell, a 20-year-old American collegian with serious tennis ambitions, and John Brown, a 27-year-old Australian college lecturer with none, provided the upsets today in the 79th Meadow Club invitation tournament.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -Senator Eugene J. McCarthy had praise today for the selection of Richard M. Nixon as the Republican nominee for President.
The New York Stock Exchange, conceding that it was acting under "Government prodding," proposed yesterday the first reduction in brokerage commissions in its 176-year history.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Congressional budget cuts have forced the Federal space agency to condition itself for a single entry in the race to the moon -- and little else.

The Government's new 5 5/8 per cent notes that were marketed Monday declined slightly yesterday, after the Treasury announced that larger subscribers would get 18 per cent of the securities they requested.

The Government's new 5 5/8 per cent notes that were marketed Monday declined slightly yesterday, after the Treasury announced that larger subscribers would get 18 per cent of the securities they requested.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 8 -- The Republican National Convention's ratification of the NixonAgnew ticket has, at long last, given the Democrats some encouraging news for 1968.
The Glen Alden Corporation received mixed signals from the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday.

BRANCHVILLE, N. J., Aug. 8 -- Betsy Gerson stood disconsolately on the sidelines, her left arm in a East up to the elbow, when the open jumper class got under way tonight at the Sussex County horse show.

Civil liberties groups accused a newly formed police organization yesterday of a "frightening power play to take over the judiciary" and an "undisguised declaration of war against the black militant communities."

DULLNESS on television is an inescapable reality for a medium trying to do too much too often, but the Wednesday night coverage of the Republican National Convention should qualify as cruel and inhuman punishment.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 8 -The top-seeded team of George Rapee and Edgar Kaplan of New York, Sidney Lazard of New Orleans and Eric Murray and Sam Kehela of Toronto won the Spingold Knockout Team Championship here in the early hours of this morning at the end of a contest that lasted slightly more than a week.

TRENTON, Aug. 8 -- Nine Morris County communities, several of which have rapidly developing residential and industrial complexes, were ordered today in State Superior Court to suspend any further building until they stopped polluting the Rockaway River.

The Committee of American Steamship Lines, which speaks for 13 of the 14 subsidized deep-sea operators, said yesterday that "the railroads are interested in some sort of cooperative program" to encourage more manufacturers to seek export markets.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 8 -"Elephant Steps," Stanley Silverman's hour-long "occult opera," seen and heard in its premiere at Tanglewood last night, has scarcely a single unfamiliar element.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 8 -- Assistant Suffolk District Attorney Carl Spitznagel told the jury trying Queens Supreme Court Justice James A. Roe Jr. on bribery charges here today that there was "absolutely no evidence" linking the defendant to an alleged attempt to bribe a prospective witness.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 8 -- Paul O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, called today for the establishment of a national primary election to nominate future Presidential candidates.
LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Bishops attending the 10th Lambeth Conference opened debate today on whether to upset a cherished Anglican tradition and begin ordaining women as deacons, priests and even bishops.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The National Football League exhibition game between the Philadelphia Eagles and Detroit Lions scheduled for Sunday here was canceled today.
Prices declined slightly yesterday in an active day's trading on the American Stock Exchange.

It would seem appropriate to "blow the whistle" on policy adopted by the Port of New York Authority and some of the commercial airlines serving the New York metropolitan area, relating to traffic congestion allegedly caused by "general aviation" or nonairline traffic.

As human populations proliferate through our planet's limited spaces, preservation groups scramble to set aside significant lands and buildings under the belief that the sure hand of commerce will otherwise wreak disfigurement and even total disappearance.
The Board of Education announced yesterday that it had reached "unanimous agreement in principle" on all major decentralization steps to be taken during the new school year beginning on Sept. 9.
A truckload of upstate hoofers got a lot of little hands from a standing-room audience of youngsters in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday.

Stock brokers, whose bread and butter is affected by the New York Stock Exchange's proposed new basis for commission charges, were far from united yesterday in their appraisal of the suggested scheme.
HONG KONG, Aug. 8 -Groups called Mao Tse-tung's Thought Propaganda Teams are the latest weapon being employed in the effort to curb extreme leftist elements in Communist China.

ST. LOUIS, Aug? 8 (AP) -The Federal Communications Commission's regulations governing operation of Community Atenna Television (CATV) were upheld today by the United-States Eighth Circuit Court or' peals.

It took six pitchers, three managers, an umpire who objects to being called nasty names, 3 hours 31 minutes, and 11 innings to subdue the New York Yankees last night at Yankee Stadium. John Roseboro's home run off Fritz Peterson gave the Minnesota Twins a 4-3 victory.

There is obviously something wrong or at least something missing in most of the explanations of why Richard Nixon chose Gov. Spiro T. Agnew of Maryland as the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee. Mr. Nixon won the nomination and blew the election all in one day, according to some of these explanations, by appeasing the South with Agnew and affronting the urban North.
The Little Sisters of the Poor, a Roman Catholic order that provides homes for the destitute aged, will celebrate its centennial in the United States next month.

NYACK, N. Y. -- This riverside town is awash in antiques, and the flood tide is still rising. Already seven antiques stores line one street (South Broadway) and the total of a dozen (give or take an opening or two) works out at more than one shop for each 1,000 residents.

BONN, Aug. 9 -- A Viscount airliner of British Eagle Airliners bound for Innsbruck, Austria, from London crashed and burned today beside the autobahn at Pfaffenhofen, north of Munich. There were no survivors among the 44 passengers and 4 crewmen.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 9 -- Ron Holmberg and Gene Scott each rallied from the loss of a first set today and advanced to the semi-finals of the 79th Meadow Club invitation tennis tournament, along with the South Africans, Bob Hewitt and Ray Moore.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- An airline stewardess no longer has to worry about losing her job she marries.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- A backer of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy for President charged today that Democratic National Committee officials arranging the party convention were "biased" in favor of Vice President Humphrey and were working to "foreclose any hope for an open convention."
LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Londoners are debating with vigor whether a bit of blue sky was sighted here for a few moments earlier this month.
GENEVA, Aug. 9 -- The World Council of Churches called on its member churches in more than 80 countries today to put pressure on their governments to take action to relieve the suffering in Nigeria.
Stock prices trimmed earlier losses in late trading yesterday, but the market closed slightly lower on balance for the second consecutive session.

Anti-Communism has been Richard M. Nixon's chief political stock in trade since the beginning of his public career in 1946. His early electoral victories against Jerry Voorhis and Helen Gahagan Douglas were gained by intimating his opponents were at least soft on Communism if not outright Communists or fellow travelers.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 9 -- In his first public defense of his controversial running mate, Richard M. Nixon described Spiro T. Agnew today as "one of the most underrated political men in America."

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 9 -- The Suffolk County District Attorney, George J. Aspland, was accused today of employing "a mysterious type of trial tactics" in arresting a defense attorney last Wednesday night during the bribery trial of Queens Supreme Court Justice James A. Roe Jr.
The New York Stock Exchange yesterday reported the changes carried below in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
DETROIT, Aug. 9 -- As Petula Clark, the English songbird, sings it in commercials for Chrysler, the beat goes on and on and on.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- This year's corn crop is estimated at 4,555,893,000 bushels, 4 per cent less than the record of 4,722,164,000 bushels produced in 1967, the Agriculture Department announced today.
DETROIT, Aug. 9 -- Detroit's two regular daily newspapers resumed publication today, ending the nation's longest newspaper blackout at nearly nine months.

SAIGON, South Vietnam; Aug. 9 -- The monsoon rain splashed through the broken tiles of the abandoned farmhouse and fell on the soldiers inside as they chatted about Richard M. Nixon's victory at the Republican National Convention.

A pompadour haircut, some of the numbers of a license plate and the acute memories of several witnesses brought about the arrest yesterday of a free-lance auto salesman as a suspect in the slaying of a Queens lawyer.

STANTON, Del., Aug. 9 (AP) --- Heavily-favored Damascus, pointing toward his second straight horse-of-the-year crown, goes against a nominal field in tomorrow's $50,000 added William du Pont Jr. Handicap at Delaware Park.

WALNUT, Calif., Aug. 9 (AP) -- Jim Ryun, the star Kansas miler, will draw the closest attention tomorrow when candidates for the United States men's Olympic track team compete at Mount San Antonio College.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 9 -- The World Medical Assembly adopted a code here today that specifies that at least two physicians must pronounce the donor dead before surgery transplanting an organ may be performed. The code leaves physicians with the responsibility for determining the moment of death.

Although the nuclear-powered freighter Savannah did not exactly sputter up to her pier in Hoboken yesterday like an automobile with an empty fuel tank, her operators said she had just about "run out of gas."

Bond prices moved indecisively yesterday, ending a week in hich the market paused a bit to digest the dramatic gains registered throughout July. Government issues fell during the day by up to 1/4 point, while corporates edged upward.

The announcement by its president, Robert S. McNamara, that the "World Bank can very substantially increase its program of borrowing and thereby expand the flow of investment funds to the developing countries" could not have been more timely.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia -- This is a strange and beautiful city -- a clean, decorous, fairly prosperous composite of two worlds.

RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 9 -- George C. Wallace claimed credit today for influencing the selection of Gov. Spiro T. Agnew as the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate and for the emphasis on "law and order" at the Republican National Convention.

Nathan's Famous, Inc., by its own testimony the world's greatest hot-dog purveyor, will expand its red-hots empire into Times Square in December.

Gardner, Representative Ogden R. Reid of Westchester County and Representative Charles E. Goodell of Jamestown.
Four vagrants were routed by the police from bottle-littered Pioneer Park at noon yesterday as residents of Greenwich Village cheered.

Bailey's Beach, a kelpfilled, watery and very private retreat at Newport, R. I., may soon be not quite so private nor quite so much of a retreat (the kelp is apparently immutable).

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 9 -- The first half of last night's concert of new music at Tanglewood was, for the most part, gentle. Not so the second half. To the frustration of their passengers, some international flights destined for Kennedy Airport but delayed by air congestion have landed at Newark Airport to refuel, without discharging the passengers, and then returned to the skies to spend hours aloft before finally landing at Kennedy.

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario, Aug. 9 -- To show you how life imitates art, the new issue of True Confessions at the Niagara drugstore has an article called "My Husband Hid a Tape Recorder Under Our Bed, Then He Left Me Alone With His Brother."

BRANCHVILLE, N. J., Aug. 9 -- Pam Carmichael, a 16-yearold blonde from Acadia Farms in Northfield, Ohio, rode the winners of both the large and small junior working hunter divisions tonight at the Sussex Country Horse Show.

PARIS, Aug. 9 (UPI) -- A French National Railways spokesman cleared up today confusion surrounding fare reductions available to foreign tourists in France.

Summer is often a dull period in potato futures trading, partly because producers and dealers often sell to hedge their positions. Prices for the May contract showed little change.

PARIS, Aug. 9 -- French officials fear that half a million Biafrans will die of famine before the end of this month unless food supplies reach them. They express the hope that something can be done, but they add that France will take no singlehanded action to help the secessionists.
DUBLIN, Aug. 9 -- The United States team won the premier international trophy of the week at the Dublin horse show today before a crowd of 25,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -Senator George S. McGovern of South Dakota, a dove on the Vietnam war, plans to announce tomorrow his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

CAMBRIDGE BAY, Northwest Territories -- It was a typical day. In the morning Annette Blake assisted at the birth of an Eskimo baby; in the afternoon she saw patients at the clinic and in the middle of the night she sewed up a bad laceration.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 9 -- A High Court judge ruled today that the Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith had achieved legal status. The ruling appeared to strengthen Rhodesia's campaign for international recognition of its break from Britain in 1965.

YONKERS, Aug. 9 -- The horse the bettors forgot, Fresh Yankee, streaked to victory in the stretch at Yonkers Raceway tonight, and as he was passing horses that couldn't keep up the blazing time, he disappointed the chalk-players while upsetting the odds-on Flamboyant.

When Mayor Lindsay took office he correctly assessed the "band-aid measures" of his predecessor as a hopeless approach to curing the great sickness of our city. The Ogden Corporation, diversified company engaged in manufacturing and services, reported yesterday second-quarter net income of $6,806,405, equal to 66 cents a share, up from $5,740,415, or 56 cents a share, in the similar three months last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Secretary of Defense, Clark M. Clifford, authorized today the immediate purchase of 1.5 million tons of steel to meet the Pentagon's major hardware requirements for the current fiscal year, which started July 1.

Twenty-three years ago this week the world entered the nuclear weapons era at Hiroshima and Nagasaki. NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 9 -- City Manager Murray C. Fuerst challenged the State Housing Division today by appointing two public-housing tenants to the New Rochelle Municipal Housing Authority.

RUDDERLESS Fairchild Camera told the investing public what it wanted to hear yesterday. It said it had hired a top administrator to take the wheel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower's doctors reported today that the was gaining strength and was in "excellent spirits" following his latest major heart attack last Monday.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (UPI) -Jim Hart passed for two touchdowns, and Willis Crenshaw ran for one tonight, carrying the St. Louis Cardinals to a 24-7 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in an exhibition game between the National Football League teams.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- An American civil engineer now working in Vietnam was granted a patent this week for a machine to explore and blow up enemy tunnels, caves and trenches. The unmanned vehicle, with a television camera in its nose, is designed to worm along passageways and around corners.

The Mozart-Haydn Festival at Philharmonic Hall is giving Haydn the weekend off and making Mozart do doubletime. The first of two performances of "The Operatic Mozart" was given last night. It will be repeated tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today the 1963 acquisition by the Seeburg Corporation of another company in the same field, violated the Clayton Act, Seeburg is a major producer of vending machines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it was lifting its ban on trading of Alsco, Inc., securities. But it cautioned broker-dealers and investors to protect themselves with full information about the company's affairs.

A rash of forged and fraudulent real estate appraisals, used to obtain loans or to elicit fees from unsuspecting realty investors and mortgage lenders, has led a national organization of appraisers to issue a general warning to the industry.

CAIRO, Aug. 11 -- Well informed Arab diplomats have said in the last week that the United Arab Republic would accept a Middle East settlement that included internationalizing the Gaza Strip, waiving past demands for the repatriation of Palestinian refugees, and demilitarizing the Sinai Peninsula.

Modern-dance companies, traditionally the poor relations in the American artistic family, will receive a $485,000 helping hand from the Ford Foundation. The foundation yesterday announced three grants to help seven leading troupes and several lesser groups state a total of 25 weeks of performances in major New York City theaters beginning this fall and ending in the spring of 1970.

GUATEMALA, Aug. 11 -- In an effort to appease 4,800 striking students who have been away from classes since last Monday, the University of Guatemala has abolished a controversial General Studies School.

MILFORD HAVEN, Wales, Aug. 10 -- The Gulf Oil Corporation of Pittsburgh enjoyed a coup in its overseas expansion program today with the presence of Queen Elizabeth II and members of the royal family at a glittering opening ceremony for its first refinery in Britain.

OYSTER BAY COVE, L. I., Aug. 11 -- Ten days ago, Valiant Hawk suffered a bad bruise when he inadvertently stepped on a rockpile while he was being groomed. After treating him all week, Mr. and Mrs. John Leib sent him to the Northwood horse show today.

A Defense Department program that would allocate the greater part of the agency's peacetime cargo movements to the nation's subsidized carriers will kill the fleet that has borne the brunt of the Vietnam sealift effort, according to the Maritime Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
Why make a quality product when it is easier and cheaper to make one for the mass market?

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Norm Snead, the No. 1 quarterback of the Philadelphia Eagles, suffered today a broken left ankle that may sideline him for most of the season. The injury came on the first play as the Eagles dropped a 20-3 decision to the Detroit Lions in a National Football League preseason game.

The defeat Moscow and its allies suffered in their recent confrontation with Prague inevitably forced a rethinking of attitudes on many issues. This reconsideration could produce changes making positive contributions and helping to ease present areas of world tension. There are no guarantees, of course, but evidence that some rethinking is taking place comes from the first shock waves that are already spreading in the wake of the meetings at Cierna and Bratislava.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Edward C. Baumert 3d with Ariette won the Shields Race on Long Island Sound today. The class of 30-foot fiberglass keel boats proved fastest in the season's 21st Yacht Racing Association championship regatta and the second half of the Huguenot Yacht Club's 74th annual event.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 -- Gil Hodges lost an exercise in gamesmanship and the New York Mets lost two games to the San Francisco Giants today.

MONMOUTH BEACH, N. J., Aug, 11 -- The skipper and first mate of a 65-foot commercial fishing boat were arrested today after they allegedly shouted abusive language at marine policemen, theatened them with garbage cans and then eluded capture for 24 hours.

SOONDUK KIM owns three lengths of false eyelashes -short ones for going to church, medium ones for day and sweeping ones for evening. The other day she was wearing her medium ones, the proper length for taking her lively young sons sight-seeing on their first visit to New York.

The Alumni Federation of Columbia University yesterday proposed the creation of boards of visitors -- with student members -- that would inspect the troubled institution's operations and listen to the grievances of its students and faculty members.
Paul O'Dwyer's Democratic campaign staff talks about spending at least $1-million and is optimistic -- if unspecific -- about its chances of raising the money.

MORE than a thousand players took part in the National Championships of the American Bridge Association that ended in San Francisco Saturday, a remarkable total for an organization that provides primarily for Negro players.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 11 -- Richard M. Nixon has disappeared from view again, in a part of the country inhabited by the kind of people to whom he will be keying much of his campaign this fall.

GRANDMASTER Larry Evans of New York became the United States Chess Champion by scoring 8 1/2-2 1/2/ over a strong 12-man field in the recent round-robin title play at the Empire Hotel. He won six games and drew five.
The head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said yesterday that he would issue "get tough" guidelines to more than 29,000 members of his union some time this week.
PRAGUE, Aug. 11 -- If you are under 30, Prague seems the place to be in this summer.
An Anglo-Australian quintet that has brought some elements of romanticism back to the youth pop scene, the Bee Gees, was heard Saturday night at the Forest Hills Music Festival in Queens.

The State Division of Human Rights announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with 12 major real estate management concerns and with the New York Life Insurance Company on methods to eliminate racial imbalances in housing under their control.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 11 -- In a three-hour duel interrupted by several disputes, Ron Holmberg's artistry outlasted Gene Scott's tenacity today in the championship singles match of the 79th Meadow Club invitation tennis tournament.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -Billy Williams's two-run homer in the fifth inning helped Bill Hands gain his 14th victory today as the surging Chicago Cubs beat the National League leading St. Louis Cardinals for the sixth straight time, 7-3.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 12 -President Johnson vetoed today legislation that would have prohibited imports of extralong staple cotton from countries not having diplomatic relations with the United States. The bill would have also reduced this nation's import quota for this premium cotton.

Passers-by on St. Marks Place between Second and Third Avenues last night were treated at least in part to "a study of underground living in the 100th century." Most of them didn't bat an eye, in true New York tradition.
People who have been sneezing out of season (out of ragweed season, that is) are probably allergic to the mold spores that have been plentiful in the atmosphere in the metropolitan area this month.
DETROIT, Aug. 12 -- The automobile industry is preparing a new class of automobiles, smaller and cheaper than any built in this country now but still bigger than the tiny imports.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 12 -- Two Syrian Air Force pilots landed their MIG-17 jet fighters this morning at an abandoned airstrip in northern Israel, five miles south of the Lebanese border.

The Long Island Rail Road, plagued by a shortage of electric cars in good operating order, canceled a record number of 53 trains yesterday and announced last night that another record would be set this morning with the cancellation of 28 westbound and four eastbound trains.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- The Archbishop of Santiago, Raul Cardinal Silva Henriquez, suspended nine Roman Catholic priests from their ecclesiastical functions today for having led a "people's struggle'' demonstration at the city's cathedral.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- A sparkling two-under- women's-par 36 on the first nine holes today provided the impetus that enabled smiling Shirley Englehorn of Caldwell, Idaho, to win the $28,500 Concord open by three strokes.
A SHORT time after the Russians executed Lavrenti P. Beria, Stalin's despised chief of secret police, a German Communist leader was discussing party affairs with a Russian.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP) -Dennis McLain pitched a five-hitter for his 24th victory tonight as the Detroit Tigers scored a 6-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians. The triumph was the right-hander's 16th in a row on the road.
PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Aug. 11 -- The major trembles when he speaks. "I have seen too much war," he says. "I have seen 20 years of war."
Steel production fell 7.5 per cent last week, compared with that of the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

PLAYERS in major championships are frequently careless in entering the results of their deals, and their errors are quickly detected by the scorers, an unsung body of men and women working behind the scenes who produce the scores and rank the winners with great speed and accuracy.

HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Jim King, a Chicago pro who rejoined the tour five weeks ago after a 4 1/2-year absence, led the qualifiers at Westchester Country Club today as a field of 186 pros played an 18-hole round for 10 places in the Westchester Golf Classic.

A revival of peace hopes stimulated a broad rally in the stock market yesterday.

ATLANTA, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Satchel Paige, the famed Negro athlete whose uncertain age has been reported as high as 70 years, was signed by the Atlanta Braves today as an adviser and possibly a part-time pitcher.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- After ten days of immersion in the Republican party, even in air-conditioned Miami Beach, it is a relief to turn to the Democrats, even in Lyndon Johnson's Washington. It is not that the Democrats are any less square or any more fun; it is just that the hardiest among us can still hope that the Chicago convention, not having been held yet, will produce something miraculously supportable.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 12 -Somewhere between here and Kennedy Airport in New York there is a five-game losing streak trying to find the Yankees.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug 12 -- Democrats loyal to the national party outlined today a drive to defeat the third-party movement of former Gov. George C. Wallace in Alabama "as it overextends itself afar."

A book by Senator George S. McGovern, "A Time for War/ A Time of Peace," is being rushed into print by Random House for publication before the Democratic National Convention, which starts Aug. 26. The book had originally been scheduled to appear in October.

City officials and spokesmen for the League of Women Voters reported yesterday that incomplete statistics showed at least 722 persons in predominantly Negro and Puerto Rican areas registered to vote last Saturday, the first day of a special registration drive.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI( -- Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today 94 civil rights suits initiated by the Justice Department in the last 12 months showed that America was "eliminating injustice as few people have ever done."

Continuing pessimism in the face of the record wheat crop created a landslide in wheat futures prices yesterday. All contracts again slipped to seasonal lows. Prices declined more than 3 cents a bushel in every contract, one of the sharpest drops traders remember in a long time.

The United Aircraft Corporation had the most profitable quarter and first six months in its history according to the semiannual report issued yesterday from its East Hartford headquarters.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Aug. 14 -- The Suffolk County police arrested 23 persons most of them teen-agers, during a raid early this morning in a drive to smash a heroin ring that has been operating in the western part of the county.

At 3 o'clock one morning last week, when it should have been almost blank, the arrivals and departures board in the Trans World Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport wore its rush-hour face. The terminal was thronged with passengers.

Noted writers and artists registered their support for Senator Eugene J. McCarthy last night by taking over Cheetah, normally a young people's spot for soft drinks and hot music, and making it an arena for what Daniel Stern, novelist, called "the politics of pleasure."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The Democratic Presidential candidates and their aides believe that the national convention, which opens in Chicago Aug. 26, is being set up in accordance with orders from President Johnson.
CLINTON, Okla., Aug. 14 (AP) -- The Federal Government paid Cheyenne-Arapaho Indians $15-million last week and almost forced western Oklahoma bankers to close their doors.

HONG KONG, Aug. 14 -- Sir Donald Hopson, head of the British diplomatic mission in Peking for the last three years, expressed the hope today that his departure from Communist China after what he described as considerable delay was a good sign.
THE CONSTANT CIRCLE. H. L. Mencken and His Friends. By Sara Mayfield. 307 pages. Delacorte Press. $6.50.

Another strong rally came in the silver-futures market yesterday. The London silver price was up sharply as well, possibly because of a belief that the I market was oversold in a recent sharp decline. Another bullish factor was the rejection by the Government at its weekly auction of all bids on high-grade silver.
A 35-story office building will be erected where Park Avenue South becomes Park Avenue, at the intersection of 32d Street.

To the Editor: The prospect of a STOLport on the West Side of Manhattan is not to be welcomed as a milestone in aviation but resisted as yet another encroachment on decent residential life in this city of ours. Fortunately, our neighborhood has been aware of Pan American's plans -- even though your paper and others have assiduously avoided reporting developments.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 14 (Reuters) -- The Government banned the opposition United party today and arrested its leader, Nalumino Mundia.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 14 -- As Denny McLain goes for the jackpot -- 30 victories, a pennant and a six-figure salary next year -- the story of this self-possessed 24-year-old becomes intertwined with two of baseball's biggest stars of exactly 20 years ago: John Sain and Lou Boudreau.

NEWARK, Aug. 14 -- Anthony Imperiale, leader of a militant white group, won election here today to a community council that will oversee the city's slum rehabilitation. LeRoi Jones, the Negro poet and black leader, was defeated.

Interest rates on bonds to finance public housing -- the most important gauge of local Government borrowing costs -- dropped sharply yesterday. The Housing Assistance Administration announced that $129,045,000 of Federally backed tax-exempt bonds were sold at competitive bidding at an average interest cost of 4.2516 per cent, more than half a percentage point below the record 4.7281 per cent cost incurred in the preceding sale in May.

To the Editor: What constitutional provision guarantees any individual the right to riot or to incite riot? As to your Aug. 2 editorial "Curbing College Freedom,'' I would not spend one penny to maintain my own child in a college or university where he saw overthrow of the administration as his sole course of action.

In the shortage of skilled seamen for emergency sealifts to Vietnam this summer, Federal officials believe there are hundreds of qualified former seamen who would return to the sea for temporary duty if maritime unions would relax rules barring them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- It now appears that we will have to choose the next President from among Richard Nixon, Hubert Humphrey and George Wallace. In preparing to make this choice, the important thing for the sound citizen is to remain in good mental condition.
The Curtis Publishing Company, stranded by changes in public taste, yesterday sold two of its magazines. The Ladies Home Journal and American Home, to Downe Communications, Inc.

Goodbody Co. has become the first brokerage concern to match up customer orders and completed transactions by electronic computer, a process designed to reduce clerical errors and to pave the way for future inroads into the paperwork backlog.
ATLANTA, Aug. 14 -- Democratic chairmen from six Southern states produced today a list of seven regional political leaders they intend to back for the party's Vice - Presidential nomination.

GURI DAM, Venezuela, Aug. 10 -- The impending close of the sluice gates at the huge Guri hydroelectric dam here will produce a tank full of tigers, deer, armadillos, rattle snakes and 50 other varieties of tropical fauna.
HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 14 -- President Johnson disagreed today with his political critics who say the nation is seriously ill and taking the wrong medicine to cure itself.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Among the other tenets of the Protestant ethic is the cautious belief that chickens should not be counted before they are hatched. But the report of Hubert Humphrey's task force on the post-Vietnam economy will tempt some reckless souls to do just that.

NORTON, Conn., Aug. 14 -- Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr., representing the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound and Larchmont, N.Y., Yacht Club, and John Welch of the St. Lawrence Valley Y.R.A. and Hudson, Quebec, Y. C., were tied for the lead at 14 1/4 points after the first three races today in the Area B semi-final series of the men's North American championship on Long Island Sound off Noroton Y. C.

DALIA, Israel -- In a way it is chance that this kibbutz in central Israel has its own poet, its own composer and its own painter-sculptor, and in a deeper sense it is no accident at all. It is chance that any kibbutz, even one that is as well established as the 35-year-old Dalia, has in its membership gifted artists of professional standing like Ely Netzer, poet; Dov Carmel, composer, and Shlomo Meyer, painter-sculptor.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 14 -- Highly placed Western diplomats say that the United Arab Republic has privately been pressing a proposal to end its 20-year-old state of belligerency with Israel.

Diseases related to narcotics addiction cause more deaths among New Yorkers 15 to 35 years old than murder, suicide, accidents or natural causes, Dr. Milton Helpern, the city's chief medical examiner, reported yesterday.

The Board of Education has decided to give each local school board in the city the power to pick its district superintendent this fall.

Indifference by many Negroes to the outcome of the Presidential election was reported by some officials yesterday as one of the basic reasons for the low number of slum dwellers who responded Saturday and Tuesday to this month's special voter registration drive in 63 low-income areas.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 14 -- The Miss America Pageant today sought Negro beauties to compete in its annual contest here.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- Frustrations continued to mount today for opponents of a "closed" Democratic national convention.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 14 -- There is only one thing wrong as the Yankees leave town with a three-game winning streak: Bill Robinson is hobbling with a pulled right hamstring muscle.

PARIS, Aug. 14 -- The French National Union of Airline Pilots declared a boycott of Algeria today, beginning Monday, to protest the detention of the seven Israeli crew members of an El A1 airliner hijacked on July 23.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy proposed today a new national housing program, saying that existing programs helped only the rich and the middle class and were "insensitive" to the needs of the poor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- The National Academy of Sciences urged the space agency today to begin an ambitious program of unmanned interplanetary flights, including a mission to Jupiter 500 million miles away.
Vice President Humphrey proposed yesterday that floor demonstrations be abolished and nominating speeches sharply limited at the 1968 Democratic National Convention.

Circle in the Square on Broadway, the new lessee of Henry Miller's Theater, has postponed its own presentation, "Morning, Noon and Night," in favor of "The Cuban Thing," to be produced by Ivor David Balding Associates.
BUFFALO, Aug. 14 -- In the first major shift of delegate strength, Vice President Humphrey picked up a net of 11 votes from Erie and Niagara Counties today in his bid for the Presidential nomination.
DOG shows have been held in the United States for nearly a century. In 1967, more than 1,000 were staged under the aegis of the American Kennel Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -- A divided Federal Reserve Board moved today to make life easier for state-chartered member banks.
An internal dispute at Liberation News Service, the left-wing, news agency "underground" and radical papers, broke into the open yesterday with charges of theft, embezzlement and kidnapping.

PRAGUE, Aug. 14 -- The Presidium of the Czechoslovak Communist party condemned today what it termed "violations of law and order" in recent political activity in Prague.

SCORES of little boys sat on green park benches in Harlem this week and watched Chuck McKinley and Joaquin Loyo-Mayo of Mexico play tennis. McKinley slammed a volley off the court, and an official sitting near the boys roared: "Oowwt."

Grandmothers who loudly proclaimed the virtues of rainwater may have instinctively known something science has just discovered -- that rain can be a plentiful source of vitamin B-12.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Aug. 14 (UPI) -- Catherine Lacoste of France rallied from three strokes down in the morning round then handily won her afternoon match today to assume the role of favorite as the 68th annual United States women's Amateur golf tournament entered the quarter-finals.
TRENTON, Aug. 14 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes characterized Richard M. Nixon today as an old-time Communist-baiter who now caters to Southern segregationists.

HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 14 -- Mason Rudolph played in the sunshine today and scored a seven-under-par 65 for the low professional score in the preliminary of the $250,000 Westchester Golf Classic, which will start at 8 A.M. tomorrow.

The spectacle of an industry closing its doors each Wednesday because of unprecedented business -- and profits -- no longer is merely baffling the securities brokerage trade.

Silver eased yesterday after an active upswing. The September contract closed at $2.21 1/2 an ounce, down from $2.23 1/2 on Wednesday, possibly because of profit taking by traders after the recent rise in prices.
A suit seeking to block the election in November of 25 new Civil Court judges was filed yesterday in State Supreme Court by a group of Reform Democrats and representatives of minority groups.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 15 (AP) -- President Johnson issued an Executive order today setting up a cooperative area manpower planning system intended to emphasize state and local initiative in meeting local manpower problems.
The New York Mets will stage a return match with the Houston Astros tonight in their first encounter since the team brawl in the Astrodome 10 days ago.

HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 15 -"Everything went just perfect," declared a rookie professional, Bob Murphy of Nichols, Fla., as he finished with a 64 and the lead in the $250,000 Westchester Golf Classic today.
Vice President Humphrey, confident of winning the Democratic Presidential nomination, announced yesterday that he would open his post-convention campaign on Labor Day in New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford said today that a halt in the bombing of North Vietnam required some reciprocal assurance from Hanoi that such a halt would not place American troops near the demilitarized zone in "greater jeopardy."
Richard Champion, a former Marine lance corporal and more recently a Post Office mail handler, exhaled into a white plastic mouth-piece connected by tubes to two large metal cylinders.

LAS VEGAS, Aug. 15 -- The controversial move by Howard Hughes to buy a sixth gambling business has been stopped, according to a statement today from the Hughes Tool Company and the owners of the Stardust Hotel and Casino.
The Continental Insurance Companies reported yesterday adjusted operating income of $25,939,778, or $2.42 a share, for the first half, against $31, 820,522, or $2.75 a share, in the 1967 half.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The current "loose talk of shooting looters" is likely to cause guerrilla warfare between Negroes and whites in American cities, Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association sent its members excerpts from the Police Department's rules and state law yesterday, emphasizing their duty to obey only the lawful orders of superiors in the department.
The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange took steps yesterday to impose restrictions upon brokerage-house acceptance of sell orders of both listed and over-the-counter securities.

ANYONE who dropped by De Pinna Wednesday night has a pretty good idea of how a fox feels during the hunt. In this instance fur was the game as well, and the hunters, blood hot with the scent of bargains, were relentless in pursuit of the quarry.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD is an island lying seven miles off the southeast coast of Massachusetts. It has 105 square miles. TAYNINH, South Vietnam, Aug. 19 -- United States and South Vietnamese troops pursued enemy soldiers through rice paddies and manioc fields south of Tayninh today after crushing an attack on the provincial capital in a night of savage fighting.
Twenty-year-old Martin D. Hauser was sentenced to 15 days in jail in Criminal Court yesterday for refusing to leave Washington Square Park after the midnight curfew.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (AP) A plea for wholesale revamping of the American school system was made today by the retiring president of the American Federation of Teachers.

The Federal Reserve Board held a secret meeting with the heads of some of the nation's largest state-chartered banks last Tuesday, Aug. 13, the day before the board issued a ruling significantly easing certain regulations governing these institutions.
STANFORD, Calif., Aug. 19 -- Stanford University announced today that Dr. Kenneth S. Pitzer, president of Rice University, would become Stanford's sixth president on Dec. 1.

WHERE WILL it all end? Raymond E. Kassar, 39-year-old bachelor president of Burlington House, one of the home fashion divisions of Burlington Industries, sometimes wonders. Mr. Kassar, who likes to think big, no sooner had started a nationwide contest for the 10 BestDressed Homes in America than he began to think that he hadn't been thinking big enough.

Ismael Laguna, a former lightweight champion, will make his second main-event appearance at Madison Square Garden within five weeks tonight when he opposes Lloyd Marshall of Newark, who is ranked sixth.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 19 -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan today denounced Israeli youths who rioted and looted in the Arab sector of Jerusalem last night after terrorist bombings in the Jewish sector.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Senator George S. McGovern called today for the withdrawl of about 250,000 American troops from South Vietnam and said United States forces there should fire only in self-defense.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- The Presidential backers of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy have turned in their hour of need to one of the oldest precepts of the old politics: the coattail theory.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug 19 -- Tod Field, representing the Port Washington (L.I.) Yacht Club, took a 14-point lead today after the first four races of the 41st Long Island Sound Midget Class championships were sailed off Horseshoe Harbor Y.C.
DETROIT, Aug. 19 -- President Johnson tonight ruled out any change in his policy on the Vietnam war, before the Democratic National Convention or after it.

BONN, Aug. 19 -- The West German news magazine Der Spiegel published today a highly critical article about William Manchester's forthcoming book "The Arms of Krupp," describing it as the "most vicious" work to date about the German steel and coal concern.
MONTAUK, L.I. -- It was 4:17 A.M. when a gentle knock at the door awakened me. Ahead lay a day of offshore fishing for marlin and swordfish.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- More than 3,000 steelworkers opened a five-day convention today in a mood to celebrate their strike-free contract achievements. But an internal question of undetermined dimensions hovered in the background.
Walter Kidde Co., Inc., and the Pacific Intermountain Express Company are talking merger, the companies announced yesterday.

Walter Kidde Co., Inc., and the Pacific Intermountain Express Company are talking merger, the companies announced yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 19 -- Gale Sayers's 76-yard run on the second play of the game led the Chicago Bears to a 10-7 victory over the Green Bay Packers tonight in an exhibition game between the National Football League teams.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 19 -- President Rene Barrientos Ortuno declared today that Antonio Arguedas Mendietta, the former Interior Minister who sent a copy of the Guevara diary to Cuba two months ago, should be tried for treason by a military tribunal.

A group of New York and California law students said yesterday that they had been arrested and held incommunicado in a Mexican jail for four days while en route to Cuba. They blamed the United States Government for their experience.
A 33-story office and hotel tower is being planned for 125th Street, Harlem's main thoroughfare, as part of a privately financed, $30-million redevelopment program.
CAIRANG, South Vietnam, Aug. 18 -- Until 10 days ago the thatched huts along the south bank of the Cantho River were considered safe and isolated from the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Backers of Vice President Humphrey presented to the Democratic platform committee today the outlines of a compromise Vietnam plank that would accept, but not demand, a cessation of the bombing of North Vietnam and formation of a coalition Government in South Vietnam.

Leonard Bernstein, who joined the New York Philharmonic 25 years ago as a brown-haired, 150-pound boy wonder, started rehearsals yesterday afternoon at Philharmonic Hall for his 10th and final season as musical director of the orchestra.

Mozart's best-known Horn Concerto, his best-known Two-Piano Concerto and one of Haydn's best-known symphonies (No. 88) made up three-quarters of the program by the New York Chamber Orchestra on the Midsummer Serenades series at Philharmonic Hall last night.
Stock prices continued to move up on balance yesterday, but the advance was rather restrained and occurred on fairly light trading volume.

About 20 members of a group calling itself the Community Action Committee staged a sit-in yesterday at two buildings -- 604 and 612 West 112th Street -- that are being demolished to make way for the Bank Street College of Education.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 19 -- The Yankees lost a game tonight and they could even lose a protest they no longer want to file.

The touring golf pros, who perform before millions of television viewers each week, announced formation yesterday of the American Professional Golfers. The action followed a split last week with the 52-year-old parent organization, the Professional Golfers' Association of America.

The Lindsay administration backed down yesterday from its policy of recommending citywide $15 fines for overtime parking at meters.

CAN Fanny May find happiness in private life? Fanny May, as the Federal National Mortgage Association is called, is about to convert to full private ownership. If recent prices are criteria for happiness, Fanny May must be fairly glowing.

Pan American World Airways disclosed yesterday that it had postponed plans to buy a new fleet of Sikorsky S-61 helicopters that were to have been used to restore service to and from the Pan Am Building within the next month.

NICOSIA, Cyprus -- Archbishop Makarios III, President of the Republic of Cyprus, is today's only prelate ruling a lay state except for the Pope in his capacity as chief of Vatican City. Once chosen, the Pope, as Makarios points out, is there for life.

Ross of the Chicago Yacht Club, the defending champion, led the fleet of 12 in the second race of the 22d annual championship regatta of the Luders-16 Class today but Daniel B. Killeen of the Southern Y.C., New Orleans, took a 1-point lead in the series being sailed off the Indian Harbor Club on Long Island Sound.
There will be no renewal of the Mrs. Billie Jean King-Nancy Richey rivalry in the first United States Open tennis championships next week at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.
Precious metals glittered in commodity futures markets yesterday.
