WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower clung resolutely to life today, but with a fragile grip that his doctors acknowledged could loosen at any time.

SAIGON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Savage fighting along the Cambodian border, in the Central Highlands and the northern provinces cost the enemy 739 dead, most of them in Tayninh Province northwest of Saigon, Allied spokesmen said today.

Kennedy circulated in the Democratic platform committee today a compromise dovish plan on Vietnam calling for a halt in the bombing of North Vietnam, a cease-fire and negotiations between the Saigon Government and the National Liberation Front, the political arm of the Vietcong.

HUALLANCA, Peru -- The Callejon de Huaylas is being groomed by Peru's Tourist Bureau as a spectacle of grandeur second only to the ruined pre-Incan city at Machu Picchu. The Callejon, which means "alley," is indeed spectacular: A corridor that winds for 100 miles between two mountain chains of the Andes, the Cordillera Blanca (snow-capped mountains) and the Cordillera Negra (black mountains, which, in fact, are rusty brown).

CLIFTON, N. J., Aug. 29 -- The touring golf pros continue to nibble away at their $6-million pie tomorrow when they tee off in the $150,000 Thunderbird Classic at the Upper Montclair Country Club. First prize is $30,000.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 29 -- The Harness Horse Breeders of New York State, a group of horsemen whose enrollment list in the last decade has grown from half a dozen to 400, claimed today a world record for purse disbursement for two afternoons of standard bred racing at a fairground.

William Zeckendorf Sr., the real estate executive whose buildings helped shape the New York skyline, filed a petition yesterday for an arrangement with creditors under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- The chairman of the New Hampshire delegation to the Democratic National Convention was dragged in handcuffs out of the International Amphitheatre tonight after he had inserted a credit card into the electronic machine that validates credentials for admittance to the convention.

A legal attack on a special citizens' committee set up to screen candidates for 17 State Supreme Court judgeships in Manhattan and the Bronx was rebuffed yesterday by a justice of the Appellate Division and a judge of the Court of Appeals.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- A new campaign button appeared at the Democratic National Convention today. It was blank.

Five members of a Canadian family and a family friend who were removed from a schooner in distress in the Atlantic arrived here yesterday aboard the liner Franconia, which rescued them.

TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 30 (AP) -- A $16-million suit against Dow Jones Co., two aides to Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr., a Florida Land Sales Board official and a Wall Street Journal reporter was dismissed in Hillsborough County Circuit Court today.

PRAGUE, Aug. 30 -- A heavy sadness has descended on this beautiful city, which Goethe described as "a gem in the crown of the world." WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -Mortgage purchases by the Federal National Mortgage Association's secondary market operation provided financing for 165,000 housing units in the last fiscal year, the agency reported today.

The surprise defeat of Senator Ernest Gruening in the Democratic primary signals the end of an era in Alaskan history and politics. Dr. Gruening was more responsible than any other for Alaska's achievement of statehood in 1959. He embraced that cause soon after he "discovered" Alaska as an Interior Department official in 1933, bringing to it all the fervor and energy that had marked an earlier career as a crusading journalist.

DURING his seven years as Secretary of Defense -- from January, 1961, to his resignation last February -- Robert S. McNamara was second in power and responsibility only to the two Presidents at whose pleasure he served. To many, myself included, he was, with the possible exception of Robert F. Kennedy, the most complex, arresting and intriguing figure in high appointive position in the two Administrations.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- The Vatican told bishops in a letter before publication of the papal condemnation of birth control that it would cause "bitterness" but urged them to present convincing arguments in support.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended with slight losses yesterday after late profit taking erased many of the earlier gains.
AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 3 -- Junior college enrollment is expected to increase substantially over the next seven years, according to an Administration study released today.

Steel production took its tenth consecutive weekly decline last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

ALBANY, Sept. 4 -- Five hospitals in New York State with semiprivate rates of more than $100 a day are among those whose increased rate schedules have been approved by the state for Medicaid reimbursement.

Gary Lane, a big quarterback who likes to run, was acquired by the New York Giants yesterday in a trade with the Cleveland Browns for a future draft choice. The Giants stayed within the current player limit of 43 by placing Tom Kennedy, their third quarterback, on waivers.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

Forster's prudent fraction, for Amaury de Riencourt. He is a fearless futurist. All moaning doomsters to the contrary notwithstanding, the world is quite likely to go on.

Stressing that language is the bridge that connects us, she analyzed syntax -- ordinarily a dreary procedure -- in terms of its components: each of the parts of speech and each of the symbols of punctuation were defined in verse that conveyed the principles of grammar soundly and amusingly in such a way as to stretch reasoning.

Paul Hoffmann's Thunderhead and William Heine's Jet Stream got away to the best starts in the two main divisions of the City Island Yacht Club's 33d annual 70-mile race to Stratford Shoal and back yesterday.

CERVIA, Italy -- "Now people will come here, not only to have fun and chase beautiful girls, but also to win $5,000." The local shopkeeper grinned broadly as he described Cervia's newest lure: A prize to the person who can water-ski across the Adriatic from Pula, Yugoslavia, to Cervia in the shortest time.
St. LOUIS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Gaylond Perry pitched a five-hitter today and the San Francisco Giants whipped St. Louis, 5-1, for their third straight victory over the National League leading Cardinals.

Vive la France! Certainly, rive Orly Airport! After the agonies of many "ins and outs" at Kennedy International Airport this summer, it was an untold pleasure to arrive at Orly Airport in Paris yesterday (Aug. 22) -- a pleasure to which trans-Atlantic and even domestic passengers are entitled, but have grown not to expect.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A. J. Foyt Jr. of Houston won the annual Hoosier Hundred auto race for the fifth time today before a record crowd of 30,358.
NOATAK, Alaska -- This Eskimo village of 250 persons and 189 dogs has fared better this summer than many other native settlements in Alaska.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 7 -- The Israeli Government has launched an intensive educational campaign to try to heal the wounds opened between Israeli Jew and Israeli Arab in the wake of the fatal bombing this week in Tel Aviv.
RED HOUSE, W. Va., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Seven-year-old Matthew Spritz, his life one of near torture because of daily bronchial asthma attacks, came to Bronco Junction two months ago.
CAPETOWN, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- A surgical team led by Dr. Christiaan Barnard transplanted the heart of a pregnant black woman into the chest of a white former policeman tonight.
TOKYO, Sept. 7. -- Probably as much as anyone can, Miss Teruho Matsunaga represents a fusion of old and new elements in this nation in transition.

From what I had read of Zoe Caldwell in "The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie," I had expected to see a fine performance. I had not expected, as I found, one of the finest characterizations I have seen in over 30 years of theatergoing.

FRA ELBERTUS, as Elbert Hubbard sometimes called himself, he of the flowing locks and billowing cravat, the copious pen and tongue, was originally a soap salesman of high attainments. He was able to abandon the gimmicks and premiums of his trade (kerosene lamps, button hooks for high-button shoes, perfume and celluloid collars) when he was 36 years old and become, as he described it, "Inspector General of the Universe."

Paul O'Dwyer, Democratic candidate for the Senate, called on Senator Jacob Javits yesterday to repudiate the "continuing attacks on the right of Americans to dissent" made, he said, by Spiro Agnew, Republican candidate for Vice President.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept 7 (UPI) -- The California Angels announced today that Fred Haney would retire as general manager of the American League club at the end of the year, giving rise to speculation that field manager Bill Rigney, the field manager, would succeed him.
THERE are many reasons for planting small flowering trees. They provide shade for a small terrace, spring bloom, an accent in a shrub bed or a change of texture among evergreens.
STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 7 -- Lady Post, who rode Concorde to the green jumper championship at the North Shore Horse Show today, can almost anticipate the first question from a stranger.
BONN, Sept. 7 -- A group of young progressives attending the Catholic convention in Essen announced today that they would try to carry their fight against orthodoxy into each inividual parish.

Far Hills, N.J., Sept. 7 -- A striking black standard poodle, Ch Rimskittle Rampant, owned by Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Clark of Cecilton, MD., captured her first all-breed best in show tonight at the Far Hills Fairgrounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Dr. Robert Q. Marston, the new director of the National Institutes of Health, is optimistic over the future of the enterprise, one of the world's greatest medical research organizations. But he is seriously concerned over present financial problems in recruiting staff members.
WASHINGTON -- Every morning, on his way from the bedroom to the dining room in his new million-dollar-plus mansion, David Lloyd Kreeger passes through the Great Hall.

It is foolish to insist, as some do, that music cannot be enjoyed properly without the ability to read, or at least follow, a score. On the other hand, it is just as pig-headed to dismiss score-carrying at concerts as cultural one-upmanship akin to cork-sniffing in restaurants.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A Youngstown widow sued Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard and the Youngstown Osteopathic Hospital for $430,000 today in the death of her husband, Samuel Lopez.

MOST perennials can be planted in the fall, and should be, for autumn weather is ideal for root growth, plants' main concern at this time of year. Planting can start in September or whenever new plants arrive from nurseries and can continue into November in most regions. The earlier the planting date, the better, so orders should be placed promptly. Most will be shipped in October.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 7 -- Nassau County Executive Eugene Nickerson proposed today that the county's three towns be abolished and that their powers be transferred to villages to give the residents a greater voice in local government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Shots were exchanged across the alley behind the Washington office of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee this morning in the third outbreak of violence there in as many days.

SANHO, South Vietnam, Sept. 8 (AP) -- United States paratroopers, who lost 12 killed and 21 wounded in a furious fight for this village, set fire to most of its huts today as they swept through after enemy troops had pulled out.

CAPETOWN, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The world's latest heart transplant patient, Pieter Johannes Smith, was fully conscious today, 12 hours after his operation, and asking his doctors if he could get out of bed.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 8 -Every evening during Copenhagen's Tivoli season, running from the beginning of May until mid-September hundreds of Copenhageners and visitors watch one of the strangest and most venerable free entertainments in the world -- the Tivoli Pantomime.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Horst Kwech, born in Austria and reared in Australia, won his first major professional auto race today when he captured the $20,000 Mission Bell Trophy race of the Trans-American sedan series.
GLADSTONE, N. J., Sept. 8 -- Potomac Alegre, owned and ridden by Collette Stevens of Gaithersburg, Md., won the American Horse Shows association intermediate dressage championship today.

The concert at Town Hall last night was billed as a "folk-jazz" presentation, a vague smudging of identification that turned out to almost accurate. The two featured performers -- Bill Lee, a bassist and composer, and Lance Hayward, pianist -- dealt in music that was somewhat folk-rooted, somewhat jazz-tinged and sometimes splashy, middle-aged pop.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, said today that he would move to discharge the Senate Judiciary Committee if it did not take steps toward reporting out the nomination of Abe Fortas as Chief Justice of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The sentiment of Jewish youth, including many activists in campus rebellions and other "anti-establishment" revolts, is not to withdraw from Judaism. What many of them do reject are the "corporate institutions" of present-day Jewish life.

ST. CHARLES, Mo., Sept. 8 -- While Wallace for President signs are blossoming like goldenrod across the rolling hills of Missouri, the two candidates for the Senate are puzzled and concerned about what impact this new political force will have on their race.
NEW CASSEL, L.I., Sept. 8 (UPI) -- A mob of 25 to 30 men attacked two Nassau County patrolmen and took their prisoner away in front of a bar here last night.

Members of a citizen judicial screening committee, upset over what they consider a "double-cross" by political leaders, may "go back into business" this week as an action group seeking structural changes in the method of selecting judges.
MIAMI, Sept. 8 -- Educational television will begin in Cuba tomorrow, with regular classes at junior and senior high schools, the Havana radio announced today.
Norton Simon, Inc., announced yesterday operating earnings of $46,884,000, or $1.95 a share, for the 12 months ended June 30.

THORPE BAY, England, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Yankee Flyer, the United States challenger, defeated Lady Helmsman of Britain today in the second race of the international catamaran trophy series, known as the Little America's Cup.
A group of 11 four-story town houses, the first such group of single-family dwellings built in Manhattan in several decades, will rise on 67th Street between Second and Third Avenues.
A 25 per cent loss of capital sounds painful by any standard. That is almost what the pace of inflation has sneaked away from the value of the dollar in terms of living costs in the past decade.

Several maritime industry groups have urged the Senate Commerce Committee to schedule hearings this month on a long-pending and controversial measure that would bar vessels converted abroad from use as carriers of defense cargoes.
ERFURT, East Germany, Sept. 8 -- "Ask him," the Soviet soldier said, nudging his shy comrade forward "go ahead, ask him!"

A 70-mile race around Stratford Shoal and back, the 33d annual event of the City Island Yacht Club, was won yesterday by Dr. Walter Neumann's 40-foot sloop, Sitzmark IV, from the New York Athletic Club Yacht Club.

River-watching along the eastern edge of Manhattan can be a desultory pleasure these September days, especially toward evening when the sky is changing and the wind coming off the water is often strong and cool.

HOLMDEL, N. J., Sept. 8 -- The recently formed team of Gerry Mulligan and Dave Brubeck made its first appearance near New York City last night, playing during the second and final evening of the Garden State Art Center Jazz Festival.

BOSTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Boston Beacons completed their first, and possibly only, season in the North American Soccer League by edging the Baltimore Bays, 1-0, today before 3,764 fans at Fenway Park.
PURPLE prune plums from the Northwest -- sometimes called Italian prune plums -- will be available in quantity in local markets from now until early October.

MONZA, Italy, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The defending world champion, Denis Hulme of New Zealand, driving a McLaren-Ford, outlasted his accident-prone rivals today to win the Grand Prix of Italy Formula One race. It was his first victory this season.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8 -- Steel men are talking about a market slump deeper than had been expected.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Jim Lefebvre got four straight hits, including his fifth homer and a run-scoring double, as the Los Angeles Dodger stopped the Cincinnati Reds, 3-2, today.
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 8 -- Huey P. Newton, the 26-year-old Black Panther leader, was convicted tonight of voluntary manslaughter in the killing of an Oakland policeman, John Frey.
PARIS, Sept. 8 (Reuters) -- The University of Paris tonight closed the left-bank headquarters from which medical students were organizing a boycott of examinations.

Julie Harris, last seen on Broadway in "Skyscraper" three years ago, returns to the local stage in the starring role of "Forty Carats," a comedy which Jay Allen has based on the Parisian hit by Pierre Barillet and Jean Pierre Gredy, the original authors of "Cactus Flower.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 -- The New York Jets, having finished their interleague adventures, turn now to the sticky part of the season -- the 14 games that count for the American Football League championship.

The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee said yesterday that its national chairman, Phil Hutchins, was among seven persons arrested in St. Louis following a rally Saturday night. Mr. Hutchins -- along with John Wilson, national deputy chairman of the Black Anti-War Anti-Draft Union; Charles Koen, a student committee representative, and four members of the St. Louis-based Black Liberators -- was charged with "unlawful assembly and making inflammatory statements that could lead to illegal activities."

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Red Lion an Sun, the Iranian Red Cross, has put the death toll in the devastating earthquake last weekend at "nearly 10,000." An earlier figure issued by the organization placing the death toll at 10,588 was "gladly reduced to nearly 10,000" since some who fled had been found.
RICHMOND, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Richard Petty, driving a Plymouth, led for 216 of the 300 laps and fought off a challenge by David Pearson today to win the Capital City 300 stock car race.
MEDELLIN, Colombia, Sept. 8 -- The Roman Catholic bishops of Latin America have made a series of recommendations that could have a profound influenced on the internal reform of their church.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Phil Gagliano laced a run-scoring pinch single in the 11th inning today to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 3-2 victory over San Francisco. The triumph snapped the Cards' losing streak at four games.
EUGENE, Ore., Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Sandra Haynie of Fort Worth shot a two-over-par 74 today, but captured the $12,500 Pacific women's golf tourney by three strokes, with a 54-hole score of 213.
The Israel Bond organization opened a campaign yesterday to sell $100-million in State of Israel bonds by the end of the year to strengthen that country's economy.

The season on the city's grass and concrete is coming to a close with a crescendo of music, theater, dancing and storytelling after a triumphant summer of activities in Central, Prospect and other borough parks. What in past summers had been interim and cooling-it entertainment has developed into a regularly accepted series of programs, thanks to the newly integrated Administration of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 8 -- The military command of the Egyptian armed forces announced tonight that it would launch, beginning today, "preventive defense operations" against Israeli military positions along the eastern bank of the Suez Canal.

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- The West German film "Artists at the Top of the Big Top" ("Die Artisten in der Zirkuskuppel") won the top prize at the Venice Film Festival tonight. The American John Cassavetes's "Faces" took a total of five awards.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8 -- Things did not go well for the New York Mets today in their final game of the season at Forbes Field. They lost to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-0, even though they got eight men into scoring position. And Tom Seaver took his 10th defeat of the season because he made three highly unsuccessful pitches.
LONDON, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Brian Huggett of Wales beat John Panton, 1 up, today to win the News of the World match-play golf tournament.

J. J. McFall, vice president of Columbus Line, announced yesterday that his company has been appointed general agents in North America for the Brodin Line. He said the arrangement would help to provide more frequent and combined sailings.
Captain Hawley MacDermid, one of the Grace Line's most versatile shipmasters, retired last week after 38 years of service with the company.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Dave McNally kept Baltimore's slim pennant hopes alive today, defeating the Chicago White Sox, 3-2, with a four-hitter. The triumph was the left-handed pitcher's 20th and extended his winning streak to 12.
A National Academy of Sciences committee has published a reasoned, and in many respects persuasive, study calling for greater governmental use and support of the social sciences.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Rebellious Negro bus drivers rejected today a court-proposed agreement aimed at ending a wildcat strike against the Chicago Transit Authority. But the worst transportation tieup in more than a year was apparently averted when Negro rapid transit workers called off a scheduled sympathy walkout.

Howard Butcher 3d, a director of the Penn Central Company and the Philadelphia-based brokerage house of Butcher Sherrerd, has denied illegally using inside information in trading the railroad's stock last summer.

The 90-member American Ballet Theater left here yesterday for Tokyo. The company will begin a four-week tour of four Japanese cities with a performance of "Swan Lake" at the Tokyo Bunga Kaikan Theater on Saturday.
Virginia Wade, a nonprofessional from Britain, upset Mrs. Billie Jean King yesterday in the women's singles final of the $100,000 United States Open tennis championships at Forest Hills, Queens.

WHERE does the gray flannel elevator go? Straight to the gray flannel fashion show. Of course, there are other things, too, at Abercrombie Fitch's "Gallery of Fall Fashion" on the second floor: sherry, fruit and cheese; fur, leather and tweed; pants, pants and even an occasional skirt.

James Farmer, who is running for Congress in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section, proposed yesterday the nationwide sale of government-guaranteed bonds to provide "seed money" for local development corporations in economically distressed areas.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 8 -- Syracuse University's 10 opponents this fall are well-aware of the strong defense they will face. Even the cagey Ben Schwartzwalder, starting his 20th season as the Syracuse coach, can't soft-peddle his defensive unit, which has most of the players back who made the Orange defense one of the best in the nation last year.

MANILA, Sept. 8 -- The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization marked its 14th anniversary today. President Ferdinand E. Marcos said in an anniversary statement that such pacts served to discourage aggressive aims.
Doyle Dane Bernbach has announced the appointment of John Leonard, vice president, as a management suvisor.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 8 -- President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz, in a report to the nation last Sunday, remarked ruefully, "We had been provincially proud and ingenuously satisfied that, in a world of juvenile disturbances, Mexico was an untouched island."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Businessmen have trimmed their spending plans for new plant and equipment this year, but their estimates are still running ahead of last year's outlays.

WILLISTON PARK, L. I., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Debora Collins, 14 years old, was electrocuted at about 8 P.M. yesterday while crossing the tracks of the Long Island Rail Road at the nearby East Williston station. The police said she tripped and fell on the railroad's electrified third rail.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city's schools would reopen as scheduled today, but the president of the United Federation of Teachers said that his union's 55,000 members would be on strike.

The Most Rev. Anthony Pantin, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Port of Spain, Trinidad and the first native of the West Indies to be raised to the hierachy, preached and celebrated solemn mass yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
NOROTON, Conn., Sept. 8 -- Bill Shaw of the Marblehead Yacht Club won the Noroton Y. C. three-race Lightning Class regatta today.
STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 8 -- Chumbo won the final class, then went on to beat out Gustavus in a jumpoff today to capture the open jumper championship at the North Shore Horse Show.

Msgr. Francis J. Mugavero, Bishop-designate of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, said yesterday that there were no theological barriers to either the institution of a married priesthood or the recognition of women as priests.
CAIRO, Sept. 8 -- Egyptian communiques said today that the Israelis opened fire at 4:15 P.M. on the city of Suez and that Egyptian guns replied strongly.

MASTER PAUL BRANDTS of New York, a former state champion, won the second brilliancy prize during the recent United States open chess tournament at Aspen, Colo. He took the prize for his victory as White in a Queen's Gambit Accepted against Master Edward Formanek of Berwyn, Ill.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- It is "essential" that the United States back up its policy of fiscal restraint with monetary restraint as well, the International Monetary Fund warned today.

Top Republican leaders in the state are generally pleased with the prospect of Governor Rockefeller's appointment of Representative Charles E. Goodell to the Senate seat vacated by the death of Robert F. Kennedy.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Danny Cater and Bert Campaneris powered an 18-hit attack to lead the Oakland Athletics to a 10-2 triumph over Cleveland today behind the five-hit hurling of Jim Hunter.

GENEVA, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that it flew 80 tons of food and medicine into Biafra during the night. Planes from Switzerland, Sweden, Denmark, Norway and Finland carried the supplies in nine flights from Fernando Po.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Following are excerpts from a statement today by Richard M. Nixon at the convention of B'nai B'rith:
CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Billy Williams got four straight hits today, including his 25th and 26th home runs of the year, as he paced the Chicago Cubs to a 10-3 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies.

A jeweler's tray containing 84 watches with a retail value of $60,000 was stolen from Bloomingdale's Saturday, the police reported yesterday. The watches were stolen five minutes before the store closed at 6 P. M. while a salesman had his back turned, the police said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Hubert H. Humphrey defined the 1968 campaign today as a "referendum on human rights" and charged that Richard M. Nixon and George C. Wallace were in competition against him, trying to exploit "the fears and hates aroused by this issue."

NDOLA, Zambia, Sept. 6 -- At a luncheon meeting of the Lions Club here the other day, a visiting Rhodesian looked around for a moment at the white faces in the room and then said to his host: "I see you don't have any Africans in your club either."

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- An Old English Sheepdog came out of the West to take top honors at one of the East's prestige dog shows today. He was Ch. Prince Andrew of Sherline, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Howard Sherline of Detroit and he won the massive Strathglass Memorial Challenge Trophy as best among 2,930 dogs at the Westchester Kennel Club Show at Croton Point Park.
SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Dave Hemion scored a basket with two seconds left tonight to give the Western Washington State College a 58-56 triumph over the Australian Olympic basketball team.

BUFFALO, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- R. C. Gamble, a rookie halfback, made a 45-yard touchdown run and Gino Cappelletti kicked three field goals today as the Boston Patriots whipped the Buffalo Bills, 16-7, in the season opener for both American Football League clubs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- When it is in neutral, you can watch Walter Cronkite on TV. You can drive it without a steering wheel. The seats have massage units to reduce driving fatigue (or jiggle you to sleep), the tires light up at night, and if a carnapper tries to break into all this luxury, the doors give him an electric shock.

MONTREAL, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Gaetan Paris, Canada's second and longest surviving heart transplant patient, was back in the hospital today after having suffered a cut head in an early morning car collision.
The youth revolution has even spilled over into professional football.
WOMEN who aren't satisfied simply with gloves to keep their hands warm in the winter months ahead have it made this year. Something even more chic is back -- the fur muff.

A plea for continuing improvements in the nation's highway system to handle the tremendous upsurge in passenger and freight traffic anticipated by 1980 has been made by the American Trucking Association, the trade organization of the motor carrier industry.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Graig Nettles, a rookie, hit a three-run homer -- his fourth homer in three days -- today to give Dean Chance and the Minnesota Twins a 3-1 victory over the American League-leading Detroit Tigers.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept. 8 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Suffolk County Police Department today announced the arrest last night of two brothers, their sister-in-law and another man in the investigation of the $50,000 robbery of the South Setauket branch of the Tinker National Bank on July 22.

WARSAW, Sept. 8 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, the leader of the Polish Communist regime, warned Czechoslovakia today that a "difficult and perhaps long road" lay ahead before she recovered from "counterrevolutionary and antisocialist damage."

DETROIT, Sept. 8 -- Miss Bardahl, an unlimited hydroplane sponsored by the company that makes an additive motor oil for automobiles, seemed to have luck today as she won the $40,000 Gold Cup race for the fifth time in the last six years.

ATLANTA, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Southern Christian Leadership Conference threw its active support behind the Atlanta garbage strike today as Mayor Ivan Allen Jr. declared that strikers must return to work or be dismissed.
ROME, Sept. 8 -- Pope Paul VI today called for "good men, united and strong," to meet the challenges of the "difficult and bitter days" ahead.
MIAMI, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Cuba's sugar harvest, the source of most of her dollars, is estimated by exile economists at the relatively low figure of slightly more than 5 million tons for this year.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 8 (UPI) -- The California Angels scored three runs in the first inning today and held on to defeat the Boston Red Sox, 3-2.
TORONTO, Sept. 8 -- The Ashby Players, a Negro theater company without professional credentials or pretensions, have achieved a measure of success in their first venture beyond their native Detroit.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 8 (Reuters) -- Policemen using tear gas arrested 100 people when a crowd of Sikhs marched on a rival meeting her today in a dispute over organization of a temple.
A New York City Opera Company musician offered a reward of unspecified amount yesterday for return of a $3,000 viola, a Besiato model made in Naples in 1862, which was lost or stolen last Tuesday.
Sperry Hutchinson Co. has reached an agreement in principle to acquire the business of Western Girl, Inc., a temporary help concern and its affiliated companies.

State Supreme Court Justice James A Roe Jr. was killed and his two sons were seriously injured yesterday when their chartered plane was struck from above by a second plane as both aircraft were attempting to land at Flushing Airport in Queens.

LIEGE, Belgium, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Jan Koudelka of Czechoslovakia defeated Steve Tidball of Beverley Hills, Calif., 1-6, 6-1, 6-2, today in the men's singles final of an international tennis tournament. In the women's final, Tidball's fiancee, Carol Sheriff of Australia, defeated Jeanne Salome of the Netherlands, 6-2, 6-0.
TOKYO, Sept. 8 -- Japan these days is in a position somewhat like that of a rich man who worries that he isn't carrying enough cash in his pocket.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Los Angeles was selected by the United States Olympic Committee today to represent the United States in international bidding for the 1976 Olympics. Los Angeles will make its bid in Amsterdam before the International Olympic Committee in 1970.

DACHAU, West Germany, Sept. 8 (Reuters) -- Fifty young Socialists shouting anti-American and antimilitary slogans interrupted the unveiling of a monument at the former Dachau concentration camp today.

It should be permissible to remove a beating human heart for transplantation, provided there is unmistakable evidence that the person's brain is dead, several surgeons said here yesterday at a symposium on heart transplants.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 8 (Reuters) -- The Manhattan Rugby Club of New York lost, 18-8, today in the third game of its South American tour to Club Universitario de Buenos Aires. The game was tied 8-8 at the half.

Firemen, whose contract with the city expires on Sept. 30, will seek a pension after 15 years of work, or added benefits under the present 20-year pension regulation, Michael Maye, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A high-priority telephone cable into the Great Lakes Naval Training Center was severed by saboteurs early today, the struck Illinois Bell Telephone Company said. The cutting, about 40 miles north of Chicago, temporarily interrupted national security communications, Bell said. Telephone officials said the cable had apparently been cut by an ax.
The Corporation Counsel's office has informed the city that it need not pay Medicaid fees to supervising doctors in teaching hospitals.
The Defense Department says it still needs McGuire Air Force Base in Wrightstown, N. J., "for the foreseeable future," it was disclosed over the weekend by the Port of New York Authority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A long-awaited report, released late last week by a White House committee, sheds light on present Government policy concerning the ownership of patents resulting from Federal research and development contracts.

Two automobiles, trailed for hours by detectives, made a rendezvous in the Bronx early yesterday. The police moved in, arrested the drivers and, they said, seized $6-million worth of heroin.

THROUGHOUT most of the United States open tennis championships, she was announced as "Mrs. Wade" and her age was declared to be 28, but yesterday 23-year-old Sarah Virginia Wade, who has "no steady boy friend," established her identity as the winner of the $6,000 first prize in the women's division.
Sheldon Harrison and Owen M. Quattlebaum have been named vice presidents of the Bank of New York in the corporate agencies and investment divisions, respectively, it was announced over the weekend.
HOLLYWOOD, Sept., 8 (AP) -- Leon Uris, the author of "Exodus," and Marjorie Edwards, a jewelry designer, were married today in Temple Israel Rabbi Meyer Heller performed the ceremony.

While the nation focused its attention on the Republican convention in Miami Beach and the Democratic convention in Chicago, George C. Wallace was out quietly rounding up the petitions that his followers say will put him on the ballot in at least 34 of the 50 states.

Free performances of "The Municipal Water System Is Not Trustworthy," a new play by Tom Andersen, will be given Sept. 16 and 17 and twice on Sept. 23 at the Sullivan Street Playhouse. Reservations may be made by calling Ch. 3-3880 or JU 2-1427.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Finance and Economics Ministers of the European Economic Community plan to discuss proposed reforms of the International Monetary Fund at their regular meeting in Rotterdam tomorrow and Tuesday.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 8 (UPI) -- Gary Player, the British Open champion, sank an 8-foot birdie putt on the fourth hole of a sudden-death playoff with Bob Goalby, the Masters titleholder, today to win the first prize of $50,000 in the seventh annual World Series of Golf.

The U.S. Life Holding Corporation has reached a preliminary agreement to acquire Inter-County Title Guaranty Mortgage Co., a title insurer. The transaction would involve more than $7-million in stock, according to the announcement made over the weekend.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that public-service strikes could not be eliminated by law and called for the creation of "impartial" bodies to work out binding settlements in such disputes.

Seaboard World Airlines announced yesterday the election of Capt. Harry L. Clark as vice president for flight operations, effective Oct. 7, upon his retirement from American Airlines. Captain Clark, who joined American in 1936 as a co-pilot, has held a number of flight administrative positions with that carrier.
THE ISSUES: The major demands of the United Federation of Teachers include the following:

Nicholas Kisburg, a labor-union critic of current welfare policies, proposed yesterday that the state raise the minimum wage to at least $2.50 an hour and then act to jail "natural or legal fathers who illegally abandon their children."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Premier Tran Van Huong said today that if South Vietnam does not solve its corruption problem it will fall to the Communists. In 16 years "China was lost to the Communists because of governmental corruption," Mr. Huong told military administrative affairs students.

Frank A. Nemec, president of Lykes Bros. Steamship Company, Inc., has been named chairman of the water carrier panel of the Transportation Association of America. Mr. Nemec succeeds Alexander Purdon who recently resigned as president of United States Lines. J. W. Hershey, president of Commercial Barge Lines, Inc., is currently serving as vice chairman of the panel.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 7 -- About the only problem for Richard M. Nixon in Ohio is that his first campaign visit here is scheduled for Friday the 13th of September.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 8 -- Mr. and Mrs. Everett Smith Jr. gave a tea dance at the Belle Haven Club here today for their daughter, Miss Pamela Putnam Smith. The debutante, a graduate of Miss Porter's School in Farmington, will attend Briarcliff College.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The National Federation of Priests' Councils asked Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle today to name an impartial panel to reconsider the dismissal of a Washington Roman Catholic priest.

Bronx District Attorney Isidore Dollinger and State Senator Ivan Warner were rejected for the State Supreme Court by a citizen's screening committee because of their separate involvement in two controversial cases.
The Bankers Trust Company announced yesterday the election of John S. DeJose as vice president and general counsel and of Richard S. Denny as vice president and secretary.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Federal Reserve Board agreed today to supply a quarterly report to Congress on monetary and financial developments, including the money supply but not limited to it.
DETROIT, Sept. 9 -- General Motors Corporation's Pontiac division showed its 1969 cars to the press today, disclosing a new medium-priced sporty car and a number of new safety features.

Fritz Peterson does not want to know that his earned-run average is down to 2.68 or that he has issued one unintentional walk in his last five games. Such statistical awareness got him in trouble in the first place.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Bobby Foster, the world light-heavyweight champion, slashed open Roger Rouse's face in almost half a dozen places and scored a fifth-round technical knockout in their nontitle bout tonight.
VIENNA, Sept. 9 (Reuters) -- The Czechoslovak Government broadcast today an appeal to all Czechoslovak citizens abroad not to delay their return home.

Walter W. Heller, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations and a key adviser to Vice President Humphrey in the current election campaign, said yesterday that a "softening" in the economy was already visible.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A House-Senate conference committee approved today a $1.9billion foreign aid authorization bill -- $1-billion less than President Johnson had requested and the smallest amount since the program began in 1946.
After 44 years with J. Walter Thompson, Norman H. Strouse, the board chairman, is leaving the business. Leaving the city. Leaving the state.
Nino Benvenuti, who lost the world middleweight championship the first time he undertook to defend it, apparently is in no hurry to risk losing it a second time.
BUCHAREST, Sept. 9 (AP) -- President Nicolae Ceausescu, soaked to the skin by a thunderstorm, told a youth rally today that his independent-minded regime would never betray its Communist allies.

PARIS, Sept. 9 -- A dry, persistent cough that made President de Gaulle pause more than a dozen times today during his 75-minute news conference spoiled the impression he usually gives of an unshakable man in perfect control.
Criminal Court Judge Jack Rosenberg, in a ruling described as the first of its kind here, declared yesterday that a defendant in a misdemeanor case was entitled to a trial by jury.

HAYATNAGAR, India, Sept. 6 -- The downtrodden villagers called harijans, traditionally considered untouchables, could rarely afford meat. When the rains failed here, almost in the center of India, in June, they gave it up altogether.
The election of Harlow W. Gage as a vice president of the General Motors Corporation and general manager of the overseas operations division, effective Oct. 1, was announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9--The Soviet leadership, clearly haunted by the specter of the democratization that it restrained in Czechoslovakia, has conscripted all areas of culture in an effort to thwart the emergence of any similar ideas threatening to the Communist party's ideology and dominance.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 9 (UPI) -- James A. Roe Jr., the New York Supreme Court Justice who was killed in a two-plane collision yesterday, was acquitted today of charges of bribing two policemen who had stopped him for a traffic offense.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- A new policeman was fatally wounded today by a shotgun blast fired from an apartment house after he responded with other officers to complaints that an armed man was terrorizing the neighborhood.

PRAGUE, Sept. 9 -- Vasily V. Kuznetsov, the Soviet First Deputy Foreign Minister, met today with Gustav Husak, the Slovak party chief, in a continuing round of conversations with Czechoslovak leaders.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy (SANE) said today that it would organize "truth squads" to raise major issues in the Presidential campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk suggested today that while some American troop reductions in Vietnam might be possible eventually, it was too soon to be specific on when such withdrawals might begin.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 94 on Friday from a revised level of 93.9 on Thursday.

The New York Metropolitan Section of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers has scheduled its first meeting of the 1968-69 season for Thursday at 5 P.M. in the Brass Rail Restaurant, Fifth Avenue and 43d Street. Ship propulsion performance and how to measure it will be discussed.

PRAGUE, Sept. 9 -- The Sovietled invasion of Czechoslovakia last month provided Western observers with the first opportunity since World War II to watch the Soviet army in a situation of combat readiness on a large scale.

Genesco, Inc., the country's largest apparel manufacturer, reported yesterday the highest sales and earnings in its history for the fiscal year ended July 31, with a 27 per cent gain in net income on a 16 per cent sales gain.

FLINT, Mich., Sept. 9 (UPI) -- A United Auto Workers official expressed surprise and concern today after learning that a union local had broken with tradition and endorsed George C. Wallace for President.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Bill Sudakis, playing in his seventh major league game, blasted a grand slam in an eight-run second inning tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers crushed the St. Louis Cardinals, 10-1.

A Louis Harris poll reported yesterday that 81 per cent of voters questioned in a national sampling agreed with the statement "law and order has broken down in this country." The poll reported only 14 per cent disagreed and 5 per cent said they were not sure.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Sept. 9 (AP) -- A general court- martial sentenced Lance Cpl. Denzil R. Allen of the Marine Corps to life in prison today in the killing of five Vietnamese civilians near Hue. The court also ordered a dishonorable discharge, forfeiture of pay and allowances, and reduction to the rank of private.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Representative Howard W. Robison, Republican of upstate New York, introduced today a bill to authorize the creation of community development corporations in urban and rural areas of low income and high unemployment. The corporations would then own and manage production enterprises in inner city areas.
The Northrop Corporation had record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended July 31 for the third successive year, the company reported yesterday.

GENEVA, Sept. 9 (Reuters) -- Informed sources here said today that planes of the International Committee of the Red Cross made nine mercy flights to Biafra during the night, taking 87 tons of relief supplies to the starving population.
NEWPORT, Ky., Sept. 9 (UPI) -- City Manager Donald Roney today carried out his threat announced last week and dismissed 78 public works employes because they refused to end their strike.

THE 16 teams of the National Football League made their final cuts yesterday, reducing squads to a maximum of 40 players prior to the opening of the season this weekend. Trades and injuries also made it a busy day.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- The New African nation of Swaziland today formally requested membership as the 125th state in the United Nations. Swaziland became independent of Britain last Friday.
DETROIT, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Warner Gardner, injured when his powerboat flew into the air and disintegrated as it smashed into the Detroit River in yesterday's Gold Cup race, died today.

PRAGUE, Sept. 9 -- A news-reel produced by the Government's film studios is giving the people of Czechoslovakia the opportunity to see a pictorial record of the Soviet-led occupation of Prague and the negotiations before and after.

ARTHUR ASHE reached center court at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday for the final of the first United States open championship tournament. Even before his racquet had sped a ball in the direction of Tom Okker, the dynamic national amateur king had reached a rare peak of eminence.

James L. Buckley stuffed a paperback copy of the President's Riot Commission report, an issue of National Review and a wad of notes pencilled on yellow legal paper into a briefcase yesterday and prepared to move into a new office above the Conservative party headquarters at 468 Park Avenue South.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Louis Tiant pitched a five-hitter and struck out 16 batters tonight to score his 20th victory of the season as the Cleveland Indians downed the Minnesota Twins, 6-1.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 9 -- United States and South Vietnamese troops joined yesterday to smash an enemy attack in the Central Highlands, the scene of heavy fighting in the last few weeks.

Herbert Khoury, professionally known as Tiny Tim, has obtained a temporary restraining order prohibiting Bouquet Records and John Ponzillo from distributing an album titled "Concert in Fairland" and a single disk, "Be My Love," it was announced yesterday by Warner Brothers-7 Arts.
TOKYO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Yoshiaki Matsumoto, 111 1/2, Japan, outpointed Eli Aquinto, 110 1/4, of the Philippines, tonight, in a 10-round bout.

The recreation and education programs offered to New York youngsters by the Police Athletic League will get a boost next Tuesday with the help of a popular designer who spent his childhood in Milan, Italy.

Peter J. B. Stevens has been appointed president of Leasco Europa, Ltd., London, it was announced yesterday by the Leasco Data Processing Equipment Corporation, Great Neck, L. I., the parent organization. Prior to joing Leasco Europa as managing director, Mr. Stevens was vice president for marketing in Europe of the Control Data corporation.
BONN, Sept. 9 -- President Heinrich Lubke disclosed today that he might resign next March, five months before his five-year terms runs out," under appropriate circumstances."

MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 9 -- Physicists from throughout the Western world assembled here today to honor the memory of a teacher and theorist and to spend a few days seeking to look ahead down the path upon which he helped set modern physics.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Senator Robert P. Griffin, Republican of Michigan, asked the Senate Judiciary Committee today to reopen its hearings on President Johnson's nomination of Justice Abe Fortas to be Chief Justice of the United States.

SOMERSET, Pa., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Jack P. Rubin, 20 years old, of Brookville, L. I., son of Aaron Rubin, executive vice president and treasurer of the National Broadcasting Company, was killed today in an automobile accident on the Pennsylvania Turnpike.

The Rev. Philip A. Carey, an experienced labor - relations teacher at Xavier Institute, was appointed mediator yesterday to speed contract talks between the city and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 9 -- A young man who said he had defected from the Egyptian Army described today the circumstances of the abduction of an Israeli soldier last week from the east bank of the Suez Canal.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The head of the department of gynecology and obstetrics at St. Louis University said yesterday that he would continue his research on artificial contraception, despite a recent encyclical from Pope Paul VI against such methods of birth control.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The chairman or the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith cautioned the American Jewish community today not to exaggerate fears of Negro anti-Semitism.
With a pledge to heed its findings, Richard M. Nixon set up a Student Coalition yesterday to develop proposals to meet "the new issues and new concerns that will confront America."
Contract negotiations in the longshore industry were broken off yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the United States had no evidence that the crewmen of the Pueblo were about to be released.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Sept. 9 -- Ralph Johnston, unattached, took a one-stroke lead with a 33, 36 -- 69 today in the seventh Port Jefferson Open at the Harbor Hills Country Club. Par for the 6,708-yard course is 36, 36 -- 72.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- Dr. Karel Kral, the United Nations correspondent of C.T.K., the Czechoslovak news agency, has been recalled to Prague, according to a C.T.K. dispatch monitored here.
PRAGUE, Sept. 9 -- The impression of Western observers is that the Soviet forces are making no effort to disguise or hide their military equipment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Ken McMullen and Frank Howard drove in four runs with homers and Del Unser dampened a Baltimore rally with a fine defensive play tonight as the Washington Senators defeated the Orioles, 6-2.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 9 -- Usually reliable South Korean sources said today that the United States had told North Korea that it was ready to sign a document of apology in return for the release of the crewmen of the captured intelligence ship Pueblo.
PRAGUE, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Foreign Minister Jiri Hajek, who has been denounced in the Moscow press, was reported to be back in his office today and to have resumed his normal work.
SOMETIMES the longest way round turns out to be the shortest for becoming an interior decorator.

The Levin-Townsend Computer Corporation announced plans yesterday to make a tender offer for about 49 per cent of National Equities, Inc. stock on the basis of offering a $100 convertible debenture bearing 7 per cent interest for each share of National Equities.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 9 (Agence France-Presse) -- The peace talks here between Nigeria and Biafra were postponed indefinitely today.
ATLANTIC City, Sept 9 (UPI) -- Dr. Fager heads an 11-horse field drawn today for the 16th running of the invitational United Nations Handicap to be run at Atlantic City Wednesday.
The International Civil Aviation Organization's Assembly has elected Brig. Gen. A. Numa Sanchez of Argentina as its president. The Assembly is made up of 116 governments.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Dr. F. J. L. Blasingame announced today that he was resigning as executive vice president of the American Medical Association. Dr. E. B. Howard, executive vice president since 1948, will become acting executive vice president, the board of trustees reported.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Joe Gordon, the first in a long line of managers discharged during Charlie Finley's turbulent seven-year regime, was hired today to manage Kansas City's American League expansion team.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Clay Dalrymple singled with the bases loaded in the 15th inning to drive in two runs and give the Philadelphia Phils an 8-7 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight after the Phils lost a four-run lead in the ninth.

The election of Theodore F. Brophy as executive vice president and general counsel of the General Telephone Electronics Corporation, was announced yesterday. He had been vice president and general counsel since 1959.

In the conflict that led to the shutdown of the city's schools, Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, has adamantly insisted that the union was not striking against decentralization.
Most school supervisors from assistant principals to assistant superintendents stayed away from work yesterday in support of the teachers strike.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 9 -- "I've been described as a laconic New Englander," Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine told a convention of Government employes in Las Vegas today. "I've got to look that word up."

ALBANY, Sept. 9 -- Supporters of George C. Wallace for President filed petitions containing 32,524 signatures today -- almost three times the number required -- with the Secretary of State here to get the name of the former Alabama Governor on the ballot in New York next November.
Chester J. LaRoche, the president and one of the charter organizers of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame, was named yesterday the 12th recipient of the group's Gold Medal Award.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The volume of offers to sell mortgages to the Federal National Mortgage Association continued to drift downward at this week's auction, the agency reported today.
The United Federation of Teachers has listed five basic conditions that must be met before it will agree to end the strike. These are the following:

CAPE KENNEDY, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- The three Apollo 7 astronauts rehearsed emergency escapes from their spacecraft today. Afterward, Comdr. Walter M. Schirra Jr. said: "The whole system looks real good." He, Donn Eisle and Walter Cunningham are scheduled to begin their 11-day earth orbital flight Oct. 11.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Mickey Lolich hurled a two-hitter and Willie Horton, Mickey Stanley and Al Kaline slammed home runs tonight to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 6-0 victory over the California Angels and increase their American League lead to eight games.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 9 -- The Black Panthers began a propaganda campaign today for the immediate admission to bail of their minister of defense, Huery P. Newton, who was convicted last night of voluntary manslaughter of an Oakland policeman.
PARIS, Sept. 9 -- A Hanoi spokesman said at a press conference today that a call by Arthur J. Goldberg for an immediate halt in the American bombing of North Vietnam was "positive" and "realistic."

VENICE, Italy, Sept. 9 -Some months ago, Luigi Chiarini, director of the Venice Film Festival, announced his intention to resign next year. And the final week of this 29th annual Venice Festival, which ended last night, cast the entire future of film festivals into doubt.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 9 (AP) -- A petition to place Communist party candidates for President and Vice President on the November ballot in Minnesota was rejected today by Secretary of State Joseph L. Donovan.
Tibetan art, for 20 or more years hidden away in quaintly off-beat museums, is coming back into vogue.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 -- Harry J. Karafin, former investigate reporter for The Philadelphia Inquirer, went on trial here today on charges of blackmail and unlawful solicitation.
Columbia University announced yesterday that it had asked the courts to drop criminal trespass charges against 400 students arrested last spring during two police raids on occupied campus buildings.
Tests to type white blood cells are proving important in the long-term outlook for organ transplant patients, two of the world's leaders in the typing work said here yesterday.
THE DANCE OF GENGHIS COHN. By Romain Gary. Translated from the French by Mr. Gary and Camilla Sykes. 244 pages. World. $5.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- A five-year experimental project to provide driver training as an alternative to license suspensions and revocations was outlined here today by Motor Vehicle Commissioner Vincent L. Tofany.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 -Vice President Humphrey set out today on his first crosscountry journey as the Democratic nominee for President, and he had to summon all the resources of his optimistic nature to pronounce it a memorable and auspicious take-off for the White House.

Reynolds Co. said yesterday it had placed into service a new communications system that validates the price of every buy or sell order through a computer memory bank containing current market quotations.

VIENNA, Tuesday, Sept. 10 (Reuters) -- The Prague radio reported today that Premier Oldrich Cernik of Czechoslovakia and towo other ministers had left by air for talks in Moscow with Soviet officials.
ATLANTA, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Striking garbagemen set up picket lines at City Hall and at emergency dumps today in an effort to persuade Atlantans not to cooperate with emergency sanitation measures.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Administration said today it would impose a $4 minimum landing charge for all airplanes at Washington National Airport, effective Wednesday.
The new musical, "A Mother's Kisses," will have the distinction of setting a new high of $8 for the Wednesday matinee and $9 for the Saturday matinee when it opens Oct. 29.
It was business as usual for Jacques Coe yesterday although it was his 60th anniversary in the securities industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- S. I. Hayakawa, the distinguished scholar of languages, said the other day that alienation among the young may result from television. Modern children, he notes, spend an inordinate amount of time in company with the TV set: and the danger of the TV set, as he sees it, is that it offers no opportunity for "interaction."
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 -- In front of the cluttered storefront they occupy on Fillmore Street, the Black Panthers gathered early today to express their anger.

James L. Marcus, who on the day of his swearing-in as the city's Water Commissioner accepted Mayor Lindsay's congratulations and the same night secretly discussed kickback deals with a reputed Mafia leader, was sentenced yesterday to 15 months in prison for bribery conspiracy.

The election of Gavin K. MacBain and Richard J. Schwartz to the board of the Simplicity Pattern Company, Inc., was announced yesterday. Mr. MacBain is chairman and chief executive officer of the BristolMyers Company and Mr. Schwartz is president of Jonathan Logan, Inc.
The executive board of the Subway Supervisors Association voted unanimously last night to recommend a strike in its contract dispute with the Transit Authority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Imports of man-made fiber products in July were almost double those of a year ago and exceeded cotton textile imports for the first time, the Commerce Department reported today.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 9 -- Philip Santora of Westchester Hills, the 1965 winner, took a two-stroke lead for the 34th Westchester Seniors' Golf Association championship today by scoring 36, 38 -- 74 at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club.
Interest rates on top-grade corporate bonds moved up yesterday in the first major test of the market in four weeks.

The New York Stock Exchange will soon announce dates for a series of meetings to explain its proposed interim commission schedule to brokers. Last week, the Securities and Exchange Commission accepted the interim schedule proposed by the Big Board.
NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 9 -Two of four counts of alleged failure to enforce gambling laws in Newark against Dominick A. Spina, the city's Police Director, were dropped today.

Dustin Hoffam, "The Graduate" of movie fame, went back to school yesterday for his first Broadway starring role in Murray Schisgal's "Jimmy Shine." He started with a real new boy's disaster -- his pants split.

The Conservative party agreement not to nominate any slate of Presidential electors in New York is an interesting example of party abnegation. It demonstrates that to the Conservative party the election of Richard M. Nixon is more important than numerical success for the party itself.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said tonight that "Vice President Humphrey and Ed Muskie are best equipped to handle the problems facing the nation."
PARIS, Sept. 9 -- Dick Gregory, the Peace and Freedom party's candidate for President, met with members of the North Vietnamese delegation here today.
BISMARCK, N. D., Sept. 9 (UPI) -- Disorders during the Democratic National Convention in Chicago may have cost 19-year-olds the chance to vote in North Dakota.
The stock market continued on an upward path yesterday although there were some signs of profit-taking pressure.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 9 -- Qualified Yugoslav sources said today that Soviet-bloc pressure on their regime was being continued in the form of criticism from Bulgaria and Poland that seemed inspired by Moscow.

The New York Mets, who open a two - game series in Chicago today, have announced plans for their St. Petersburg team in the Florida Instructional League, which will operate from Sept. 22 through Nov. 20. There are 13 teams in the circuit, with regular games beginning Sept. 27.

SAO TOME, Sept. 9 -- According to missionary sources in Biafra, Nigerian forces are moving against Owerri in an attempt to cut the Ibo heartland in two.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 9 -- Hundreds of famine-stricken Boran tribesmen have begun returning to remote northeastern Kenya from Somalia, where they fled three years ago to escape Kenya's anti-guerrilla operations.

Marcor, Inc., will be the name of a new, parent corporation to result from the merger of Montgomery Ward Co. and the Container Corporation of America. Both concerns filed papers yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, calling for the establishment of Marcor as a Delaware corporation.

OLD network television shows never die; they fade away into syndicated presentation on individual stations. The latest example is that electronic antique, "What's My Line?" which was dropped by the Columbia Broadcasting System and reappeared last night at 11:30 on WOR-TV (Channel 9).

The executive director of the Puerto Rican antipoverty program here said yesterday that the city had slashed the project's job-placement and training funds from an annual rate of $815,000 to $660,000 for the year starting Oct. 1 -a 23 per cent cut.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -The Treasury bill rate rose at today's auction from the levels set in the preceding sale on Aug. 30, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

BOSTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) -- The Negro boycott of a slum elementary school lost some of its impact today as nearly half the 430 pupils returned to their classrooms.

Mayor Lindsay filled two vacancies on the Board of Education yesterday, although one of the new appointees may not be able to take office until it is legally determined whether he is a resident of the city.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Biafran troops have counterattacked in Aba, a town captured earlier by the Nigerian Army.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Perhaps to comfort the heterosexual majority, plays about homosexuality generally show it as a miserably sterile condition, offering even less fun than is allowed to the rest of us. In "Spitting Image" at the Hampstead Theater Club,' Colin Spencer breaks this fine old rule with a brazenly cheerful piece about a good marriage between two men who even manage to produce a baby.
The Maritime Administration announced yesterday the extension of charters for four Moore-McCormack Lines freighters now serving the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service.

HONG KONG, Sept. 10 -Speeches in Peking by Premier Chou En-lai and Miss Chiang Ching, the wife of Mao Tsetung, provide fresh indications that consolidation rather than revolution will be the main emphasis of the rulers of Communist China for the predictable future.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., Sept. 9 -- The general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union voted today to direct all affiliates to reopen their contracts covering wages of 250,000 garment workers throughout the United States.

The American News Company has agreed to acquire the New York City newsstand operations of the Garfield News Company for an undisclosed sum, it was reported yesterday. American News said the deal involved 19 newsstands with a gross of roughly $5-million a year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- The House Agriculture Committee agreed today that the House should compromise its differences with the Senate on two important bills -- measures covering the food stamp and basic farm programs.
the $1.9-billion foreign-aid authorization bill that has finally emerged from a House-Senate conference committee reflects a growing mood of truculent isolationism in Congress.
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 10 -- Two Oakland policemen fired from a police car into the local headquarters of the Black Panther party early this morning. The building was empty at the time.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 10 -- Tension remained high along the Suez Canal today as two Israelis were wounded in incidents along the narrow waterway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -President Johnson delivered a strong defense of his Vietnam policy in a speech to the American Legion convention in New Orleans this afternoon, and then told a B'nai B'rith audience here this evening that he had warned the Soviet Union against the threat or use of force in Berlin.
WAYNE, N. J., Sept. 10 -The Long Island women's golf team won the 39th annual Myra D. Paterson Trophy for the fourth year in a row today.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Democrats today picked Roy Elson, long-time aide to retiring Senator Carl Hayden, to run against Barry Goldwater in the general election.
TRENTON, Sept. 10 -- A Governor's committee has recommended the state's central pine barrens as a site for the New York metropolitan area's fourth major jetport.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- A 20-foot 13-ton model of an Apollo lunar module, in orbit since April 4, has apparently re-entered the earth's atmosphere and landed in the Western Pacific Ocean, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.
SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Sept. 10 -- Sporting gold track shoes that he hopes will carry him to an Olympic gold medal, Jim Hines strengthened his claim today as America's No. 1 sprinter.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary made one of his rare visits to City Hall one morning last week to get Mayor Lindsay's approvel before taking any action in the case og the off-duty patrolmen who attacked a small group of Black Panthers in a Brooklyn courthouse the day before.
Salim L. Lewis, one of Mayor Lindsay's recent appointees to the Board of Education, resigned yesterday.
Prices on the London stock market maintained a firm tone yesterday, although early gains were replaced by a mixed tendency at the close.
MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- Premier Oldrich Cernik of Czechoslovakia conferred today with the three principal leaders of the Soviet Union in the course of a day's visit. He also signed economic accords.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Minnesota Twins pulled off the seventh triple play in the major leagues this season in the fifth inning of tonight's game against Cleveland.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 10 (AP) -- President Rene Barrientos Ortuna ordered last night that the state school system be shut for the two remaining months of the school year. The action was aimed at 25,000 striking teachers.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A jury of seven men and five women was completed today for the trial of Harry J. Karafin, former Philadelphia Inquirer reporter. Mr. Karafin, 53 years old, is on trial on charges of blackmail and unlawful solicitation.

AARHUS, Denmark, Sept. 10 -- If a prize were to be given for the world's least known arts festival, then I am sure that the Aarhus Festival in Denmark, this year running from Sept. 7 through 15, would be on most people's short list.

The site for a new office skyscraper on Third Avenue has been assembled by a group headed by Norman F. Levy, president of Cross Brown. Arlen Properties, associated with Mr. Levy in the venture, will build the tower on the west blockfront of Third Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary said yesterday that he believed the emergence of a militant right wing in the Police Department was a reflection of a similar swing to the right in the community at large.
Norris Industries, diversified producer of commercial and military products based in Los Angeles, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the year ended July 31.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 10 -There are only six seniors on the Lehigh football squad of 58 athletes this fall. Fred Dunlap, their coach, said, "These six seniors have to be dedicated to stick it out the last two years and still come back."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -The Republicans are giving a historic hotel a new lease on life.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Billy Williams cracked two-run homers with machine-like regularity today as the Chicago Cubs drove the New York Mets deeper into the National League cellar, drubbing them, 8-1, before a select gathering of 1,501 chilled fans at cloudy Wrigley Field.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 10 -- In celebration of its 14th anniversary this week, the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization draped the dull, gray building that houses its headquarters here with gay strings of colored lights.

Construction of the port's largest privately sponsored waterfront development, which includes a 700-acre containership terminal, got under way yesterday. It is in the Howland Hook area on Staten Island's northwest shoulder, at the lower end of Newark Bay.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -Gov. Spiro T. Agnew of Maryland, Richard M. Nixon's running mate, attacked Vice President Humphrey today as one who had been "soft on inflation, soft on Communism, and soft on law and order over the years."

The Black Panther party charged yesterday that the City Police Department had engaged in a systematic pattern of "violence, intimidation and humiliation" against its members and filed a suit in Federal Court asking that the control of the police be given to local communities.

The number of business failures in the United States fell to 150 in the week ended Sept. 5 from 200 in the corresponding 1967 week and from 191 in the preceding 1968 week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

A 13-year-old high school freshman from Oak Lawn, Ill., winner of a two-place Cessna Commuter 150 aircraft in a contest sponsored by Revell, Inc., model kit manufacturers, received his prize yesterday at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- There's a new fight brewing in the Democratic party. It's a battle of sexes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Legislation that would create a department of peace at the Cabinet level was introduced today by Representative Seymour Halpern, Republican of Queens. The measure would consolidate the Agency for International Development, the Peace Corps and the arms control and disarmament agency under the jurisdiction of the peace department.
THE wrong contract may be much more interesting to play than the right one.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -Senator Edward M. Kennedy returned to his duties in the Senate today for the first time since, his brother, Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was fatally shot June 5.
After a year's absence the annual luncheon and fashion show of the American Women's Voluntary Services (A.W.V.S.) will be held at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof next Wednesday.

William C. Freund, vice president and economist of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday he expects economic growth to slow in coming months and then show "a real resurgence" in the second half of 1969.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Denny McLain breezed to his 29th victory of the season and slammed three hits tonight as the Detroit Tigers routed the California Angels, 7-2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The White House announced today that Prime Minister Keith J. Holyoake of New Zealand would visit Washington Oct. 9 and 10 to confer with President Johnson.

Jane Cooper, a member of the faculty of Sarah Lawrence College, has been awarded the Lamont Poetry Selection prize sponsored by the Academy of American Poets for her first book of poems, "The Weather of Six Mornings," It is scheduled for publication in February by the Macmillan Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The House today sent to the Senate a $21.6-billion military procurement bill, including authority for sales of surplus weapons to local police and fire departments. The roll-call vote was 323 to 15.

Donohue easily won the United States Road Racing championship for sportsracing cars and the TransAmerican Championship for small sedans, both sponsored by the Sports Car Club of America.

MOSCOW, Sept. 10 (Reuters) -- Soviet newspapers today ignored President de Gaulle's renewed condemnation of the Soviet-led military intervention in Czechoslovakia. The papers carried heavily edited versions of the French leader's news conference yesterday.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Laotian Government sources said today that Pathet Lao forces had blown up a bridge in central Laos, killing one Laotian soldier and wounding two.

MONTREAL, Sept. 10 (AP) -Elie Zaor, 58 years old, Canada's third heart transplant patient, died today. He suffered a stroke yesterday, the 10th day after the operation. The Montreal Heart Institute reported, "the transplanted heart performed very satisfactorily until the end."
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 10 (AP) -- State Senator Jerris Leonard, a Republican, defeated three opponents today and will challenge Gaylord Nelson for the Senate. Senator Nelson, a Democrat, was unopposed.

TRENTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -Off-duty policemen and firemen from through out the state, estimated to number 5,000, staged a rally at the State House here today in hopes of persuading the Legislature to vote them higher pay and increased benefits.

Pulsing with images and giving off a gentle Wurlitzer glow, Iris, a giant closed-circuit television construction designed by Les Levine, made her debut yesterday as a work of art. She may be the first home art work to make her owner a TV star.

ATLANTA, Sept. 10 (UPI) -The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy was arrested today while trying to block emergency garbage pickups. He said that his Southern Christian Leadership Conference would back "to the real finish" the city's week-old garbage strike.
Two of pro football's leading players, Lou Groza and Jimmy Taylor, retired yesterday. Groza, 44 years old, had played since 1946 for the Cleveland Browns, a record for longevity in the sport.

HONG KONG, Sept. 10 (Reuters) -- The official Hanoi newspaper, Nhan Dan accused the United States today of having deliberately brought the Paris talks into an impasse, the North Vietnamese press agency reported.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie appealed today for voters to stay with the two-party system and to shun "protest" votes for President in November.
VIENNA, Sept. 10 (Reuters) -- The Austrian Government extended military service for draftees now serving in the army by one month today in view of the situation in neighboring Czechoslovakia.

OTTAWA, Sept. 10 -- George W. Ball, United States delegate to the United Nations, paid a one-day visit here today to prepare for the new General Assembly meeting Sept. 24. Mr. Ball's principal meeting was with Mitchell Sharp, Secretary of State for External Affairs.
