MEXICO CITY, Sept. 10 -Despite urgings by the rector of the National University for a return to normal operations, striking students called today for a new mass street demonstration Friday.

A yellow and blue World War II torpedo bomber, stripped of its weapons and carrying an infrared mapping device instead, took off from Albany yesterday morning and headed down the Hudson River to New York City in the latest phase of a special mission.

The New York State Conference of branches of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced yesterday a statewide program to assist migrant farm workers with health, maintenance and transportation
Stock prices declined moderately yesterday as the market went through its first setback in seven sessions.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Representative Donald M. Fraser, a Democrat, easily won renomination today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department today estimated this year's corn crop at 4,636,456,000 bushels -- only 2 per cent less than last year's record -and a record wheat crop of 1,596,599,000 bushels.

PRAGUE, Sept. 10 -- The Czechoslovak Government issued a proclamation tonight guaranteeing individual rights and the freedom of artists, scientists and intellectuals to maintain contact with the outside world.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Daniel B. Brewster, incumbent Democrat, and Representative Charles McC. Mathias, a Republican, easily won Senate nominations today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 10 -- William S. Cox won the William H. Taylor Trophy for the Noroton (Conn.) Yacht Club for the second time in three years today by defeating Benjamin H. Bryon Jr., representing the Greenwich Cove Racing Association, 3-0, in the scheduled best-of-five race final series for the Long Island Sound i interclub match-race championship.

George A. McCracken, a Queens district leader, announced yesterday that the 19th Assembly District Regular Democratic Club covering the Rosedale area would not support Paul O'Dwyer, the Democratic candidate for the Senate.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- The Medical Committee for Human Rights branded Mayor Richard J. Daley's report on demonstrations during the Democratic National Convention "incredibly" inaccurate to day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Associate Justice Potter Stewart ordered Ohio today to prepare to carry George C. Wallace's name on its election ballots pending a decision by the Supreme Court on whether the state had acted constitutionally in refusing to list him.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Harold W. Hayward, town justice of Big Flats, near Elmira, was elected president of the State Magistrates Association here today at the group's annual meeting. He succeeds Lawrence J. Zweig, town justice of Nassau, Rensselaer County, as head of the 2,200-member organization.
Mayor Lindsay signed two local laws yesterday establishing the Municipal Services Administration and a Department of Consumer Affairs.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Senator Wallace F. Bennett swept to a fourth-term nomination in he Utah Republican primary today over the challenge of Mark E. Anderson, a Salt Lake City lawyer and former regional coordinator of the John Birch Society.

The Grand Union Company, the country's ninth-largest food chain, reported yesterday a 12.6 per cent gain in sales in its fiscal first half ended August 31, to $494,522,656 from $439,159,635 in the 1967 period.

The appointment of Claude Feninger as president of Sheraton - International was announced yesterday by Ernest Henderson 3d, president of the Sheraton Corporation of America. Mr. Feninger will direct operations of Sheraton's overseas properties, including the company's Hawaiian hotels and others in operation or planned for 14 different countries abroad.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- The Aluminum Company of America announced today plans to build a major Bauxite refining plant on the island of Jamaica this year. Eventual yearly capacity will be 880,000 tons of alumina.

The city announced yesterday the abandonment of its fleet of five Sanitation Department tugs. All will be sold when the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, low among four bidders for the contract, takes over the operation on Sept. 30.

Seventy Renaissance frescoes from Florence were unloaded from the liner Cristoforo Colombo yesterday afternoon at Pier 90 North River en route to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. They will be exhibited from Sept. 28 through Nov. 15.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 10 -Richard M. Nixon opened his campaign for New York's 43 electoral votes tonight in the warm embrace of Governor Rockefeller and to the tumultuous cheers of a vocal Westchester County rally.

BROCKTON, Mass., Sept. 10 (UPI) -- An arsonist driving a speeding car hurled nine flaming smudge pots into a station wagon, a supermarket, a $50,000 home, a gasoline station and a pharmacy in the Brockton area early today.

HOUSTON, Sept. 10 -- With ever greater acknowledgment of the opposition to him, Hubert H. Humphrey is staking his claim to the Presidency on the simple proposition that he is the best available, or at least the least objectionable, man for the job.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept 10 (UPI) -- A Government agency had no telephone service today because it failed to pay its bills to the Governmentowned monopoly.

GREENEVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 10 -- As Little Peeler -- formally Calvin Peeler -- was filmed in his first episode of "Mayberry R.F.D." yesterday, he and his family were told that they should be prepared to fly back to Hollywood for future episodes, and perhaps to stay.
LONDON, Sept. 10 (AP) -The International Coffee Organization approved a coffee export quota of 47.8 million bags for the year beginning October.
HOUSTON, Sept. 10 -- Vice President Humphrey talked again today about his "feeling" that the Paris talks on Vietnam might become "more substantive" before the end of the year.

Thousands of retail buyers flocked to New York this week for two large trade shows serving department, chain, variety and specialty stores -- the National Notion Show and the National Merchandise Show.
Important problems are emerging in the use of the substance considered most promising in preventing rejection of transplanted human organs, a pioneer in its use said yesterday.

WHEN Eddie Stanky disappeared from the scene as White Sox manager in mid-July, the serene life of Senor Alfonso Ramon Lopez was violently disrupted. The one-time Gay Caballero had been enjoying his retirement in his native city of Tampa. He played golf every day and occasionally went on talent-appraising trips in his role as "consultant."
DETROIT, Sept. 10 -- Buick showed its 1969 models today, and the styling changes are minor.

SEOUL, Sept. 10 (AP) -- South Korea will send 55 athletes to the Olympic Games in Mexico City, Oct. 12 to 27, it was announced today.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Nancy Wake-man told the police that she shot her husband, a financier, after he slapped her in a family fight, a fromer police sergeant testified today.
Charging that the Democratic, Republican and Liberal party leaders "did not respect their commitments," the citizens judicial screening committee for Manhattan and the Bronx dissolved yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 10 -- An 8-year-old Negro boy was brought into a North Carolina hospital a few months ago suffering from severe anemia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -Attorney General Ramsey Clark told the Senate today that if it "really wants to do something to control crime," it should immediately pass a comprehensive gun control bill, including the registration and licensing of firearms.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 10 -- Unusual secrecy and a wide-ranging reluctance of people to serve on the jury marked the start of the first of two related murder trials here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Madison Fund, an investment company, demanded today dismissal of the proceedings instituted against it by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The New York Jets announced yesterday the election of a woman vice president.

Foreign government officials, here to attend a United Nations social welfare parley, yesterday heard a weeping 52-year-old grandmother contend that she was beaten by the police during a school demonstration in the Brownsville area of Brooklyn.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 94.3 on Monday from 94 on Friday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Some 2,000 garbage collectors, on strike since yesterday, have agreed to return to their jobs, Mayor Richard J. Daley said today. He said details of the settlement would be worked out next week.

MOSCOW, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Mikhail A. Menshikov, 66 years old, the former Soviet Ambassador to the United States, has resigned as Foreign Minister of the Russian Federation to go into retirement, it was announced today.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 11 -- On the grounds where Dina Merrill rode her pony as a child, Peter Gogolak placekicked and punted here today. The football soared through the air at C. W. Post College, the onetime estate of Marjorie Merriwether Post, mother of the actress.
The chief minister of Madras State, India, C. N. Annadurai, arrived yesterday to undergo surgery at the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases.

TAYNINH BASE, South Vietnam, Sept. 11 -- Allied forces turned back a major enemy assault on Tayninh City and nearby American installations today, but the enemy was holding on in several suburbs, trying to increase his foothold.

A five-year plan costing more than $12-million that would establish a nationwide program for young skiers was proposed yesterday by Bob Beattie, United States Alpine ski team director.

Directors of The New York Times Company voted yesterday an increase in the regular dividend for the third quarter to 50 cents a share, from 40 cents, and approved a four-for-one split of the common stock.

TOKYO, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The Socialist party, the major opposition to the ruling Liberal three - day convention today. The next general election is not scheduled until 1972, but it is believed that Premier Eisaku Sato may call an election next year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Straight Ahead, ridden by William Gavidia, pulled away in the late stretch to win the $10,000 Display Handicap by one length before 12,591 at Hawthorne Park today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- B'nai B'rith called today for immediate state and Federal legislation that would require the registration of all firearms.

The Curtis Publishing Company, in an economy drive, has given dismissal notices to about a dozen of the staff members of The Saturday Evening Post, according to William Emerson, The Post's managing editor.

RANK has its privileges, and what is the point of being the conductor of an orchestra if you cannot program your own music? Lukas Foss, who brought the Buffalo Philharmonic to New York last night in Carnegie Hall, led the first complete New York performance of his "Baroque Variations."
Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc., of Chicago has bought a substantial minority interest in the Weidenfeld Group of Publishers, Ltd., of London, a prominent British publisher of quality books.
Two policemen were injured early this morning when several shots were fired into their patrol car parked at Schenectady Avenue and Eastern Parkway, in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic National Chairman, said that it was apparent that Gov. Spiro T. Agnew of Maryland had been delegated to "travel the low road" in the Republican campaign this year.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 11 -- Italy and Greece have given diplomatic assurances to Yugoslavia that they will not take advantage of the current Soviet-bloc pressure on her to revive oral grievances or create other complications.

A teacher's right to strike was vigorously debated yesterday by many of New York's public school students as they returned to school after a 10-week summer holiday that was extended two days by the teachers' walkout.
Substances recently found in common bacteria have been suggested as a new tool to help solve the central problem in transplantation of human organs.

The Associates Investment Company announced yesterday that it planned to make a cash tender offer involving about $19.5-million for all of the outstanding stock of the Providence-Washington Insurance Company.
SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Sept. 11 -- The frustration finally ended today for Chris Farrell, pretty wife of the Olympic-bound 800-meter champion, Tom Farrell.
The London stock market eased yesterday from its recent sustained rise.
OTTAWA, Sept. 11 -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau accused France today of "underhandedly" sending an agent to Canada to "agitate" among French Canadians.
LAST night's special entitled "From Chekhov, With Love" was a disappointingly superficial attempt to suggest the personal and professional life of the Russian dramatist and short story writer.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 11 -- The Government decided today to create an "autonomous state within the State of Assam" in northeastern India.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 11 -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew, the Republican candidate for Vice President, said today he had "no doubt" that among Vietnam war protestors there was "a conspiracy of the type which is legally punishable in this country -- a conspiracy to overthrow the government by force."

Groups representing motion picture theater owners and operators have filed suit against the Board of Estimate and two Manhattan cable television companies to prevent the showing of movies and other programs on cable television here.

TRENTON, Sept. 11 -- The Department of Transportation is offering a $500 prize for the best name for the high-speed electronic commuter cars New Jersey will soon place in service on the Penn Central and Erie - Lackawanna Railroads in the state.

With the start of classes only two weeks away, Columbia University made another attempt to reduce campus tension yesterday by announcing the reinstatement of 42 students who were suspended during last spring's uprising.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11 -- Dr. Fager won the United Nations Handicap today. The Tartan Stable's 4-year-old colt carried top weight of 134 pounds and was running on grass for the first time. He found himself headed in the stretch, yet came on to take the mile-and- three-sixteenths event by a neck.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Johnson today asked Congress to approve new and comprehensive legislation for coal-mine safety before it adjourns in October.
Fully expecting to be rebuffed, the Conservative party yesterday authorized the appearance on the Conservative party line, Row C, of the 43 Republican Presidential electors.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Senator McCarthy asked state officials today not to put his name on the ballot as a Presidential candidate in Minnesota and New York.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
Mrs. Johannes Eerdmans of 1045 Fifth Avenue has been appointed chairman of the women's division of the Salvation Army's fund campaign for 1969. The division will seek to raise $400,000.

The American Express Company is planning to enter the magazine publishing field through the proposed purchase of the U. S. Camera Publishing Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Howard L. Clark, president of American Express.

GALILEE, R. I. -- Shortly before 8 A.M., most of the 138 boats in last weekend's 26th annual United States Atlantic tuna tournament were running off the rock jetties of Point Judith Pond for the final eight hours of the three-day event.

A National University Forum to serve as a channel of communication between the university community and Vice President Humphrey was announced yesterday by R. Bruce Carroll, a political scientist on the faculty of Middlebury College, in Vermont. The forum's 35 members include both students and teachers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The House Commerce Committee voted today to delay for a second time a decision on authorizing pay television in various parts of the country.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 11 -- Following are excerpts from a text prepared by Vice President Humphrey for delivery today to the convention of the American Legion here:
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 11 -- Richard M. Nixon endorsed the nuclear nonproliferation treaty today, but asked the Senate to postpone approval of it.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- The new African state of Swaziland was unanimously approved today by the Security Council as the 125th member of the United Nations. Approval by the General Assembly later this month is taken for granted.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities is considering an investigation into the street fighting that marred the Democratic convention in Chicago, it was reported today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 11 -- Sculptures from the collection that Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Hirshhorn have given to the United States will be on display Wednesday at their estate here to benefit the scholarship fund of the Barnard College Club of Fairfield County.

FLINT, Mich., Sept. 11 -- Vice President Humphrey attacked Richard M. Nixon today as "a wiggler and a wobbler" on the most crucial issues and the creator of doubts that he said were aggravating the international situation.

NICE, France, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- A twin-jet Caravelle airliner caught fire today on a half-hour flight from the island of Corsica to Nice and crashed into stormy waters off the French Riviera, killing all 95 persons aboard.
THE DAYS of lying in a bassinette playing with one's little pink toes are over. Or they are if Three World's, Inc., has anything to say about it.
CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Senator McCarthy and Mayor Lindsay will be fourth party running mates in New Hampshire Nov. 5, unless they ask to be taken off the ballot by Sept. 25.
Air-conditioners were added yesterday to the lengthening list of products for which consumers and industrial users will have to pay higher prices.

Vigorous economic expansion in eastern Venezuela sets an encouraging example for that country's partners in the lagging Alliance for Progress. The rapid growth of heavy industry and the reclamation of hundreds of thousands of acres of land along the Orinoco River represent the kind of progress the Alliance seeks but rarely achieves.

An exporter here was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charge that be billed the Agency for International Development $550 for transformers with a catalogue price of $25. They were destined for Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Representatives of New Jersey Gov. Richard J. Hughes's Airport Evaluation Committee attempted to raise support today among the state's members of Congress and Federal transportation officials for a proposed jetport in the Lakehurst area.
PARIS, Sept. 11 -- W. Averell Harriman today acidly criticized President de Gaulle's view that the United States, along with the Soviet Union, had sought to divide and dominate Europe.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said today he would delay for at least three weeks any statement on whom he will support for President in the November election.
A one-day walkout of port engineers that idled two United States Lines freighters in the Port of New York has ended with agreement by the company to permit a union representation election.

A plan under which Panamanian seamen would receive training at the National Maritime Union's training center at 346 West 17th Street and discussed yesterday by President-elect Arnulfo Arias of Panama and Joseph Curran, union president.

The creation of a coordinated network of public and private institutions of higher education in the mid-Hudson, Rockland and Westchester region has been mapped out in a study commissioned by the State University of New York.

The New York Fruit Auction, which has struggled along for longer than its officers can remember in a ramshackle pier on the decaying lower west side, will join the exodus to the Bronx within the year and relocate on a site near the new Hunts Point produce market.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Sept. 11 -- Eight rookies got a chance to make their moves against two established players today as the Knicks began their preseason training at the State University at Farmingdale.

NORWALK, Sept. 11 -- The heaviest rain in several years, with 3.12 inches falling within a three and one-half hour period, caused some 1,200 customers of the Connecticut Light and Power Company to be without power for varying periods early this morning.

THERE is almost nothing that the people at Henri Bendel like more than being different. Their latest effort in this direction is small scale. The seventh-floor children's department has been redecorated, refurnished and restocked. The new size 4 to 12 department is called "Grow ing Up at Bendel," and the growing up is done on a rather sophisticated level. There are three sections, all decorated in gingham checks.
THE ARTS OF THE ALCHEMISTS. By C. A. Burland. Illustrated. 224 pages. Macmillan. $9.95.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Bob Gibson struggled to his 21st victory tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals moved closer to the National League pennant by beating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-4.

For more than two months the House Rules Committee has entombed an excellent, far-reaching bill to strengthen the Federal regulation of campaign spending. The relevant provisions of the Corrupt Practices Act of 1925 and the Hatch Act of 1939 have been ignored or distorted for so long that President Johnson has accurately described them as "more loophole than law."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 11 -- "They've emasculated us." "They've cut the ground from under us." "This couldn't have happened at a worse time."

ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 11 (UPI) -- Willie Horton belted two homers, numbers 33 and 34, and Bill Freehan belted his 22d to pace the Detroit Tigers to an 8-2 victory tonight that completed a sweep of a three-game series against the California Angels.

HONG KONG, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- Ten anti-Maoists, described as counterrevolutionaries, thieves and murderers, have been executed in Chekiang Province, the Chekiang radio reported today. The trials took place in public in Hangchow, the provincial capital, the radio said.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- Four Negro boys entered Girard College today, the first of their race to be admitted in the 120-year history of the orphans' school.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons ran into Republican delaying tactics today -- tactics apparently aimed at postponing Senate action until after the election.

SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Sept. 11 -- Geoff Vanderstock, a 21-year-old Californian, set a world record in the 400-meter hurdles today, but Jim Ryun's bid for two Olympic gold medals vanished in a cluster of pine trees.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- Two gunmen today robbed Mrs. Leonard Marks, wife of the United States Information Agency director, and 14 other women attending an informal luncheon. The bandits escaped with more than $500 in cash and an undetermined amount of valuable jewelry.

YONKERS, Sept. 11 -- With 14 named this morning to start in Saturday night's $50,000 E. Roland Harriman Trot at Yonkers Raceway, the fifth-annual blue-ribbon test for 2-year-olds was divided into two divisions. Management, in accordance with the conditions of the race, added $25,000 to increase the gross purse to $75,000, each dash offering $37,500.
DONCASTER, England, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Ribero, owned by Charles W. Engelhard of Far Hills, N. J., held off Canterbury and won the $96,000 St. Leger race by a head today.
Potatoes rose their limit of 35 cents a hundred pounds in active futures trading yesterday and closed at or near record levels.
ATLANTA, Thursday, Sept. 12 -- Senator Herman E. Talmadge easily defeated yesterday his young Negro challenger, Maynard H. Jackson, for the Democratic nomination for the Senate.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 11 -- A 61-year-old man who was freed last year after having spent 28 years in state mental institutions on an arson conviction has started a $5-million civil suit against Nassau County.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- Two gunmen today robbed Mrs. Leonard Marks, wife of the United States Information Agency director, and 14 other women attending an informal luncheon. The bandits escaped with more than $500 in cash and an undetermined amount of valuable jewelry.

YONKERS, Sept. 11 -- With 14 named this morning to start in Saturday night's $50,000 E. Roland Harriman Trot at Yonkers Raceway, the fifth-annual blue-ribbon test for 2-year-olds was divided into two divisions. Management, in accordance with the conditions of the race, added $25,000 to increase the gross purse to $75,000, each dash offering $37,500.
DONCASTER, England, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Ribero, owned by Charles W. Engelhard of Far Hills, N. J., held off Canterbury and won the $96,000 St. Leger race by a head today.
OWOSSO, Mich., Sept. 11 -- Late tomatoes are ripened on windowsills here at this time of year so the first frost will not brown them.
A $82,382 Federal grant to extend the cultural reach of the Countee Cullen Library, one of the 85 branches of the New York Public Library, was announced yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 11 -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew tonight sharply criticized Mr. Humphrey's recent statements about troop withdrawals from Vietnam, saying that he was jeopardizing the Paris talks and indulging in a "politics of desperation."
Potatoes rose their limit of 35 cents a hundred pounds in active futures trading yesterday and closed at or near record levels.
ATLANTA, Thursday, Sept. 12 -- Senator Herman E. Talmadge easily defeated yesterday his young Negro challenger, Maynard H. Jackson, for the Democratic nomination for the Senate.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 11 -- A 61-year-old man who was freed last year after having spent 28 years in state mental institutions on an arson conviction has started a $5-million civil suit against Nassau County.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 11 -- Details of a Long Island land-zoning transaction that led to the indictment of former State Tax Commissioner Walter M. Conlon and Islip Town Councilman Donald J. Kuss on bribery charges were heard in Supreme Court here today.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Pope Paul VI urged today that the world's Roman Catholics respect papal authority and curb impulses to break away from church teaching.
Private cartmen who haul garbage and waste for restarrants, hotels and other businesses asked yesterday that they be allowed to charge as much as $4.76 a cubic yard. The present maximum is $2.75.
NEWARK, Sept. 11 (AP) -- For 25 years Clarence Clark's conscience has been gnawing on him.
"I'm sort of nervous, as you'd expect," said Matthew Marcus, "but I try to keep cool about it."
Most of the 10 teachers who have become the focal point of the present school crisis have not been eating or sleeping well, and they have been troubled by threatening and insulting telephone calls.
HARTFORD, Sept. 11 -- A Federal study group proposed today a master conservation plan for a 125,000-acre belt along the banks of the Connecticut River, from the Canadian border to Long Island Sound.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- An effort to offer Chicago's official regrets for "insults or degradations" suffered during the week of the Democratic National Convention was buried in committee today by the City Council.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 12 (AP) -- North Korea reported that the captain of the Pueblo admitted to foreign Communist newsmen today that the ship trespassed into North Korean waters before it was captured on Jan. 23.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -- Male homosexual assaults are "epidemic" in the Philadelphia prison system, according to a documented report filed in court here today by the District Attorney's office.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 11 -- American troops reported killing 95 enemy soldiers this morning as they turned back an attack in the jungle 40 miles northwest of Saigon.

"Our egghead in Congress -- a creative intellectual in the best sense of the word" was the description given yesterday for New York's new Senator, Charles F. Goodell, by Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Presidential candidate.
"We Bombed in New Haven" and "The Great White Hope" will be the first two beneficiaries of a fund designed to bolster creative activity in the commercial theater.
A dog may be man's best friend, but not in the case of two men arrested yesterday on a charge of bookmaking.
W. Willard Wirtz said he wanted to be where the action was. So the Secretary of Labor came to town yesterday and visited Judy Livingston on Canal Street.

BOMBAY, India, Sept. 11 -- The Indian state that has been getting the most striking results in its family-planning program has decided to start penalizing parents who ignore its blandishments and propaganda and produce more than three children.
PARIS, Sept. 11 -- American and North Vietnamese negotiators exchanged claims today of smashing victories on the battlefield.
ALBANY, Sept. 11 -- Dean William H. Mulligan of Fordham University School of Law has been appointed a member of the Advisory Council on Labor and Management Improper Practices Act.

POSITIONALLY instructive beyond the common run of games was the Sicilian Defense, Grandmaster Bent Larsen of Denmark and Gregory De Fotis of Chicago, the United States junior co-champion, played in the recent United States tournament at Aspen, Colo. Larsen was the winner of the tournament.

BONN, Sept. 11 -- The West German border police announced today that a 27-year-old East German used a frogman's suit and miniature engine in fleeing to Denmark by swimming across the Baltic last Monday.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 11 -- Lord Graham resigned today as Minister of External Affairs and Defense in a clash with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith over whether Rhodesia should move faster toward apartheid, separation between whites and blacks.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11 -- The Masai tribesmen of Kenya eat at least as much cholesterol as the average American, yet these Africans are lean people with little body fat and almost no heart disease.
The election of David I. Margolis as president of Colt Industries, Inc., producer of systems and equipment, was announced yesterday. He formerly was executive vice president and treasurer.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced yesterday that it had discovered an oil and gas well in the Santa Barbara Channel. The company, which is operator for itself and the Standard Oil Company of California, said that oil and gas were produced in substantial quantities from four separate intervals.
PARIS, Sept. 11 -- The outlook for a quiet return to school in France this autumn was dimmed today by unrest among students on one side and politicians on the other.

Negotiations between representatives of the New York City Opera and a committee representing its 51-member orchestra continued into the evening yesterday on a new contract. The musicians, whose contract expired in June, are members of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians.

Seldom, in a major league game, can one see a team botch up an inning as thoroughly as the Chicago White Sox did last night when they made four errors and a wild pitch to help the New York Yankees to a seven-run sixth inning that meant a 7-2 victory.

CHICHESTER, England, Sept. 11 -- Seven years is no great time in the history of the theater, yet it comes as a shock to realize that Britain's Chichester Festival is only now in its seventh season. When Laurence Olivier started the festival and opened the Festival Theater in 1962, he was in effect starting the British National Theater, and for four seasons his theater made its summer home at Chichester.

The city plans to develop a vacant 10-acre site on the fringe of Kennedy International Airport into an industrial park containing facilities for the aviation industry, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.
Senator Jacob K. Javits yesterday toured the South Bronx, one of the city's most blighted areas, and fielded questions that for the most part focused on his attitude toward anti-poverty programs.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -- Bob Odell, Pennsylvania's football coach, can't spell his quarterback's name without plenty of time to think about it. But he knows just what the little athlete can and cannot do on a gridiron.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Congress completed action today on legislation calling for a White House conference on the problems of the elderly to be held in 1971. The bill, given final passage by the House, authorizes $1.9-million for the conference.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 12 -- An advertising salesman for The New Yorker magazine, a financial analyst for a division of General Dynamics, a United Air Lines pilot, the sales manager of a Connecticut airport-parts supplier and an upstate New York mechanic who built his own helicopter at the age of 16, have come to Nigeria to operate the first helicopter airlift of relief supplies to victims of the country's bitter 14-month civil war.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 12 -- In two hours of quiet argument, Charles Garry, counsel for Huey P. Newton, today requested a new trial for the Black Panther leader, who was convicted of involuntary manslaughter in the shooting of an Oakland policeman.
The stock market went through another irregular retreat in brisk trading yesterday.

Hart Schaffner Marx, Chicago, has held several meetings with the antitrust division of the Justice Department to allay the division's concern over the company's retail-acquisition program, John D. Gray, president of the Hart Schaffner, said yesterday.

AREA A -- Because of the storm that lashed the East Coast recently, nothing spectacular has been caught although with the waters starting to calm down from Sandy Hook to Asbury Park, N. J., school fish (from 3 to 5 pounds) are starting to appear.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan filed suit in State Supreme Court here yesterday for an injunction to bar any of the city's 75 Criminal Court judges from ordering jury trials in misdemeanor cases.
The General American Transportation Corporation plans to go into the banking business through a proposal to acquire the LaSalle National Bank of Chicago for securities valued at about $40-million.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The widow of a man killed last year in the crash of a Mohawk Airlines jet in Blossburg, Pa., has been awarded $240,000 in damages.

The election of L. C. Ackerman as a director of the J. I. Case Company, Racine, Wis., was announced yesterday following a meeting of the board. He is president of the Walker Manufacturing Company, also Racine, and fills a vacancy on the Case board caused by the death of Allan B. Kline.
Former financier Lowell M. Birrell, 61, convicted last December of securities violations, was released from jail yesterday after he posted $30,000 bail in U.S. District Court.
WHEN Dennis Dale McLain strides to the mound in Tiger Stadium in Detroit tomorrow afternoon, the national attention will switch for two hours from the overriding issues of the day to baseball.

Dr. Arnulfo Arias, President-elect of Panama, is scheduled to leave for home tomorrow after a five-day visit here in which he discussed the Panamanian investment climate with American business leaders. The President-elect arrived here Monday from Europe where he sought to promote more trade with France and West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The White House drew a distinction today between President Johnson's responsibility to speak out on national policy issues and statements made by Vice President Humphrey under the pressure of the election campaign.

HEBRON, Conn., Sept. 12 (UPI) -- A 17-year-old girl was fatally stabbed today in a high school corridor and her alleged assailant, a boy two years younger, was arrested after a pursuit by 50 of his classmates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Paul L. Sitton to be urban mass transportation administrator in the Transportation Department. Mr. Sitton, who is from DeKalb County, Ga., has been Deputy Under Secretary for Transportation.
Vice President Humphrey "has to do more" to win over supporters of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy for the Democrats to win New York State, John J. Burns, the party state chairman, said yesterday.
Prices on the London stock market again drifted lower yesterday, after a mild early rally faded.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- President Johnson announced today that he would nominated Edward D. Re of New York City to be a judge of the United States Customs Court.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Senate opened debate today on gun control legislation so changed by Judiciary Committee amendments that the Justice and Treasury Departments were complaining it would be ineffective in controlling interstate sales of firearms and ammunition.

The manuscripts of many of Stephen C. Foster's compositions went for a song a century ago, but one of them found open-handed bidders last night at an auction in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, with a winning bid of $4,500.
Teachers College at Columbia University announced yesterday that for the first time two representatives of the student body would join the Committee on Policy, Program and Budget.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- President Johnson said today that the programs he would submit to Congress in January are "not only for next year but for decades ahead."

Technique, sometimes regarded by the dance avant-garde as a virtue to be felt but not seen, came to the fore at the Judson Memorial Church last night in a distinguished concert by Viola Farber and Peter Saul, both of whom formerly danced with Merce Cunningham.
The push toward higher prices for chemicals continued unabated yesterday.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose slightly yesterday, after a downtrend on Tuesday that put an end to six consecutive sessions of advances.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 12 -- College football coaches have been hung in effigy maligned by alumni and dismissed for losing seasons. The job is one with built-in ups and downs. Right now Dom Anile is way up. Two days before C. W. Post College was to open its training camp, head coach Joe Scannella resigned to become a scout for the New York Giants.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 12 -- An abundant grain harvest this year is spelling trouble for many Danish farmers.

ROME, Sept. 12 -- The Italian Communist party chief, Luigi Longo, advised the five Warsaw pact powers to pull out of Czechoslovakia and give her back "full sovereignty" to counter "conservative and reactionary" efforts to renew the cold war in Western Europe.

CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Prevaricate took the lead at the start and had enough left for a three-quarter-length decision over Good King in today's $1,800 feature at Finger Lakes Race Track. Prevaricate completed the muddy mile in 1:44 and paid $21.80, $9.80 and $5.60 for $2 across the board.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The State Department made public today secret instructions given to the intelligence ship Pueblo last Jan. 5 to stay at least 13 miles off the North Korean coast.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- An American Zionist leader asked today for an immediate cooperative effort among all national Jewish groups to combat what he described as "the rising manifestations" of anti-Semitism by black extremists throughout the country.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Democratic State Central Committee voted today to oust J. Marshall Brown, Louisiana's Democratic national committeeman, in a fight between its conservative and loyalist factions.

LONDON, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- Sir Robert Menzies, former Australian Prime Minister, is recovering in a hospital here from a mild stroke and has canceled a visit to the United States, the Australian Embassy said today. Sir Robert was invited to deliver three lectures at the University of Texas later this month.

At least 37 of the candidates for electors pledged to Gov. George C. Wallace for President were listed by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith yesterday as persons who have been involved with white Citizens Councils, the John Birch Society or other rightist groups.

Patrolman John W. Thompson of Safety Unit B studied the license plate of the car parked yesterday at noon at a meter in front of 1605 Broadway, between 48th and 49th Streets. Time on the meter had run out.
HONG KONG, Sept. 12 -- Peking has begun to hold out the possibility of forgiveness to persons in Communist China who have violated the Maoist concept of right deeds and right thoughts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A $20-million, four-year extension of a Federal program to help states develop commercial fisheries resources was approved today by the House Merchant Marine Committee. The Senate passed a similar bill July 29.
BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Sept. 12 -- Bob Shields and Mrs. Philip Baris of Alpine won the qualifying medal today in the annual pro-woman golf championship over the Forest Hills Field Club.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 13 -- American infantrymen battled a North Vietnamese force of about 1,500 men for 13 hours yesterday in the jungle eight miles from the Cambodia border.

DENVILLE, N. J., Sept. 12 -- The defending champions in both divisions lagged today at the finish of the first round in the 10th annual New Jersey State Golf Association pre-seniors and seniors championships.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The American Legion unanimously elected William C. Doyle, 49 years old, of Vineland, N. J., as its president today at the close of its 50th national convention. Named national vice commanders were Lewis E. McCray, Tuscaloosa, Ala.; C. Russell Huber, Anchorage, Alaska; Maurice R. Parisien, Portland, Me.; Howard E. Lohman, Moorhead, Minn., and John A. Jones, Weirton, W. Va.
The Securities and Exchange Commission, hobbled by Federal budget cutbacks at a time of tumultuous volume in the stock market, is trying to shift some of its law-enforcement burden to other agencies.

ATHENS, Ohio, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- The president of Ohio University, Vernon Alden, announced his resignation today, effective next June. He will become chairman of the Boston Company, Inc., and the Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Company.

Scores of persons were questioned and roofs were scrutinized along many blocks in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn yesterday by more than 50 policemen. They were seeking the sniper or snipers who wounded two policemen early yesterday morning.

The new Fortune Theater, situated on the second floor at 62 East Fourth Street, will receive Megan Terry's play, "The People Versus Ranchman," on Oct. 27. The presentation was formerly announced to open Oct. 15 at the Actor's Playhouse.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- President Johnson today proclaimed the week beginning Nov. 22 as National Farm-City Week. The lives of Americans in the next century, he proclaimed, will be determined "by whether our core cities are restored, and whether suburban growth is translated into durable and desirable forms of community development."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The academic senate of the Catholic University of America took what appeared to be a hesitant and tentative step today toward an investigation of 17 professors who have publicly dissented from Pope Paul VI's encyclical on birth control.
For the pupils in the six elementary schools in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration district the threat of a teachers' strike most likely will not mean an end of school.

The 19-member governing board of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville Demonstration School District consists of two clergymen, an Assemblyman, a college professor, the only Puerto Rican principal in the city, and parents and teachers.

Hundreds of subway riders were delayed last night when a cable fire in the Canal Street-Broadway station area forced a shut-off of power on the IRT and BMT lines using the station. The fire, reported at 6:43 P.M., was quickly extinguished by firemen, and the power was restored 12 minutes later for all trains except the BMT express to Brooklyn.
PRAGUE, Sept. 12 -- Postinvasion Czechoslovakia faces a serious threat of inflation.

HARTFORD, Sept. 12 -- Stewart L. Udall, Secretary of the Interior, predicted today that the Federal Government's new 125,000-acre conservation program for the Connecticut River Valley would succeed regardless of who is elected President in November.
KILLEEN, Tex., Sept. 12 -- Andrew D. Stapp of New York, chairman of the American Servicemen's Union, and two of his co-workers were convicted of vagrancy today and fined $200 each.

ROME Sept. 12 (AP) -- Food production rose last year, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization reported today and "the world food and agricultural situation is now in a state of transition arid hope."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Senate completed Congressional action today on a bill for providing for the creation of a National Water Commission to study water resources and requirements. The study's estimated cost is $5-million.

George Abbott has succeeded Jack Klugman as the director of the new Allan Sherman-Albert Hague musical, "The Fig Leaves Are Falling," due here in January It will be the 90th show to be directed by Mr. Abbott, who is 81 years old.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended Wednesday in thousands of pounds follows:
LONDON, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Mrs. Mary Rand, who won three medals for Britain in the 1964 Olympic Games, announced her retirement from track tonight.
Major airlines are strengthening the wings of their Boeing 707 jets because of the discovery of metal fatigue cracks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- A Government study group has found that the drug industry makes exceptional profits without exceptional risk and that the elderly bear the brunt of high drug costs, probably suffering more illness as a result.

PRAGUE, Sept. 12 -- In a first-floor office at the Interior Ministry, a young police captain in a tweed sports jacket leaned back in his chair this morning to explain pleasantly to an American visitor that the Czechoslovak secret police had made no arrests of liberals or intellectuals since last month's Soviet invasion and that it proposed to make none unless they violated laws.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Republican Congressional leaders disputed today a charge by their own party's Vice-Presidential nominee that Hubert H. Humphrey was "soft on Communism."

The election of Dr. Vernon R. Alden as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Boston Company and its principal subsidiary, the Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Company, effective Jan. 1, was announced yesterday.
Cocoa futures yesterday plunged the daily permissible limit of 100 points, or one cent a pound, in a technical reaction to the recent sharp rise.
Governor Rockefeller will embark Saturday on the first of a series of coast-to-coast trips in support of Republican candidates, according to an announcement from his office here yesterday.
An American listener need not be steeped in the complexities of Indian music to be engrossed by the effects, from subliminal to sublime, displayed at Ravi Shankar's "Festival From India."
NYACK, Sept. 12 -- Two joint committees of the Legislature today heard appeals for help from residents and officials of communities along the shore of Tappan Zee Bay.

The election of H. I. Romnes to the board of directors of the Colgate-Palmolive Company, was announced yesterday. Mr. Romnes is chairman and chief executive officer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
BOSTON, Sept. 12 -- Northeastern University missed an undefeated season last year by one game. The Huskies hope to make Coach Joe Zabilski's 21st campaign even more memorable.
While it eschews the label, the Ogden Corporation is what Wall Street calls a conglomerate, formed in the if-Litton-can-do-it-so-can-we fashion.

THORPE BAY, England, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The fourth race in the Little America's Cup for catamarans was declared no contest today as the Americans worked frantically to repair their damaged craft, Yankee Flyer.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 12 -- Two weeks ago, Dave Kelley, noticed that Model Cadet, one of the country's leading conformation hunters, appeared to be tiring in shows.

A year ago Tucker Frederickson was a substitute for the New York Giants. In their first two games he carried the ball only four times and gained 3 yards as a replacement for Bill Triplett at halfback.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Favored T.V's Princess beat Baby Jane II in the stretch today to win the feature $7,000 allowance event at Atlantic City race track by a neck.

At least one of the city's school boards has dismissed a district school superintendent as a result of community tensions. Another district is weighing the qualifications it feels a district superintendent should have.
ALGIERS, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- Secretary General Thant arrived today to address the fifth summit conference of the Organization of African Unity, which opens tomorrow.
SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Sept. 12 -- Bob Seagren, who was on his back in a local hospital two weeks ago, pole-vaulted back to the top of the world today.

TRENTON, Sept. 12 -- Democratic leaders and state labor officials agreed today that the Wallace Presidential candidacy apparently was hurting Vice President Humphrey here far more than Richard M. Nixon, who, they said, now appeared headed toward a victory in New Jersey.

The New York City Opera has postponed indefinitely the opening of its fall season at the New York State Theater because of failure by the company and its orchestra musicians to negotiate a new labor contract.

The election of John J. Yorwerth as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Buckingham Corporation, importer of Cutty Sark Scotch whisky, was announced yesterday. Charles Bechert remains as president of the company and becomes chief operating officer.
Crowell Collier Macmillan, Inc., completed arrangements yesterday to acquire control of G. Schirmer, Inc., the 107-year-old music publishing and printing concern.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 10 -- Until 10 years ago the rhinoceros was a frequent visitor to the northern provinces of South Vietnam -- rumbling down from southern China to breed in the dense jungles along the Laotian border.
PARIS, Sept. 12 -- The French Government denied today that one of its officials had been agitating in Manitoba in "an underhanded and surreptitious way."

William H. Booth, chairman of the City Human Rights Commission, yesterday urged the city's teachers not to strike today. He contended in a statement that binding arbitration was provided for in the event of any future transfers during decentralization.
LILO'S DIARY. By Richard M. Elman. 155 pages. Scribners. $4.95. A MARRIED MAN. By Benjamin DeMott. 153 pages. Harcourt, Brace World. $3.95.

The premiere of "Before I Wake," at the Greenwich Mews Theater, is set for Oct. 14. Ernest Hemingway and F. Scott Fitzgerald are portrayed in Trevor Reese's two-character play, dealing with the 17-year friendship of the two authors before Mr. Fitzgerald's death in 1940. Norman Budd will direct the offering, to be presented by Frank S. Stuart and Charles Harrow.

Federal District Judge Edward C. McLean ruled yesterday that the International Controls Corporation of Fairfield, N. J., be subject to a hearing for a permanent injunction in October on charges that it violated Federal securities laws in its tender offer for 500,000 common shares of Electronic Specialty Company's stock.

TANNERSVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association approved a resolution today condemning any group or person bringing discredit on the New York Police Department through "unlawful, antisocial or violent acts."

A SUPERLATIVE exhibition of the masters of modern European painting opened yesterday in the galleries of the Center for Inter-American Relations, 680 Park Avenue at 68th Street. Entitled "Cezanne to Miro," and consisting of 54 paintings on loan from major museum and private collections in the United States, this exceptional anthology of classic works from the years 1880 to 1945 has just returned from a South American tour.
WALL STREET'S rumor mill is still turning and there is no sign that the Securities and Exchange Commission's crackdown on the peddling of insider information will stop the wheel.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union indicated today it still hoped to hold a world Communist conference despite the disarray in the international movement brought on by the invasion of Czechoslovakia.
The Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, long associated with the pleasing rather than the frenetic musical sound, will reverberate with rock for the first time beginning this evening.

LAMPEDUSA ISLAND, Italy, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Fishermen pulled in their boats, peasants stayed at home in this vintage time and all other workers remained idle today in a general strike against the prospect of having this most far-off of Italy's islands turned into a nuclear-waste cemetery.

The City Board of Education asked the State Education Commissioner, Dr. James E. Allen Jr., to intervene last night after Mayor Lindsay had failed in his attempt to avert a new teachers' strike set for today.

The 46,000-ton Italian Line passenger vessel Michelangelo sailed at noon yesterday with 995 passengers for the Mediterranean 15 1/2 hours late as the result of a crew sitdown. The work stoppage is one in a series of demonstrations beinng staged by Italian seamen in Italian and foreign ports to bring pressure on employers with whom they are negotiating for a new contract.

YONKERS, Sept. 12 -- Mrs. Joan Cruise's homebred Bar Man, a 6-year-old black gelding who had been campaigning with moderate success at Vernon Downs upstate, fared handsomely tonight in his first outing at the current Yonkers Raceway meeting.
PARIS, Sept. 12 -- Censorship of the radio and television monopoly goes on despite a recent reorganization and official announcements of reform.
The Collins Aikman Corporation achieved record results in the three and six months ended Aug. 31, the diversified textile producer reported yesterday.

SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Sept. 12 -- A petition to give Billy Mills an opportunity to compete in the 5,000-meter final tomorrow has been signed by more than 40 athletes at the United States Olympic track trials.

With its demand that the governing board of Ocean Hill-Brownsville be removed and its administrator fired, the United Federation of Teachers has returned to its irresponsible game of escalating and embittering an already tragically divisive conflict. By its persistent obstruction of decentralization, the union has managed to place itself -- willy-nilly -- in a position of hostility toward Negro communities in search of a greater voice in the management of their schools.

PRAGUE, Sept. 12 -- A nationwide radio and television speech by Alexander Dubcek, the Czechoslovak Communist leader, was not delivered as scheduled tonight after a phone call to broadcasting stations from the party's Central Committee.

PARIS, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Foreign Minister Michel Debre said today that despite the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia and unrest at home French foreign policy would remain the same, including barring Britain from the European Common Market.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Following "Spitting Image" as London's second homosexual play this week, Christopher Hampton's "Total Eclipse," at the Royal Court theater, is a study of the tragicomic attachment between Arthur Rimbaud and Paul Verlaine -- two heroes of France's fin-de-siecle Bohemia who deserve to rank as patron saints of the swinging sixties.

Two loans totaling $600,000 from the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company will help start the $1.1-billion redevelopment of a 104-acre section of Lower Manhattan. The project is sponsored by the Battery Park City Corporation Authority.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Charles E. Goodell was sworn in today as New York's second Republican Senator and was promptly assigned to a seat in the back row and to two minor committees.

SAIGON, Sept, 12 (UPI) -- American battlefield deaths in Vietnam decreased sharply last week -- from 408 the previous week to 195, United States headquarters said today. The number of Americans wounded in the week fell from 2,513 to 1,400.
SUTTON, Mass., Sept. 12 -- Joel Goldstrand of Worthington, Minn., who likes to call himself a "rabbit" on the pro golf tour, jumped into the lead of the $150,000 Kemper open tourney today with a 67.

Almost a decade after Jack Gelber, an ex-mimeograph operator at the United Nations (night shift) achieved wide acclaim with "The Connection," produced off Broadway, he's finally making it uptown. "The Cuban Thing," a play by him about the Castro revolution, opens the Broadway season Tuesday at Henry Miller's Theater.
The appointment of Larry Levy as vice president and merchandise manager of Broadstreet's was announced yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 12 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk walked through a picket line of 650 nonviolent student demonstrators here tonight to deliver a speech calling for "a dialogue in which both generations can contribute something."

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Two of the most important Argentine morning newspapers, La Nacion and La Prensa, poured praise today on New York City Opera singer Beverly Sills for her performance in "Julius Caesar" at the Colon Theater here.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Credit managers are following "a marked trend toward overindulgence of the consumer," a top executive of a commercial-finance company warned today.
PRAGUE, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that he could neither confirm nor deny a dispatch of the Yugoslav press agency Tanyug that Foreign Minister Jiri Hajek had resigned.
THE time when a woman really cares how she looks is at night, right? That's when she counts on her hairdresser, her beautician and her dressmaker to do their best by her, right?

THE major league baseball players are developing their counter - move on what they consider "stalling" on the part of the owners in negotiations for a new pension plan agreement. The current pact, under which $4.1-million a year goes to the pension fund from tele vision revenues, expires in 1969.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A right-wing branch of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's governing Rhodesian Front resigned today from the party, demonstrating a hardening resolve to force a white-supremacist constitution.

More training of community theater leaders and directors, encouragement of playwrights to use American themes, development of regional theaters and establishment of a national theater festival are urged in a report issued this week by the National Theater Conference.
Metromedia, the broad-casting network, has invited the three major Presidential candidates to participate in a 90-minute debate next month
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- The Albanian National Assembly will decide tomorrow whether to withdraw from the Warsaw Pact, the Tirana radio reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- President Johnson says that Airman Patrick J. Nugent has been temporarily grounded for flying too much in Vietnam and that Marine Capt. Charles S. Robb can judge when an enemy shell is close enough to disrupt a shower.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Joey Que, owned by Charles and Frances Quimby of Centreville, Md., won the $3,000 Woodbridge Chamber of Commerce pace at Freehold Raceway today, paying $9, $4.40 and $4.20 for $2 across the board.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Association of American Railroads reported freight traffic in the week ended Sept. 7 totaled an estimated 12.7-billion ton-miles, an increase of 3.8 per cent over the comparable week a year ago.

The nation's mutual savings banks had a net deposit gain of $175-million during August, down from a net gain of $283-million in the corresponding month last year, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The House passed today a compromise bill to authorize a Redwoods National Park of not more than 58,000 acres in the California North Coast region.

Riders in Spanish costumes will parade their horses from the Plaza Hotel to the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park the evening of Sept. 26 to open the Feria de Sevilla. Others in fancy dress will arrive in carriages for the ball to be held at the restaurant for the benefit of the Helen Keller World Crusade for the Blind.

SUTTON, Mass., Sept. 12 -- The Professional Golfers' Association's executive committee agreed today to accept a proposal of the International Golf Sponsors Association for the operation of the National P.G.A. tour.

NEWARK, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A Municipal Court judge, in a trailblazing ruling today, ordered a jury trial for Henry M. DiSuvere, former executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union in New Jersey.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 12 -- Addressing himself to a Southern television audience tonight for the first time in his national campaign, Richard M. Nixon firmly upheld the Supreme Court's school desegregation decision. However, he expressed strong reservations about some of the methods the Government has used to enforce that decision.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- A former United States marine who deserted in Tokyo and later denounced the "immoral Vietnam war" on Soviet television said today he would return to the United States voluntarily tomorrow.
The crises over decentralization and community control of the schools is the culmination of developments over the last two years in the separate but interlocking situations.

Loew's Theatres, Inc., at a special meeting yesterday increased its offer to acquire the Lorillard Corporation, a leading cigarette producer. At a separate meeting, Lorillard directors approved the new terms.
DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Glen Hepburn, a 29-year-old linebacker for the Omaha Mustangs, died today from head injuries suffered in a Continental Football League game Saturday.
Harry Kronman took up the collection of discount coupons 18 months ago after retiring as a grocer, the Government charged yesterday, in a business venture that brought in $2,000 a week.
BONN, Sept. 11 -- Lieut. Gen. Albert Schnez, commander of a West German Army corps, will succeed Lieut. Gen. Josef Moll as head of West Germany's armed forces, the Defense Ministry announced today.

In the American political dictionary, certain words and phrases have acquired a bad name. Isolationism, power politics, balance of power, and spheres of influence are all supposed to be slightly villainous and obsolete, but they keep coming back to the center of world politics.

Duke Ellington, Lena Horne and other performers will appear at a memorial concert for Billy Strayhorn at Philharmonic Hall on Sunday, Oct. 6, at 8 P.M. Mr. Strayhorn, who wrote "Take the A Train" and was Mr. Ellington's close associate for many years, died June 1, 1967.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 12 -- The deforming effects of thalidomide are related to the drug's molecular shape, Dr. Heinz M. Wuest, a New York chemist, reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- For a man who loves to talk, Hubert H. Humphrey is in an intolerable position: He is running into trouble no matter what he says. This is an embarrassing, but not a new, position for the Vice President. He has long been known as a man who talked too much.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 11 -- In Tulsa a couple of nights ago, Senator A. S. Mike Monroney stood on a folding chair in a shopping center and told a small crowd of admirers some of the things that Oklahoma's influential Democrats in Congress had accomplished.
DALLAS, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Chuck Tanner, manager of the champion El Paso Sun Kings, has been named the Texas League's manager of the year.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced plans yesterday for a nationwide voter registration drive the week of Sept. 15.

A 21-year-old youth who almost lost his life in an upstate auto accident three years ago won a $500,000 out-of-court settlement yesterday.

The still-unanswered question, more than three weeks later, is whether the shock administered by that coup will endure long enough to fuel a long-overdue updating of NATO political and military policy.

William Talman, who played Hamilton Burger, the losing prosecutor of the "Perry Mason" television series, will appear posthumously on TV in a dramatic warning on the hazards of smoking. Mr. Talman, 53 years old, died of lung cancer two weeks ago.

The sound judgment of supervisors and rank-and-file unionists has brought the ctiy's subway system safely through what might have been a dangerous disruption. The sharp contrast between this transit experience and the turbulence in the school system provides much-needed proof that the welfare of the city and of public employes can best be protected by adherence to the orderly procedures guaranteed by municipal and state law.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Department of Commerce reported today that estimated total rettail store sales for the week ended Sept. 7 were $6.228-billion, 10 per cent above the $5.677-billion sales for the corresponding period of last year.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Bert Braun and Fred Lazard of the Garden City Golf Club tied today with 77's in the first day's play of the Long Island senior golf championship. One hundred forty six competitors played the par 35, 36 -- 71, 6,316-yard Southward Ho Country Club course.
Money eased during the week ended Wednesday, banking figures published yesterday showed.

OTTAWA, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- The average yield on today's weekly issue of $130-million in 91-day Canadian treasury bills rose to 5.60 per cent from last week's 5.58 per cent, while the average price fell to 98.622 cents from 98.627.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 12 -- Edmund S. Muskie charged today that Richard M. Nixon was using "big city lawyer" skills to mislead the American voter on issues and thus advance his bid for the Presidency.

MAYSVILLE, Ky., Sept. 12 (UPI) -- The Maysville City Commission accepted "with sadness" tonight the resignation of Mayor Ernest Heinisch, 50 years old, who faces charges of bank embezzlement. Mr. Heinisch is a former vice president of the Maysville State National Bank.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 12 -- George C. Wallace scored a victory of aggressiveness tonight before the most tumultuous rally of his third-party Presidential campaign.
OTTAWA, Sept. 12 -- The Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau committed itself today to build a "just society" for Canada.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Right Rev. Joseph Minnis, who is facing trial by an ecclesiastical court in Denver Sept. 23, has resigned as Episcopal bishop of Colorado, a church publication said today.
ROCHESTER, Sept. 12 -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew of Maryland took back today his charge that Hubert H. Humphrey was "soft on Communism."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The American Automobile Association has charged the Department of Transportation with defiance of the will of Congress in cutting back highway expenditures by $200-million.

Several more of the respondents in the Securities and Exchange Commission's administrative proceding against Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith and 14 investment companies have replied to the S.E.C.'s charges.
Helen Hayes will narrate a one-hour documentary based on the works of Rachel Carson, the late marine biologist and author, on the American Broadcasting Company Wednesday, Nov. 13, at 7:30 P.M.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- The Defense Department today identified these servicemen from New York as among those killed in Vietnam:

TOKYO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- United States and Japanese military security officials agreed at the close of a two-day meeting here today that American military bases must remain in Japan to maintain security in this area.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Israeli Army reported today that Arab gunners had opened fire on an Israeli patrol near Asdot Yaakov, which is south of the Sea of Galilee. It added that the fire was returned. No casualties were reported.

The principal of a Brooklyn elementary school was escorted inside by the police yesterday despite the protests of parents who want her transferred because she closed the school during the two-day teachers' strike earlier this week.

PARIS, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- Daniel Cohn-Bendit qualified for part of his sociology degree here without the usual examination, canceled because of the French student rebellion in the spring. The student leader, called "Danny the Red," was judged to have passed on the basis of previous work.
Miralgo carried top weight of 156 pounds to a decisive triumph in the $11,350 Rouge Dragon Hurdle Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

RUSTENBERG, South Africa, Sept. 12 (Reuters) -- Sixty Africans, including a 98-year-old woman, were fined or imprisoned today for failing to obey a court order uprooting them from their traditional land.

Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, who has almost left the national scene since the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, popped up yesterday as a gate crasher at the 35th anniversary party of Esquire magazine, and stole the show by describing the political campaign in a football story.

ROME, Sept, 12 -- Filming of a docile, amateur sort seems to be going on all over Italy these sunny days and one is constantly turning corners to find a hand-held camera filming sailors in Olbia, hippies in the Piazza Navona or Piazza di Spagna, tourists over their postcards at the Lido Excelsior or Romans over their lunch almost anywhere.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Budget Director Charles J. Zwick told Congress today that unavoidable expenditure increases of $7-billion to $9-billion were already in store for the next budget.
ABILENE, Tex., Sept. 12 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted 13 persons today for swindling 21 churches across the Eastern half of the United States of about $5-million in 1965.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The world-trade position of the United States "is being seriously damaged by the wage-price spiral in which we are engaged," Secretary of Commerce C. R. Smith said today.
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Daryle Lamonica signed a three-year contract for an estimated $200,000 with the Oakland Raiders today, the Raiders announced.

BLUE POINT, L. I., Sept. 12 -- Perry Duryea, Republican minority leader of the Assembly, warned today that if George Wallace received 20 per cent of the national vote and forced the House of Representatives to decide the Presidential election there would be further racial outbreaks in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- A special envoy of the West German Government agreed today with the United States on the principle of increased European support for the military preparedness of the Western alliance.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 12 -- A middle-aged woman ran breathlessly to a group of American tourists in the lobby of the Foresta Hotel and exclaimed: "Guess who I've just seen? Floyd Patterson, the United States boxer!"
Federal mediators will make another attempt today to resume contract negotiations in the longshore industry.
DETROIT, Sept. 12 -- A push-button ashtray is offered as a luxury feature on the full-sized 1969 Oldsmobiles, which were shown to newsmen today.

TOKYO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Students of Nihon University, pressing demands for school reforms, clashed with policemen in downtown Tokyo today. The police said that 59 people had been injured and that 154 students had been arrested.

Lewis S. Rosenstiel, the peppery, 77-year-old chairman of Schenley Industries, Inc., is marking the end of a lifelong career in the liquor industry by giving away more than $50-million in the next few months.

THE methods of bidding used by the Italians in winning 11 world championships have long been barred for use in this country, because the authorities have felt that the average player would be placed at a disadvantage in playing against them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, criticized today a bill that would allow Richard M. Nixon-Hubert H. Humphrey television debates this year by suspending a rule requiring equal time for minority candidates.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- About 3,500 San Franciscans have registered about 7,000 weapons since Aug. 16 under the city's new gun control law. The authorities believe that is about one out of 50 of the guns in the hands of city residents.
KARLOVY VARY, Czechoslovakia -- In the late Victorian era, and right up to the outbreak of World War I, this lovely Bohemian city was one of the fashionable resorts of Europe.
The governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to suspend trading in the common stock of the Continental Insurance Company, New York, effective Monday morning.
DUQUE DE CAXIAS, Brazil, Sept. 10 -- The flood of rural migrants that has been inundating Brazil's urban centers reaches the city limits of Rio de Janeiro at this railroad town.

The National Safety Council has appointed H. Gene Miller, now manager of its statistical department, as general manager for program operations. WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- A "growing Soviet physical presence in the Middle East" and "increased Arab bellicosity" are grave threats to lasting peace in the area, Senator Jacob K. Javits said today.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican, says his campaign expenses went up this year -- he spent $17.09 to win both the Republican and Democratic nominations for re-election Tuesday, about $3 more than he spent six years ago.
A new Bishop of Brooklyn, the Most Rev. Francis J. Mugavero, was ordained yesterday to head the nation's largest Roman Catholic diocese.

The Harris Survey confirmed yesterday one of the basic assumptions that has governed Richard M. Nixon's campaign thus far: that "law and order" is one of the most powerful issues running in his favor this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Justice William O. Douglas granted a last-minute reprieve from Vietnam to 113 soldiers today so that the Supreme Court could rule on their challenge to President Johnson's call-up of reservists.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept 12 -- The United States today charged the Soviet Union with violations of the public law of the United Nations Charter in its invasion and occupation of Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The House sent to the Senate by roll-call vote today a record $72.2-billion defense appropriation bill after beating all attempts to change it. The vote was 334 to 7.

The faculty of Columbia University met to adopt a new set of rules governing campus protests yesterday while some 200 student activists attempted to force their way into the building in which the professors were deliberating.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- An authoritative private study issued today reports that the Soviet Union has rushed construction of land-based intercontinental ballistic missiles and now has almost as many as the United States.
