The Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad announced yesterday the election of Theodore E. Desch as vice president and general counsel. Mr. Desch, 36 years old, joined the Rock Island 12 years ago as an assistant general attorney.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 -- Doctors and engineers unveiled today what they called the "Boston arm," an electronically operated artificial limb that an amputee flexes simply by willing it to flex, as is done with a natural arm.
Bond prices inched upward slightly yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- The number of television stations that will show Mayor Richard J. Daley's one-hour film giving the city's version of what happened on the streets of Chicago during the Democratic convention rose to 95 today.

SEA GIRT, N. J., Sept. 12 -- In a forceful extension of his argument with Richard M. Nixon about how to deal with the Soviet Union, Vice President Humphrey called again today for immediate Senate approval of the so-called nuclear nonproliferation treaty.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Frank Howard's second homer of the game and 42d of the season broke a 1-1 tie in the seventh inning tonight as the Washington Senators defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 4-1, snapping Dave McNally's 12-game winning streak.

The General Motors Corporation is moving the 3,300 employes of its New York office into the 50-story marble-and-glass skyscraper that has just about been completed on the site of the Savoy-Plaza Hotel on Fifth Avenue, between 58th and 59th Streets.
BETHLEHEM TOWNSHIP, N. J., Sept. 12 (AP) -- A 13-acre tract in this Hunterdon County community owned by David Dellinger, a pacifist, has been put up for tax sale.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- A would-be arsonist lobbed two gasoline bombs at a home for aged citizens in a southside Syracuse neighborhood today.

"ALTHOUGH I recognize the futility of my trying," said Stirling Moss, "I still have the itch to return to auto racing. It's like drug addiction. You know you shouldn't but you damn well want to. Nothing in this world can approach the life of a Grand Prix driver."
The election of James D. Fullerton as senior vice president of the Capital Group, Inc., was announced yesterday.

The E. J. Korvette discount-store division of Spartans Industries, which decided two years ago against any new stores until it had consolidated its position and improved earnings, has resumed its expansion program and plans to open 28 new stores by 1971.

The Tristate Transportation Commission is exploring the possibility of using a Coast and Geodetic Survey satellite for its next round of mapping its megalopolitan area, which branches out from New York City to Trenton, Middletown and Red Hook, N. Y., and New Haven and Meriden, Conn.
The Metropolitan Opera, which opens its season Monday, has announced the engagement of 11 new singers and one conductor.

TAYNINH, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 13 -- Enemy troops dodged allied units on the outskirts of this provincial capital yesterday morning, but then struck in an ambush of a truck convoy that touched off sharp but sporadic fighting the rest of the day.
DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Initial clinical tests have been conducted on a combined live virus vaccine against measles, mumps and German measles, a Pennsylvania virologist reported today.
The wholesale commodity price index remained unchanged at 94.2 on Wednesday from Tuesday.
Federal and local authorities yesterday arrested five members of the Black Panther party, including the reputed East Coast leader of the militant organization, in two separate incidents in Brooklyn.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- It was too good to last. When the French Government abruptly abandoned controls on foreign exchange early this month, it brought tears to the eyes of smart operators here and closed another glorious chapter in the history of the Rente Pinay.

A Board of Education adviser said yesterday that the board had promised to transfer quietly teachers who were unacceptable to the Ocean Hill-Brownsville Demonstration School District, but that the district's governing board would not go along.

Three glamorous industries -motion pictures, publishing and liquor -- are intertwined in a series of financial and business maneuvers currently under way that has the financial community buzzing from Broadway to the East River.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 13 -- It has been three years since Bucknell has had a winning football season, but many more years since the Bisons have had an offensive backfield as good as the one they will field next week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- A Jewish theologian appealed today to American Jews to rethink their voting patterns and support a "responsible conservatism'' that advocates due process of law over violence, rioting and racism.

Dr. Israel Goldstein, whose entry in "Who's Who" reads like a chronicle of American Jewish history since World War I, will celebrate his 50th anniversary as a rabbi today at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, where he began his career in 1918.
HOUSTON, Sept. 13 -- The National Council of Churches urged today the abolition of capital punishment, calling it a contributor to the "brutalization of society."

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 13 -- Under the shadow of an art gallery, with soft music in the air, Jimmy Ellis weighed in today at 198 pounds and Floyd Patterson at 188 1/2 for their heavyweight title fight tomorrow.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Keith L. Ware, a World War II Medal of Honor winner and commander of the United States First Infantry Division, was killed today as his command helicopter crashed in flames near the Cambodian border.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 -- When a panelist on a local television show asked Mr. Nixon tonight whether there had been a deal between him and Senator Thurmond to oppose Justice Fortas, Mr. Nixon replied:

TOKYO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- North Korea reported today that the skipper of the intelligence ship Pueblo, seized by the North Koreans on Jan. 23, had admitted that he knew of two other United States Navy ships that carried out spy missions against Communist nations.
James L. Marcus, once an influential member of the Lindsay administration, was led off in manacles yesterday to begin serving a 15-month prison sentence.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Red Cross suspended its flights of food to Biafra today because of fighting near its two landing strips.
WASHINGTON Sept. 13 (AP) -- President Johnson announced today the three-man high command of a new agency that will distribute anticrime grants to states and cities.

Sporadic violence, including an attempt by 150 people to storm a Bronx police station, erupted yesterday as parents and sympathizing teachers tried to keep some city schools open despite the teachers' strike.

A new legal rate of $3.50 a cubic yard for commercial refuse removal was established yesterday by Joseph L. Forstadt, acting Licenses Commissioner, to replace the old rate of $2.75, which had been in effect five years.

Milton Esterow, former assistant to the metropolitan editor of The New York Times, has been named associate director of the Kennedy Galleries, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Lawrence A. Fleischman, gallery director.

SEASIDE PARK, N. J., Sept. 13 -- Vice President Humphrey turned a barefoot jog along the beach here today into a bareknuckled thrashing of his Republican opponent as a dangerous demagogue, a dealer with extremists and a Fearless Fosdick selling counterfeit solutions to crime.
MOSCOW, Sept. 13 -- The Soviet Union charged tonight that "right-wing antisocialist elements" were holding responsible Government and public posts in Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -Senator Jacob K. Javits told the Senate today that he had found "no hard evidence" that antiSemitism was behind the opposition to the confirmation of Associate Justice Abe Fortas as Chief Justice of the United States.

Recognition of the need for major governmental safeguards against pollution of the environment is growing. Technological advances and increasing population pressures now make it advisable to guarantee basic ecological rights which would have hardly been thought of a generation ago.

Directors of Ebasco Industries, Inc., have named Charles K. Rieger chief executive officer, effective Oct. 1, it was announced yesterday. He succeeds George G. Walker, 65 years old, who retires as chairman.

WATERVILLE, Me., Sept. 13 -- Carl T. Rowan, former director of the United States Information Agency and now a nationally syndicated columnist, has been chosen by Colby College as the 1968 Elijah Parish Lovejoy Fellow.

A 40-year-old Jesuit priest, who is a student at the Yale Drama School, will have his first play produced here. Written by the Rev. Ernest Ferlita, "The Ballad of John Ogilvie" will open the 28th season of the Blackfriars Guild 320 West 57th Street, on Oct. 8.

A director of the Law Enforcement Group said yesterday that members of his organization would continue to mobilize the police and the public in the fight against crime despite the threat of expulsion from the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -Attorney General Ramsey Clark charged tonight that partisan politics and a desire to "roll back civil rights" lay behind Senate opposition to the nomination of Associate Justice Abe Fortas as Chief Justice.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has demanded an example be made of those responsible for the ritual slaying of a 12-year-old boy in Rajasthan state.
TONY COLECCHIO says he's not superstitious, but you wouldn't have guessed it yesterday. It was Friday the 13th, and he was trembling.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 13 -Edwin H. May Jr., Republican candidate for the United States Senate, today sharply criticized his opponent, Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, as having "removed himself from the mainstream" of American thinking on Vietnam.

SALISBURY, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Smith strengthened his hand in the Cabinet today by appointing John H. Howman, his Information Minister, as Minister of External Affairs. Mr. Howman has consistently supported Mr. Smith in his battle with rightwingers in the Cabinet and the party.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -A magazine editor has invented equipment to be worn by emphysema sufferers that automatically releases supplemental oxygen for breathing.

One of the largest salary increases awarded by the city to any group of public employes was announced yesterday by the bargaining representatives for more than 1,500 internes and residents on the payroll of the municipal hospital system.
NAGASAKI, Japan, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Nagasaki procurator's office indicted Dr. Earle Reynolds, American pacifist, and his Japanese wife today on charges of having violated Japanese immigration laws.

A remarkably realistic and superbly sensitive documentary on the tensions besetting American society, arising in large measure from the contrast between Negro ghettos and affluent white suburban communities, was presented by the National Broadcasting Company last night in its first white paper of the fall season.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 13 (AP) -- The United States open tennis champion, Arthur Ashe Jr., beat Clark Graebner, 9-7, 6-3, today to win the Desert Inn invitational tennis tournament singles title. In the doubles final, Graebner and Charles Pasarell upset Bob Lutz and Stan Smith, 6-3, 7-5.
While the precious metals platinum and silver held mostly steady in futures trading yesterday, speculators were showing a little new interest in a more basic metal -- copper.

LONDON, Sept. 13 (AP) -David Knox, a British information official in the Bahamas who was pardoned by President Francois Duvalier of Haiti after an espionage conviction, arrived with his wife today in London. He went directly from the airport to the Commonwealth office.
A new teachers' strike, the second this week, crippled the city school system yesterday, causing 1.1 million pupils to miss classes.
SAIGON, Sept. 13 -- American troops engaged in several skirmishes with enemy troops near the Special Forces camp of Duclap yesterday, a United States military spokesman reported.

BREAKFAST is the meal that most persons feel strongest about and is therefore the most inconsistent. Some people pass it up altogether, some take fruit juice and coffee, often on the run, and some want the works, from grapefruit through oatmeal, kippered herrings, eggs and toast with strawberry jam.

PARIS, Sept. 13 -- Maurice Chevalier spent his 80th birthday on this side of the footlights last night, as a guest of honor at the Lido cabaret where a sound-and-light tribute to his 65-year theatrical career was tacked on to the ChampsElusees nightclub's regular revue.
The reading appetite of crews of ships active in the Vietnam sealift last year resulted in increased activity for the American Merchant Marine Library Association.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 13 -- On a chilly hill in a Stockholm park last night, on a platform surrounded by red flags, a girl sang and talked to a crowd of 10,080 about Joe Hill, the Swedish-born American radical of the early ninteen-hundreds.
BERLIN, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -East Germany's propaganda chief, Albert Norden, 64 years old, is ill and in a hospital, the Communist party newspaper Neues Deutschland said today.
SUTTON, Mass., Sept. 13 -Arnold Palmer left his middleof-the-road position today and threw in his lot with the touring golf professionals in their dispute with the Professional Golfers' Association.

A Staten Island housewife won a $50,000 settlement yesterday in the first case in New York in which a wife has received damages for the loss of her husband's consortium from the party responsible for injuries to him.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today to tighten regulations on stock brokers who fail to deliver shares to customers on time.

The Republican and Liberal parties must share with the Democratic party the guilt for the nomination of three unfit candidates for the Supreme Court at the disgraceful judicial conventions of the First Judicial Department last week. The leaders of all three political parties broke pledges not to nominate candidates rejected by the Citizens Committee on the Judiciary.
Senator Jacob K. Javits and his Conservative opponent, James Buckley, agreed yesterday that the striking teachers should return to work in New York City.
The Boeing Company has all but abandoned the swing-wing concept that helped it win a Government contest to build the nation's supersonic airliner.

The highest Off Broadway top of $6.95 for week-end performances will be established by the program of Harold Pinter's new plays, "Tea Party" and "The Basement," arriving Oct. 15 at the Eastside Playhouse. A spokesman said: "We feel they're worth it.

SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 12 -- North Korea, now celebrating its 20th anniversary, is suspicious of foreigners, imposing strict control over its own population, and says little about itself in public.

MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (AP) -Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party chief, and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin made a jovial appearance at an Italian industrial exhibition today, mixing with the crowd and joking with exhibitors.

Scores of leading football games will be given at the end of the WQXR 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone the New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -The New York Yankees ran their winning streak to eight games tonight -- their longest in four years -- by sweeping a double-header from the Washington Senators.
HOUSTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -A company, official said today that the Armco Steel Corporation plant in Houston would lay off about 750 workers by Sept. 30 because of a drop in steel orders.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Sept. 14 -- A United States task force supported by tanks and Navy ships has raided the southern half of the demilitarized zone and killed 158 North Vietnamese soldiers, military spokesmen announced today.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- Walter W. Heller, former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, forecast today the need for maintaining last January's foreigninvestment restrictions on United States companies into 1969.

Stockholders of the H. J. Heinz Company at the annual meeting yesterday in Pittsburgh elected as directors John E. Crossen, 49, and Donald C. McVay Jr., 53. They were also elected members of the executive committee at the board meeting following the stockholder session.

The Democratic and Republican county executive committees of the Bronx, meeting separately, yesterday nominated the same four candidates for newly created Civil Court judgeships that will be filled in November.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission gave the television networks 20 days today to examine and comment on "hundreds of complaints" it had received about coverage of events in Chicago during the Democratic National Convention.

THEODORE LIGHTNER of New York, one of the greatest players in the history of the game, celebrates his 75th birthday today. HAMILTON Ontario, Sept. 13 -- Painstakingly, the voluminous papers of Lord Russell, the 96year-old British mathematician, philosopher and political radical, are being catalogued and microfilmed in a second-floor, back room of the McMaster University Library.

"The End Is Here, Baby!," a rock version of the morality play, "Everyman," will be given a free outdoor performance at 5:30 P.M. tomorrow at the Lincoln Center Plaza. James Lawrence, a printer employed at the United Nations, will perform the title role.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 13 -- Three Rhodesian judges, sitting as the court of appeal of the Rhodesian High Court, gave legal recognition today to the Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith. The judges ruled that the Smith Government, which declared Rhodesia independent of Britain in November, 1965, was the only legal administration.

Marie Koscak Yadzinski, a violinist with the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, made her New York debut last night at Town Hall playing Corelli's "La Folia," Beethoven's "Kreutzer" Sonata, Debussy's Sonata, Ravel's "Tzigane" and Webern's Four Pieces (Op. 7).
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified the following men from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- The Tirana radio reported that Albania formally withdrew from the Warsaw Pact today. The action by the Albanian Parliament followed denunciation of the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia and years of friction with Moscow.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 13 (Agence France-Presse) -- A list of 71 Americans -- 69 airmen and two civilians -- reported missing in Laos since 1964 and possibly captured by the Pathet Lao was submitted to representatives of the Communist-led guerrilla group here last month by the International Committee of the Red Cross, it was announced here today by Soth Pethrasi, Pathet Lao delegate.

ELLWOOD CITY, Pa., Sept. 13 (UPI) -- The former Princess Ileana of Rumania, now Mother Alexandra, will be consecrated as Mother Superior of the Monastery of Transfiguration Sept. 28 in dedication ceremonies of the monastery.
Yesterday was American Dream Day for the man whose fondest aspiration is to operate his own business.

"I know why you came here tonight -- to hear Rusty Warren talk about sex," says Rusty Warren to her Latin Quarter audience. Of course they did, and of course she does.

BUFFALO, Sept. 13 -- The Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory here will seek to make helicopters quieter and more efficient by changing the design of the tips of their rotor blades. To buffs of Arthur Conan Doyle, the clue to the winner of the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday was obvious even before the race went off. The event was the Silver Blaze Purse, an annual event named for the Baker St. Irregulars, the group of dedicated aficionados of the eminent Sherlock Holmes.
DETROIT, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A 52 per cent boost in production was set this week by the nation's automakers, the trade paper Automotive News reported today.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 -- Vice President Humphrey flew here this evening for an overnight round of campaign appearances and kept up his running criticisms of Mr. Nixon.

TWO tile plaques made in Salzburg, Austria, in about 1560 have the featured spot to the left of the grand stairway on the main floor of the Metropolitan Museum of Art that is reserved for significant new acquisitions.

The New York Telephone Company announced last night the ratification of a contract covering 15,700 of its employes represented by the independent Telephone Traffic Union.

DETROIT, Sept. 13 -- Big labor, though organically split many ways, has united at the top behind Vice President Humphrey, only to find some of its members below going in other directions or immovable.

The United States Senate was urged yesterday by the executive board of the Maritime Trades Department of the A. F. L.-C. I. O. to take immediate and favorable action on pending legislation to create an independent Maritime Administration.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -The Navy said today that 30,000 reservists who had enlisted for two years would be released from active duty ahead of time. The decision has been made to save money.

The Fortas and Thornberry nominations for Chief Justice and Associate Justice of the Supreme Court are expected to reach the floor of the United States Senate next week after a journey of two and a half months through the shoals of Chairman Eastland's Judiciary Committee. Although the committee has promised to allow the nominations out next Tuesday, the price paid is the continuation of hearings until then and the threat of a filibuster thereafter.

DALLAS, Sept. 13 (AP) -United States District Judge Sarah T. Hughes ordered a Dallas-based diet pill concern today to destroy all dosages containing thyroid and digitalis. The decision could have a staggering effect on the weight reducing medication industry.

THORPE BAY, England, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- The American International Catamaran Trophy team managed to repair its wrecked boat in time for a scheduled race today, but the race was abandoned for lack of wind.

Directors of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Co. yesterday elected James A. Zeigler as a director and vice president, Mr. Zeigler, president of the Middle Wstern Division in Chicago, fills a vacancy on the 17-man board.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (UPI) -- Senator Thurmond, apprised of the Vice President's remarks, said today, "That's ridiculous. Humphrey must be getting desperate." He added that he had never discussed the Fortas issue with Mr. Nixon, but that even if Mr. Nixon had asked him to drop his fight against Justice Fortas, "no one, including Mr. Nixon, could change my mind."

Prices advanced on a broad front in active trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Volume came to 7,076,915 shares, against 6,180,100 on Thursday. Of 992 issues traded, 478 advanced and 364 declined.
The hard rock music played at the Fillmore East yesterday afternoon received the rapt and serious attention of an audience not generally calculated to dig its wild and ear-shattering sound.

CALDWELL, Idaho, Sept. 14 (UPI) -- Sandra Haynie, fresh from her first triumph of the season, shared the first-round lead today in the Shirley Englehorn Invitation golf tournament with Clifford Ann Creed and Sandra Miller.

SANTA ISABEL, Spanish Equatorial Guinea -- When the explorer and writer Mary Kingsley saw the island of Fernando Po in a January sunset 73 years ago, she said it floated "like a fairy island made of gold or of amethyst."

WASHINGTON, Sept 13 -The Federal Government's chief traffic safety expert said today that built-in bars to protect automobile passengers in sideimpact crashes were a "must" for all vehicles "as soon as possible."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A White House spokesman said today he would follow a general rule of ignoring antiAdministration campaign statements by Richard M. Nixon "unless thoroughly aroused."

PLATTEKILL, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- A Westchester County deputy sheriff and one of three prisoners he was helping transport were shot to death today when the prisoners tried to escape on the New York Thruway near here. A second deputy and the two other prisoners were wounded.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -The Democratic National Committee has dropped Doyle Dane Berinbach, Inc., of New York and turned over the Humphrey-for-President advertising campaign entirely to Campaign Planners of Washington and New York.
The London stock market closed mixed yesterday after earlier profit taking had trimmed prices.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- Indian engineers and workmen completed what is said to be the world's highest road in the Himalaya of Kashmir. The road, running through southeastern Kashmir, passes through a 17,582-foot-high mountain pass and has an average altitude of 14,00 feet.

HINTON, Alberta, Sept. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Kelly Joachim, 27 years old, of Grande Cache, Alberta, suffered extensive leg injuries and chest bruises when mauled by a grizzly bear yesterday about 60 miles northwest of here.

CONFRONTATION with the white power structure is nothing new for Claude Herbert Oliver, chairman of the local governing board of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school district. In his home town of Birmingham, Ala., at the start of this decade; the tall, deliberateminister helped with the lunch-counter sit-ins that signaled the beginning of a new era in the Negroes' push for civil rights.
The smoke is beginning to clear on the Harris Trust and Savings Bank offering of rights to buy $25-million in convertible capital notes.

BERN, Switzerland, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Polish teams withdrew from two major European Cup soccer tournaments today, an action that sparked fear of a general Communist boycott. Pairings in both tournaments recently were redrawn so that Communist and non - Communist teams would not play one another.

Huntington Hartford, an heir to the A. P. fortune, dropped by a picket line at A. P. headquarters yesterday to lend his support to a boycott of California grapes sponsored by the United Farmworkers Union.
OHI-UTURI AIRFIELD, Biafra, Sept. 13 (Agence France-Presse) -- Although Red Cross Personnel left the airfield two days ago, other charity organizations are continuing their flights.

GRAMBLING, La., Sept. 13 -- James Gregory of Corcoran, Calif., enrolled at Grambling College today and became the first white athlete to receive a football scholarship from the institution, which has sent many well-known Negro players into professional football.

Construction began yesterday on a large, multicolored tent group at the site of the former Astor Hotel, where an invitational block party will follow the opening of the film, "Funny Girl," on Wednesday night.

Jerry Koosman pitched another shutout last night and turned his team into the best Met team in history. The rookie left-hander beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 2-0, for the Mets' 67th victory of the season, one more victory than the Mets had ever achieved in one season.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- Wrecked cars and broken glass littered the streets of Buenos Aires and provincial towns today after a night of clashes between students and the police.

LONDON, Sept. 13 (AP) -Paintings and drawings valued at more than $400,000 were stolen from two of Britain's finest collections in art raids discovered today.

SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Sept. 13 -- Two aging giants, Harold Connolly and Al Hall, won their fourth trips to the Olympic Games today, but two young track idols, Gerry Lindgren and Richmond Flowers Jr., met with frustrating failures.

Six persons, including auditing and payroll chiefs of the Neighborhood Youth Corps, were arrested yesterday on charges alleging complicity in a scheme that defrauded the youth employment project of $240,000.

The Cenco Instruments Corporation showed a rise in its sales and earnings in the first fiscal quarter ended July 31, it was reported yesterday from Chicago headquarters.
A group of 20 Americans prominent in the film industry have expressed concern for Czechoslovak film makers in a letter delivered to Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the Soviet Ambassador to the United States.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 94.3 on Thursday from 94.2 on Wednesday.

TRENTON, Sept. 13 -- The overwhelming Republican majorities in the Legislature today overrode vetoes by Gov. Richard J. Hughes and set up a $59-million school and localaid program that in most cases favors well-to-do suburbs over slum-ridden cities.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- The Vietcong broadcast repeated calls to the people of central Saigon tonight to leave the area as quickly as possible. Similar notices by the radio have not always been followed by attacks.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -Associate Justice Abe Fortas refused today to submit to further questioning by the Senate Judiciary Committee on his nomination to be Chief Justice of the United States.
FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- King Constantine of Greece and his wife, Queen Anne-Marie, arrived here from Rome today for a private visit.
The stock market moved back into an upward path yesterday, scoring a modest advance in fairly active trading for a pre-weekend session.
"The Cuban Thing" has postponed its premiere again, this time from next Tuesday night to Sept. 24 at Henry Miller's Theater. The Jack Gelber drama originally was announced to open Sept. 12.

ATLANTA, Sept. 13 (UPI) -The city's striking garbage workers accepted today the same city wage offer they rejected last night. They agreed to work tomorrow to pick up 10 days' accumulation of refuse.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 13 (Reuters) -- One Jordanian soldier was killed when Israeli and Jordanian forces exchanged fire at the northern end of the Jordan Valley this morning, a military spokesman announced.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept 13 (AP) -- Thirteen young Negroes were charged today with stoning a white woman and her 10year-old daughter yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 -Senator Edward W. Brooke of Massachusetts flew here tonight to rejoin Richard M. Nixon's entourage and to tell the Republican Presidential nominee, politely but firmly, that he had been bewildered by Mr. Nixon's recent comments on school desegregation in the South.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 13 -Two New York biochemists reported today what they believe might be the long-sought scientific reason that alcohol can cause behavioral changes ranging from euphoria through drunkenness to hallucinations.

A GROWING number of duplicate players nowadays prefer head-to-head matches between teams of four to the more familiar pair contests scored by match points.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16 -- The nervous hum of political speculation is beginning here again after a lull of a couple of months.

It is unfortunate that the bill which would permit TV debates between Vice President Humphrey and Mr. Nixon seems to be irretrievably bottled up in the Congress. There is, however, a plan which would allow these two major candidates to be seen in debate.

Manufacturers are working full speed to produce a vaccine for a new virus strain that threatens to cause an influenza epidemic in this country this winter.

KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 16 -- Four men sat high in the darkness of the Memorial Auditorium, far from the rink below where the Rangers put in another day of training today in preparation for the National Hockey League season.

YONKERS, Sept. 16 -- The fact that Nancy Lynne had broken and been outdistanced in her last start did not deter a crowd of 17,188 from establishing her as a 3-10 favorite to win a $30,400 New York Sire Stake tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
PRAGUE, Sept. 16 -- Thirteen leading Czechoslovak economists replied today to attacks in the Soviet press against the Czechoslovak economic reform and its principal architect, Prof. Ota Sik.

ATHENS, Sept. 16--Premier George Papadopoulos promised today to free all detained Greek politicians next Monday, before the Sept. 29 nationwide vote on a new constitution. Communist prisoners are not to be included.
The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday an average price increase of $89, or 2.9 per cent, for its 1969 cars, compared with the 1968 models.
Bernard Botein will resign Jan. 1 as the Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division for Manhattan and the Bronx, one of the nation's most important courts.

TRENTON, Sept. 16 -- A leading authority on the Mafia told a legislative hearing here today that organized crime sabotaged a harness race track referendum in Secaucus last November after failing to get a piece of the track for itself.
The problem of poverty remains one of the nation's most important and most baffling challenges.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- The American Civil Liberties Union attacked today Mayor Richard J. Daley's televised version of confrontations between the Chicago police and demonstrators during the Democratic National Convention.

WHIMSY flowed around the Theater de Lys last night like a flood and submerged all in sight. Which was a pity. The musical "Month of Sundays" probably deserved a better fate, or at least the ship-wrecked cast deserved a better raft than the flimsy affair provided by the authors.
PRESIDING Justice Bernard Botein leaned back in a large leather chair in his office recently and listened closely to a city detective voicing concern about the administration of justice.

Leaders of the radical Students for a Democratic Society met yesterday with Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, acting president of Columbia, and presented their demands for an end to the university's "racist and militaristic policies."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -Two Johnson Administration officials invoked executive privilege today and declined to testify on a report that Justice Abe Fortas helped formulate an Administration-sponsored bill last May.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 -- The Detroit Tigers ended the New York Yankees' 10-game winning streak tonight with a crunching 9-1 victory and assured themselves a tie for the American League pennant. They were within one game of clinching the flag.

The Metropolitan Opera had its 84th opening at Lincoln Center last night with Maria Callas drawing the cheers in the jampacked lobby while one of her rivals, Renata Tebaldi, prepared to go on stage as the heroine of "Adriana Lecouvreur."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -Vice President Humphrey published today what he called a "serious, practical, detailed blueprint" for dealing with crime, largely through "massive" Federal financial aid to the state and local police, courts and correctional institutions.

BUFFALO -- Mrs. Martin Meyerson peered through her Frank Lloyd Wright stained-glass windows at 11 o'clock the other morning. Outside, perched on a curbstone across the street, was a familiar sight. A young woman, dressed in slacks, pullover and sandals had been there, sketch pad in hand, for more than an hour, her eyes riveted on the Meyersons' somber 64-year-old house. The house, like the windows, was a Frank Lloyd Wright creation.

Someone had the temerity yesterday, in the last tense hours of preparation for opening night, to ask Rudolf Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, what kind of a season he thought it was going to be.

Purdue, Southern California and Notre Dame were rated 1, 2, 3 again yesterday in The Associated Press' major college football poll. However, the rest of the teams in the top 20 underwent a fast shuffle from the preseason rankings.
LAST night the Metropolitan Opera opened its season with Cilea's "Adriana Lecouvreur." One might as well inaugurate a serious drama festival with a soap opera.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- Secretary General Thant reiterated here today that an unconditional halt in the American bombing of North Vietnam was "the essential first step" without which no progress could be made toward a negotiated settlement of the war.
BOSTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Don Buford belted a grand-slam and Brooks Robinson and Boog Powell connected with bases empty tonight as the Baltimore Orioles routed the Boston Red Sox, 8-1.

Spring of 1969 arrived in the boys' wear market this week and the general trade reaction to the styles on display was that the strong fashion emphasis currently under way was paying off at the cash registers.
BUFFALO, Sept. 16 -- The Erie County Democratic organization turned out today for Paul O'Dwyer, the Democratic candidate for Senator. And tomorrow it is scheduled to welcome Vice President Humphrey.

The presiding judge of the marriage court of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has proposed that such tribunals be abolished and that Catholics involved in "intolerable" marriages be permitted to decide for themselves whether they are morally free to remarry.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Industrial production declined nearly 1 per cent in August because of a substantial drop in iron and steel output following the agreement on a new union contract.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -Following is the official summary of the report of the Vice President's special panel on order and justice, which was adopted today by Vice President Humphrey:

New York has acquired the somewhat curious epithet of "Fun City" during the administration of John Vliet Lindsay. I, for one, hope the Mayor is having a good time disregarding the law, sitting on the fence, and giving lip service to much and action to little.

The city's Sanitation Commissioner and the head of the sanitationmen's union agreed yesterday after an unusual inspection tour that the department's facilities for its men in Harlem -- and perhaps the rest of the city -- were substandard.
Army lost a second fullback for the season yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee took a cautious step toward slightly less monetary restraint at its meeting of June 18, in the expectation of early passage of the tax bill, it was disclosed today.

Matt Snell, the fullback for the New York Jets, and Weeb Ewbank, the club's coach and general manager, will try to reach an agreement on a new contract today after practice at Shea Stadium. Snell has said if the Jets do not meet his money terms, then the team must play without him in its next game. against the Boston Patriots at Birmingham, Ala., on Sunday.

The thoroughbreds returned to Belmont Park yesterday and the 27,025 enthusiasts on hand saw Grace Born, a 9-1 shot, win the $29,250 Stymie Handicap. But even during the Stymie the fans were still buzzing about the 136-1 shot that had won three races before.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Sept. 16 -- It was one down and one to go today as Willis Reed, the captain and mainstay of the New York Knickerbockers, signed a contract for this season's play in the National Basketball Association.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 16 -- Last season, his first as a head coach, Tom Boisture made the astounding statement that Holy Cross would win all 10 of its games.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Sept 17 -- Sharp fighting broke out yesterday in jungles around Tayninh, the setting of bitter clashes in the last month.

The World Bank's $250-million bond issue scheduled for sale today will carry a 6 3/8 per cent interest rate, and it will be priced at a discount to yield just slightly more than 6.40 per cent. The terms show a continuation of the rebound in interest rates that began early last month.
Senator Jacob K. Javits called yesterday for tax incentives that would encourage business to get more deeply involved in the antipoverty program.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Federal Power Commission examiners issued decisions today setting price ceilings on natural gas in two of the nation's major producing areas.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -James E. Webb announced today his resignation as head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
